name: Broughton Old Jock Ale (Bottle)
review: Gift from SimonTomlinson. Ruby appearance. Aroma is malt, roasted, toffee and sweet. Flavour is smooth, bitter, malt, toffee, sweet, roasted and brown sugar

name: Broughton Old Jock Ale (Bottle)
review: 500ml bottle. Pours a very dark mahogany with an off white head. Aroma of toffee, caramel, malts, bread, apple, plum. Taste of dark roasted malts, toffee, chocolate, caramel, toast bread, plum, dark fruits, slightly peaty, hint of spices. Mild roasty bitterness on the finish. Medium to full bodied. Very flavoursome and characterful. A rich, complex and extremely satisfying malty ale! P.S. - Surely, this should be tagged as a Scotch Ale / Wee Heavy and not a Strong Ale - English as it currently is?

name: Broughton Old Jock Ale (Bottle)
review: 500ml bottle from Ken Warne, Darlington. Amber brown colour, beige foam head leaving alittle lacing and aroma of malt, bready. Taste is malty, molasses, toasty, bready, dried fruits, with earthy bitterness. Medium bodied, soft carbonation, dry boozy bitter finish. Quite drinkable.

name: Broughton Old Jock Ale (Bottle)
review: Bottle. Nose is burnt toffee, sweet malt, hint of marshmallow, sticky dark fruit. Taste is toffee, dark fruit, dates, sweet malt, brown sugar, burnt sugar, red berry. Mouthfeel is slick. Far better than I was expecting

name: Broughton Old Jock Ale (Bottle)
review: 30Jun2019 Sweet grain and cereal malts, caramel, molasses, toasted bread. Clear brown, medium, creamy, off-white head. Light sweet. Biscuit, toasted bread, sweet grain and cereal malts, caramel, molasses, soft carbonation, medium bodied. Alright. Bottle from Tesco Extra.

name: Ales of Kent Defiance!
review: (Bottle 50 cl) Hazy amber coloured beer, almost flat and hence no real head. Notes of smoked malt and a marked bitter finish. 010902

name: Ales of Kent Defiance!
review: Hazy, brown yellow beer. Citrusy aroma, with tones of apple and merengue. Some smokiness. Malty flavor with tones of toffee. Smoky with OK bitterness.

name: Ales of Kent Defiance!
review: Bottled. Pours orange to amber with average head. Nutty and dry with medium body. Pleasantly malty with nice orangey bitter finish.

name: Ales of Kent Defiance!
review: Defiance! is the most recent offering from one of Kent's most recent microbreweries. An extremely pleasant, softly but interestingly hopped pale ale with a good fruity body. A very satisfying and refreshing drink, full of flavour, but gentle and well rounded. The bottle has a Latin motto: 'Scienta giducia plena provocone' which roughly translates as - The wise have the confidence to challenge! Footnote: The brewery has now closed.

name: Four Alls Smugglers Glory
review: Cask conditioned - no sparkler. Black beer with an off white head (I would have thought this a porter rather than Brown Ale!). There are hints of chocolate in the aroma and hints of chocolate in the taste as well as some maltiness. Quite tasty and drinkable.

name: Four Alls Smugglers Glory
review: Pretty boring brown ale. A little thin and watery. .........................

name: Four Alls Smugglers Glory
review: Dark brown with acidic nose. Medium bodied, clean, acidic finish. ..........

name: Badger IPA
review: Old notes from way back when. Before 2003 certainly. Don’t usually enter pre-RateBeer notes but, since this is retired and I won’t get it again, what the heck. Cask (handpump), tight sparkler. A soft, thin, amber-coloured session bitter of little distinction. Too bland to find glaring faults. Probably dumped in favour of the similar strength King & Barnes Bitter so that Badger could say they hadn’t axed K & B beers altogether. No great loss.

name: Badger IPA
review: Cask Handpump at the Pig & Porcupine, Manchester 31/08/2002 Amber golden coloured slightly pale and fruity. Acidic taste. Hop finish.

name: Badger IPA
review: This beer doesn't seem to react well to bad handling, I have had very good pints, but also very poor ones. The rating is for the better pints, but only give it a try if you trust the Landlord.

name: Badger IPA
review: Hoppy aroma, bit fruity. The beer looks like applejuice. No head. And it's not just the looks; I was amazed I actually tasted apples in the beer, furthermore hoppy and bitter taste. palate is moderate bitter. Not impressive.

name: Badger IPA
review: Clear orange color, hardly any foam. Hoppy aroma. Light hoppy and bitter taste. Not a drain pour, but i would not order it again.

name: Badger IPA
review: Original Rating 4th May 2002 - Had this on draught in a Badger pub. Very out of condition.

name: Badger Dorset Best / Badger Best (Cask)
review: Mid brown, thin head and limited aroma. Traditional English bitter, without being bitter enough for my taste.

name: Badger Dorset Best / Badger Best (Cask)
review: Cask @ St Stephen’s Tavern, Westminster London. As Badger Best. Golden with a thin head. Mildly sticky-sweet texture, not a ’best’ bitter, but drinkable.

name: Badger Dorset Best / Badger Best (Cask)
review: Had this twice, first in Salisbury at The New Inn then later in Chipping Campden. Mild and a bit thin noticeable hops. Best thing was I got a glass.

name: Badger Dorset Best / Badger Best (Cask)
review: A bit watery and not packed with flavour, prefer the tanglefoot, but this is a standard brown bitter. Slightly boring.

name: Badger Dorset Best / Badger Best (Cask)
review: Cask at St Stevens Tavern, Westminster. Copper coloured bitter, main character a slightly spicy fruitiness, medium finish. A good example of west country bitter i guess, but have to say it isn’t my favourite part of the country for local beer.

name: Badger Dorset Best / Badger Best (Cask)
review: Unassuming mid-brown ale in which neither malt nor hops dominate. Head retention is generally close to zero - not a problem if you like it that way. Just isn’t a beer I can get excited about.

name: Badger Dorset Best / Badger Best (Cask)
review: On cask. Another Badger beer and this one seems quite strange. What can I say the lack of sugar is rather noticeable I mean why have such a sour tasting beer as this. At 4% abv your not gonna get drunk on it that easy but its far from exciting this ale to be honest i’d rather drink some lemonade.

name: Badger Dorset Best / Badger Best (Cask)
review: Cask conditioned at the Ship & Shovell, Charing Cross. Amber coloured with next to no head. Aroma had a touch of caramel and a hint of grassy hops. Flavour was slightly sweet before a decent enough bitter finish. Ok, but not memorable.

name: Badger Dorset Best / Badger Best (Cask)
review: Cask (Tasted in London) Amber clear colour with a little head. Light aroma of floral and caramel. Light flavour of caramel and flower notes, nothing special at all, very common cask.

name: Badger Dorset Best / Badger Best (Cask)
review: Cask, handpump @ the conveniently named King’s Arms Inn, Mickleton. Bright and still in the glass and a tawny copper in colour. Head was there then it wasn’t, but I can’t say it was the gravity of the brew (unclean pint glass!?!). Burnt caramel and burnt toast aroma that was sharp and a little unpleasant. Rather dull in the mouth with a flat, filling but lifeless body in desperate need of flavour. Bitter, burnt caramel and toffee shines through with a flavour I can only best describe as burnt, soggy newspapers. Finish is tannic and claps out with nothing showing in the aftertaste. This was as boring as hell and any characteristics it showed just did not work. A wishy-washy bitter!!!

name: Badger Tanglefoot (Bottle/Can)
review: Aroma of fruits, malt and a hint of hay. Golden with a white head. Medium + sweet and medium bitter. Medium + body with average to soft carbonation. Slightly dry and bitter finish. Overall a decent Strong Bitter.

name: Badger Tanglefoot (Bottle/Can)
review: Yes, can. Unlike the cask that I tried 4 years ago which I remember extremely well. (Actually I have no idea). This pours with a bleach white foam and medium gold body, with nothing but rotting grain on the nose. The flavour is soft Hallowe'en candies, those chewy caramel types, and a fair bit of tin thrown in. Cloying sugariness. Wow, just.... I can't even, as the reddit incel moderators say. Just a pile of caramelly junk.

name: Badger Tanglefoot (Bottle/Can)
review: 0,5l bottle @ Vihreä Haltiatar. Pours clear golden with a medium head. Aroma is sweet malts. Flavor is sweet malts with some hops. Decent.

name: Badger Tanglefoot (Bottle/Can)
review: Bottle from Waitrose. #4 MJ 500 beer of this 2019 summer trip. Medium gold with a tall, fine head. Nose is lightly citrus hops, bit of bread, touch of cardboard and pear. Lightly spicy hops. Rather plain. Falvor is lemony, almost a touch of candy in there, tart from the hops. Some white bread and sweetness. interesting hops. Prickly, lightly bitter finish. Rather fizzy, lager-like. Ok but certainly not all that profound. This was probably one of the first wave of UK golden ales that went for the lager market, but it has been surpassed abundantly by this time. Not up there with Summer Lightning even, I would say. Still drinkable but would not be in anyone's 500 today.

name: Badger Tanglefoot (Bottle/Can)
review: Bottle 5% Pours great with a lovely head caramel taste in the background, But not as I remember it, no body and weak and watery No substance or hop taste either.

name: Badger Tanglefoot (Bottle/Can)
review: Can brewed in England. Aroma of pear and a little hops. Gold in colour. Large, moderately-lasting head with a fair few bubbles. Moderate-light carbonation, taste is earthy malt with some grassy hop lurking in the background. A touch metallic at the end, but then a lingering biscuity maltness. Something of an indoor, slightly later in the day beer.

name: Badger Tanglefoot (Bottle/Can)
review: 500ml bottle at home. Clear dark gold white head standard malt bitter bready notes

name: Badger Tanglefoot (Bottle/Can)
review: Danke (?) an minutemat. Hellmalzig getreidiger, weich herber Beginn. Leicht hopfiger Mittelteil, würzig-herb, süffig. Mittellanger, zunehmend bitterer Abgang. Nett. 8/9/10/9/6/9

name: Badger Tanglefoot (Bottle/Can)
review: Bottle 500 ml from Co-op. Aroma is malts, grain, caramel, subtle citrus and fruitiness. Clear golden body and white head. Refreshing beer with malts, caramel, grain, some citrus. Grainy aftertaste. Dry palate. I love this kind of Brit ales.

name: Badger Tanglefoot (Bottle/Can)
review: Mörkare gyllengul öl med vitt skum. Doft och smak är maltig, lättare karamelltoner och typisk ESB-beska.

name: Ballards Midhurst Mild
review: Cask, hand-pulled half pint in the Barley Mow, Portsmouth: lunchtime on 12th March 2017. Red/amber hue to the brown body, weak off-white head. Malty lead, middle and finish: light, dark maltiness throughout in fact. A nice, easy drinking low gravity Mild, liked it.

name: Ballards Midhurst Mild
review: Cask. Amber Brown. Malty; roasty malts, grainy, caramel, chocolate notes. Fruity; some dark fruits. Light hops. Bitter roast malty fruity. Dry roasty finish. OK. Easy drinking Mild. (2008)

name: Ballards Midhurst Mild
review: Cask at Chippenham Beer Festival. Brown. Smoky with lots of chocolate and some maltiness. Full flavoured but easy-drinking. Reminded me how much I love milds.

name: Ballards Midhurst Mild
review: Cask, gravity dispense at Twickenham Beer Festival 2015. Dark amber brown, almost cloudy, still, small off-white head. Aroma is plummy, fruity malt sweetness. Body is medium to light, smooth. Taste is light chocolatey malt, more plum, sweet finish but not watery or insipid. Pretty good mild.

name: Ballards Midhurst Mild
review: From cask. Pours hazy brown with a small tan head. Aroma is roasted malty and breadish. Roasted malty, breadish and dry caramelish. Bitter and dark roasted malty into the finish.

name: Ballards Midhurst Mild
review: Half at the Lyndhurst in Reading. Very dark brown with red highlights and a fair head on it. Very roasty, almost burnt, bitter, malty, tasty. Roasty aroma, with a hint of chocolate. A decent tipple.

name: Ballards Midhurst Mild
review: Cask at the South Western Arms - St Denys (So’ton) - 09/09/12. Mid chestnut brown with a thin tan head that soon clears to the edge of the glass. Weak aroma to this beer, a little nuttiness and balsamic vinegar. Light malt taste with some biscuit and faint toffee. Light bodied, quite wet, pretty bland!

name: Ballards Midhurst Mild
review: Cask at the Wandsworth Common Spring BF, London. Pours clear, red-brown with a foamy-bubbly, white head. Smells like dirty leather. Lightly sweet wth more dirt, leather, wet earth. Light bodied with fine carbonation. Faint cocoa to finish with more wet leather, faint fruits and dirt. Not too good.

name: Ballards Midhurst Mild
review: Cask at the Four Chestnuts, Chichester. Deep ruby red with fine beige crema, roasty malt nose, dry palate with hints of tart fruit and coffee, then a dry bitter choc finish.

name: Ballards Midhurst Mild
review: scura buona schiuma media persistenza naso delicato fruttato un tocco di cioccolato e cafe leggero toffe poco amara ma non dolce

name: Ballards Trotton Bitter
review: Half pint handpulled at Far From the Madding Crowd on a quiet and lazy Sunday afternoon in Oxford. Deep golden brown body with only a ring of bubbles at the surface. Vague hop floral nose. Soft hoppy taste with a smooth bitter finish. Average British bitter (16.03.2008).

name: Ballards Trotton Bitter
review: 1. Cask Stillage at the GBBF, Kensington Olympia 03/08/2001 Mid brown coloured bitter with wheat flavours and some sour fruit in a hop finish. 2. Cask Handpump at the Bath Hotel, Sheffield 30/04/2005 Amber with some alcohol and fruitiness. Nutty biiter finish that lasts.

name: Ballards Trotton Bitter
review: Copper colour. Restrained malt and hops. Not packed with flavour, but a decent dry session bitter. Not much else to say really. Cask (gravity dispense), Battersea Beer Festival 2005.

name: Ballards Trotton Bitter
review: Cask Conditioned at Hook Norton Beer Festival. Light brown with thin head. Easy drinking pale bitter with a thin malty background and a smooth hoppiness which dries to a lasting finish.

name: Ballards Best Bitter
review: Thick, dark, chewy in the mouth. A Saturday lunchtime pint over a gentle lunch. Class beer. Never had it before. Thank you for introducing me to an oral tastebomb.

name: Ballards Best Bitter
review: Cask at GBBF 2018. It pours clear rich brown with a small bubbly white head. The aroma is sweet, oily, brown, toasted nut, wood, light plastic and sweaty cardboard. The taste is dry, bitter, oily, earthy, brown bread, sticky, treacle, black tea, light spice and chewy malt. With a drying finish. Medium body and soft carbonation. Oily and slick. Not bad for an old skool bitter.

name: Ballards Best Bitter
review: Cask (backlog). Ambery orange colour with a mediumsized fluffy head, that leaves some lace. Aroma is bready malts, some nutty notes, mild wood, resin as well as a bit toasted and floral. Flavour is floral, wooden, resiny along with mild nutty notes as well as some caramel and mild sweet bready malts.

name: Ballards Best Bitter
review: Bottle - BCA; heavy crusty sediment. Copper in colour. Malty; sweet toasty malts, toffee, caramel; slightly syrupy. Fruity; citrus fruity; marmalade. Hoppy; earthy hops. Full flavoured. Sweet malty and quite fruity throughout with a balancing hop bitterness. Dry hoppy finish. Decent Bitter.

name: Ballards Best Bitter
review: A bit of a murky copper with not much of a head. Hints of caramel malt in the aroma. Taste is a bit too much like bitter coffee.

name: Ballards Best Bitter
review: 0,5L bottle. Mouldy aroma. Light taste and watery malt beer. The best part of this beer is enjoyable bitter finish. Other is watery and tasteless infusion.

name: Ballards Best Bitter
review: Cask (gravity) @ The 17th Reading Beer and Cider Festival 2011, Reading, Berkshire England. Clear medium orange amber colour with a average, frothy and open, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, nutty, earthy, keller - damp stain - fusty, chestnut, malty. Flavor is moderate sweet and light bitter with a average to long duration, rubber, sweet malt, sweet caramel. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is flat. [20110430]

name: Ballards Best Bitter
review: Bottle from Sainsbury, tried at ölföreningens english ale test. A welldone bitter, frutis, caramelmalts and hops in good balance. Rather dry finish.

name: Ballards Best Bitter
review: cask at guilford arms ...copper ... bubbly off white head ... soft light smokey toffee msalt nose ...light bitter front ... soft wooody toffee malts

name: Ballards Best Bitter
review: 50cl bottle from the Home Brew Shop, Aldershot. A brilliant golden amber appearance with a trace of white head; earthy, malty aroma; straightforward malty flavour; lighlty hopped finish. Exactly what a bitter shourld be like.

name: Ballards Wild
review: Cask at the St. Albans Beer & Cider Festival 2017. Pours clear red/brown with a small off-white head. Aroma of malt, fruit, toffee and cooked veg. Medium plus sweetness and light to moderate bitterness. Medium body, oily texture, soft carbonation.

name: Ballards Wild
review: Cask at PoW, Farnborough. Nil aroma (possibly courtesy of a snooty nose but a mate concurred). Dark (flat) cola brown. No head. Initially light bitter and umami, before a sweetness creeps in. Caramel. Cola again. Malts. Medium bodied. Slick on the teeth. Soft carbonation. An own brand cola mild?! Certainly more mild than porter. I liked it - bland but rescued by the sweet streak.

name: Ballards Wild
review: RBESG 09 Sheffield. Brown with a thin lasting brown head. Nutty aroma, sweet roasted malty taste, with toffee taste and some chocolate. Ok

name: Ballards Wild
review: Tasted this at the Paisley Beer Festival in April 2007. Cask, gravity dispense. Dark ruby red in colour with an off white head. Strong malty fruit notes come through in the long aroma. Creamy mouthfeel and poor lacing. Dark malts give a malty fruit loaf flavour with rum soaked raisins and black grapes. Dry hopped aftertaste provides a stark contrast to the fruity malt. Finish is dry and very woody with hints of oaked vanilla. Excellent session ale.

name: Ballards Wild
review: Cask at Battersea Beer Festival, 10th Feb 2011. Rich deep copper brown colour. Little head. Full, weighty palate. Pretty malty.

name: Ballards Wild
review: Cask conditioned handpump William IV Brighton. A mahogany coloured beer with a whitish head and lacing. Warming malty notes throughout. Coffee flavours and sweet woodiness in the mouth. Nice bready malts. There are hints of sourness in the nose but it’s a pretty tasty beer with good depth.

name: Ballards Wild
review: [bottle @ RBESG 2009, Grant Tasting] Nutty and slightly toasty malt aroma with no hops and a little toffee. Almost clear, almost opaque dark brown under dots and a white ring. Nice toffee caramel nut flavour with a little bitterness. Light body, low carbonation, slightly nutty bitter finish.

name: Ballards Wild
review: 5th May 2008. This is a blend of Midhurst Mild and Wassail. Dark brown beer with an almost Belgian style sourness. Very dry with just a hint of poterish smoke. Better when cold!

name: Ballards Wild
review: Bottle @ RBESG 09 Shefield ...deep brown ... thin lacing ... sweet toffee .. light roast malt ... little caramel ... toffee ... some burnt suger.

name: Ballards Wild
review: Cask gravity, The Crown Summer BF 09, Nuneaton. Headless jelly red, not especially porterish. Pleasant buttery red wine buttery aroma with vanilla and Marmite. That’s pushing an 8. Redcurrant and Bovril, lick of salt, chocolate, oak. Bittersweet and woodsy with very pleasant roast and berry hints. Buttery but it works.

name: Ballards Nyewood Gold
review: Cask oro lieve citrico note vegetali non molto secca amaro abbastanza contenuto

name: Ballards Nyewood Gold
review: I was rather enjoying this until my housemate knocked it over. Poured a nice gold with a white head. The smell was dominated by a sweet malt and the taste had a nice bitterness.

name: Ballards Nyewood Gold
review: [Bottle from Uppark House, Sussex] Pours golden-amber with a slight white head. Twiggy English hops throughout, with a bit of lemon here, some farmyard there. Might have worked better in a darker bitter, but lacks the crispness you want in a golden ale. Pretty poor really.

name: Ballards Nyewood Gold
review: 500ml Bottle - Golden with a foamy white head. Malt, grass and a hint of dried fruit in the aroma. Fruity, malty and slightly earthy taste with notes of lemon, grain and earthy hops.

name: Ballards Nyewood Gold
review: 500ml bottle. Felt slightly over carbonated on opening but then its bottle conditioned and a bit livelier than filtered ales. Yeast profile was the most discernable element. I brew my own full mash ales and this was remeniscent of ales I’ve brewed in the past. I’ve had this on tap before and its alot hoppier from the barrel. Doesnt really work from the bottle.

name: Ballards Nyewood Gold
review: Bottle 500ml. Clear medium orange yellow colour with a small to average, frothy - fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted - caramel, sweet malt, fruity. Flavour is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration, sweet malt, sugary, fruity, yeasty. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20120331]

name: Ballards Nyewood Gold
review: Bottle 50 cl. Courtesy of fonefan. Pours a clear golden with a white head. Fruity nose with a honeyish twist. Light body, again fruity, a little phenols and a surprisingly bitter finish. 030412

name: Ballards Nyewood Gold
review: 50 cL bottle. Pours clear and golden orange with a small white head. Aroma is mild fruity and light yeasty. Bitter and light fruity flavoured. Dry and crisp hoppy into the finish.

name: Ballards Nyewood Gold
review: Bottle @ FOneFan. Slightly hazy amber with small white head. Aroma is malt, fruit, hops and bread. Flavour is malt, fruit, little caramel, hops, little harsh, bread, medium sweet and a little bitter.

name: Ballards Nyewood Gold
review: Bottle @ Fonefan tasting. Nice head with good duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste are malt, bread, fruits and hops.

name: Ballards Wassail
review: 3rd beer on a ’random tasting evening’ with myself on 21st July 2017. 500ml bottle BBE July 2017, obtained from the English Heritage site at Roman Wroxeter (Shropshire). Poured slowly into a lovely vase shaped pint glass, badged for ’Old Speckled Hen’. Misty light brown pour, a dirty amber maybe: full and deep off-white blanket of foam on top. Shit, it’s been skunked, left in the sun on a shelf for too long: can’t drink it: bollox! I hate pouring beers down the sink, but this is undrinkable. Scored as I found it.

name: Ballards Wassail
review: Bottle. Orangey/Red in colour. Very prominent deep creamy head. Fruity; tangy citrus-fruity, orange marmalade. Malty; toasty malts, caramel, toffee. Hoppy; rather earthy hops. Spicy. Rather vinous. Alcohol quite noticeable. Sweet fruity throughout leading to a dry malty finish. Enjoyed this. Good beer! (2009-07)

name: Ballards Wassail
review: Bottle from Warkworth Castle. Gusher. Pours murky amber brown with a thick off-white head. Aromas are bretty, this has clearly picked up a wild yeast somewhere along the line. Loads of sherbet, wood, funky yeast and forest floor. Unintentional, I’ll bet, but actually not bad. Taste is red fruit, wood, horse blanket. Dry finish. Better than expected, for a bottle that’s probably sat on the shelf in a warm gift shop for nearly a year.

name: Ballards Wassail
review: English Heritage branded bottle. This poured a hazy dark amber ale colour with a small near white head with an aroma of nuts and berries. Some lacing; fruity sweet, apple peel, berries, honey and a lasting alcohol/bitter taste in the finish. Not bad.

name: Ballards Wassail
review: Bottle from the Lincoln Christmas Market. As English Heritage Wassail. Hazy amber colour with virtually no head. Aroma burnt orange peel, taste mainly sweet to mid bitter sweet.

name: Ballards Wassail
review: English Heritage branded bottle. Rich dark amber ale with a thinnish, but lasting white head. Nose is red berries with a touch of honey. Taste is surprisingly light, with berries, heathers, floral notes and honey. There’s a beery/alcohol taste in the finish/nose. Some slight saltiness.

name: Ballards Wassail
review: From cask. Pours cloudy orange with a small white head. Aroma is apples and slight citric. Fruity. Toasted malty. Mild citric. Toasted and dry citric. Flat malty and fruity finish.

name: Ballards Wassail
review: A mid amber orange coloured beer with a frothy white head. A rich fruity aroma, red fruit and a malt loaf aroma that also brings forth a nuttiness. Medium-dry mouthfeel. A rich fruity and malty taste. Loads of red and dried fruits, a molasses and treacle malt loaf sweetness, then a dry nuttiness comes through, that is then followed by a mildly bitter hop flavour in the finish. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Hadrian & Border Reiver's IPA
review: Cask at White Cross. Pours a clear gold with a white head that lasts throughout the beer. Aroma has leaves and wet grains with a slight nuttiness underlying. Flavor has straw and grains up front with leaves and a light nuttiness backing.

name: Hadrian & Border Reiver's IPA
review: Half from cask. Amber in colour with little head. Taste a bit hoppy with a little citrus. Pleasant enough, but nothing special ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Hadrian & Border Reiver's IPA
review: Cask in the Cottage Inn near Craster. Amber with a thin off white head. Mild grapefruit and peach aroma. Pleasant bitter flavour with citrus and peach over toast.

name: Hadrian & Border Reiver's IPA
review: Pendle Beer Festival 2016. Golden-yellow in colour. Has a decent hop malt balance, with more of the former evident. Certainly sessionable.

name: Hadrian & Border Reiver's IPA
review: Cask (Duke of Wellington, Newcastle) - Amber in colour. Toffee, peach and sultanas in the aroma. Malty and slightly sweet taste with toffee, peach and apricot.

name: Hadrian & Border Reiver's IPA
review: On draft. Deep copper with no head. Very mild floral aroma. Flavour is sweet and malty, slightly honeyed, mildly bitter. Decent.

name: Hadrian & Border Reiver's IPA
review: Cask (handpump) @ Ackhorne, 9 St. Martins Lane, York, North Yorkshire, England YO1 6LN. Clear medium orange color with a average, frothy, fair lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, caramel, fruity, light to moderate hoppy, earthy notes. Flavor is moderate sweet and light bitter with a average to long duration, fruity, straw, tart malt. Body is medium to light, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft to flat. [20130121]

name: Hadrian & Border Reiver's IPA
review: Cask at Ealing. Creamy offwhite good mostly lasting head. Yellow colour. Moderate malty and hoppy aroma. Moderate bitter flavor. Average moderate bitter finish. Oily palate.

name: Hadrian & Border Reiver's IPA
review: Cask at North Birmingham Beer Festival; light copper pour with off white head, sweet malt aroma, biscuity malt taste a hint of citrus.

name: Hadrian & Border Reiver's IPA
review: [cask at Cloisters, Edinburgh] Pours a clear gold, with a straw aroma mingled with some fruity hop. Some malt on the flavour, with a second dose of zesty hop on the finish. Decent British IPA [18012012]

name: Yards Old Ale
review: Sweet, roasty and vinous. The plummy dark fruit flavors blend with a little bit of toffee and maple and there are blackberries and acidity in there too. Ends witha dry (tobacco?) note and a hint of smoke/char. May be past its porime (’99 bottle) but still quite tasty.

name: Yards Old Ale
review: 1999 Vintage (tasted on 1/5/05). Poured a dark reddish-brown with a huge (almost 5 finger) off white head. Aromas and tastes of dark fruits (raisins), chocolate, licorice and a little smoky. Some sour cherries lurking in the background and at the finish. Lightly sweet. Lively carbonated body with a nice dry finish. This one aged well and I’m glad I picked it up.

name: Yards Old Ale
review: (Vintage 1999) Huge light brown head of tiny bubbles. Settles very slowly. Great carbonation which keeps a thin foam on the surface. Rich aroma of raisins, chocolate covered cherries, tobacco and a dusty dryness. Color is a deep dark brown/red. Bit of sweetness and a good helping of raisins, dry smoky tobacco and a nice bitterness. Finish is dry and a little bitter. Very good old ale that has aged well. Little strange flavor in that it is very dry and dusty. Still quite good though.

name: Yards Old Ale
review: Pours with a huge, rocky head that refuses to settle down. It leaves an impressive lace, actually more of a sea foam impression than lace. The aroma is mostly malt sweetness with a hint of cherry. The taste is interesting. Very prominent malt flavors which remind me of a good bourbon's sweetness. Some fruitiness is also apparent, but it doesn't seem to be a single flavor. The alcohol is noticable, and the finish is a touch too bitter in that the bitterness seems to linger. And with all the sweetness, there is a slight sourness on the aftertaste. The mouthfeel is a little edgy, with strong carbonation attacking the tongue and gums. This may help offset the sweetness a touch.

name: Yards Old Ale
review: This is a strong beer with a sweet flavor. It can be cranky at times. It's at its best if you get it cask conditioned.

name: Yards Old Ale
review: (cask-conditioned version)A great british style strong ale. dark coffee colour with a frothy head. very malty and rich but has no cloying sweetness.

name: Yards Old Ale
review: Malt! Malt! Malt! This is one of my favorite beers. These guys/gals know how to brew, I havent had a bad beer from them. I love the carmelized taste and strong malt backbone on this authentic tasting English Strong Ale.

name: Yards Old Ale
review: Had it cask conditioned and it is one of the top five beers I've ever had. Not near as good in the bottle, this rating is for the cask conditioned version.

name: Yards Old Ale
review: A unique flavor - strong alcohol taste with light malt flavor. .............

name: Yards Saison (pre-2009)
review: Old Bottle from Todd, unknown date but it has the older style label. A careful pour yields a brilliantly clear deep golden color with a huge bubbly white head that persists. Light oxidation that is sherry and faint cardboard but the aroma and flavor are still earthy spicy saison. Surprised it held up so well given the abv,

name: Yards Saison (pre-2009)
review: DATE REVIEWED: July 24, 2014... GLASSWARE: La Fin du Monde tulip... OCCASION: just watched Earth to Echo--fun, but not E.T. ...APPEARANCE: hazy, glowing golden orange body; an armada of bubbles cascades upward into a white, frothy, three-finger head that leaves thick cumulous clouds... AROMA: candied sugar, hay and lemon zest--missing the signature barnyard yeasts, though--definite allspice, cumin and coriander... PALATE: lively, active in the teeth; medium-bodied, with a long drawn-out, welcome aftertaste; sessionable but somewhat substantial... TASTE: apple, raisin, grape, zesty lemon, anise and cumin combine to create an abbey-like profile without the alcohol... OVERALL: one of the first (THE first?!) saison I had, and this bottle rewards well within my price range ($8.99 for a six); quite flavorful for the thirst-quenching expectations; Yards dos not often disappoint, and they do not here...

name: Yards Saison (pre-2009)
review: On draft at Soacebar Falls Church VA. Pours a hazy gold with a white head. Banana aroma. Flavors of citrus and spice. Decent saison.

name: Yards Saison (pre-2009)
review: didn’t know it was reformulated in 2009. when this was at it’s best it was toasted white bread with the appropriate Belgian ale spice of coriander. sweet with caramel and citrus fruit and a almost moderate body and low vegetable character.

name: Yards Saison (pre-2009)
review: Hazy yellowish pour in the glass with lots of sediment. Nose is candy and malt. Taste is citrus and light hops. Rated 12/11/2000

name: Yards Saison (pre-2009)
review: A- nice cloudy amber/yellow with fluffy white head that fades to a pretty strange lacing that looks almost like curdles floating around on the top. S-kinda gross. very macro-malty. T- nice yeasty taste with hints of citrus; very mild hop afterbite. P- light carbonation with light body...very smooth. nice. O- Saison by definition is supposed to be drinkable and this beer sure is. Serving type: bottle Reviewed on: 04-13-2007 17:42:59

name: Yards Saison (pre-2009)
review: Bottle. Pours a hazy golden body with a white head. Citrus and pear juices, some bread y sweet notes with a yeast y body. Hardly a saison more like a sweet Belgian style ale.

name: Yards Saison (pre-2009)
review: 12oz thats been in my cellar for a long time. Pours orange with bubbly carbonation and a tan ring. Nose is swet with a nice fresh scent. Taste is yucky yucky bland.

name: Yards Saison (pre-2009)
review: [1277-20080410] 355mL bottle. Floral toasted yeast aroma with a mild hint of off-ness. Clear, medium yellow body with a quick white bubbly head. Sweet flower petals flavour is toasted with a bit of vegetable and a sweet aftertaste. Light body is a bit thin. Fair, boring. (c/o GregClow, w/ blankboy, HogTownHarry, jerc, tupalev) Overheard: "Smells a little like toast in all of them... Toast Juice!"

name: Yards Saison (pre-2009)
review: THOUGHTS: Really nice. Especially when it warmed up. I don’t know why I tasted and smelled vanilla, where no one else seemed to, but I did and that made it even better. TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a light orange or dark yellow with tiny body particles of average thickness and a very small, fizzy, off-white head that mostly diminished. The aroma was light citrus hops, light doughy yeast and vanilla. The initial flavor was moderately sweet and lightly acidic; while the finish was heavily acidic and very sour with an average duration. there was citrus, slight vanilla and a little funk then a ton of sour lime. the light to medium body was watery then dry with tingly carbonation and a moderate to heavy astringent finish.

name: Brakspear Bitter (Bottle)
review: Clear dark amber beer with short dark white head, no smell, taste is cereal, malty but not sweet, light grass, bitter, bread, soft carbonation, creamy texture, medium body, long bitter finish (I have 0.5l bottle with best-before 11 May 20 and batch L B9070 17:39)

name: Brakspear Bitter (Bottle)
review: Zapach s³odowy z nutami karmelowymi. W smaku delikatne, chmielowe. Goryczka œrednia, zio³owo-trawiasta.

name: Brakspear Special (Bottle)
review: Very nice beer bought in my local hotel in Andover Hampshire. First time I’ve seen this on offer

name: Brakspear Special (Bottle)
review: Old rate. Bottle from original Brakspear brewery in Henley from a private order through the LCBO in 2004. Tasted in that year, rating pulled from old notebook I just recovered from storage. Pours a solid copper with smallish white head. Aroma is lush and British; biscuity malt, caramel sweetness. Taste is moderately bitter but satisfying. Excellent for the style and ABV.

name: Brakspear Special (Bottle)
review: Bought this at Lee’s in Henderson NV and I have no idea how old the bottle was. Thin and watery and nothing special. I am sure MJ writes about a on tap or cask verison of this beer on page 74 of his Great Beer Guide and only 456 Classic Brews to go out of 500.

name: Brakspear Special (Bottle)
review: Poured amber with a short lasting beige head. Mild malt aroma. Toffee notes at the start with a harsh bitter finish. Quite unbalanced and a little thin. Not great.

name: Brakspear Special (Bottle)
review: Darkish brown beer with a lightly hopped aroma and a lightly malted but more hopped flavour. Overall a very reasonable beer.

name: Brakspear Special (Bottle)
review: The aroma is very lightly fruity. The color is an unclear amber and it has a flat head. The flavor is a lovely slightly sweet fruity flavor from a really good malt blend. It also has a really good aroma hops - but it is most significant in the flavor. It ends on a lovely bitterness. All in all a fantastic flavor - but the palate is a little light.

name: Brakspear Special (Bottle)
review: This was my last bottle from the Henley Brewery. No more will we be able to drink Brakspears as it should be. Bye Bye o fair brewery, may those that sold you down the river burn in hell.

name: Brakspear Special (Bottle)
review: I don't know why I like this brewery so darn much - some of their beer are just ordinary, like this one. I thought it was a touch bitter and one-dimensional. Bland.

name: Brakspear Special (Bottle)
review: Fresh hoppy aroma reddish on colour with small creamy head. Very highly hopped taste wih a very bitter dry and long lasting finish. A good but perhaps little too bitter beer for my liking

name: Brakspear Special (Bottle)
review: Bottled. Copper bronze, low head and moderate condition. Good caramel and peppery hop aromas leading to a nicely balanced body with plenty of malt and hops to keep your attention and a hint of vinegar character. Finish is sweet with a long hop bitterness. Complex and tasty for such a low abv. A hard act to follow for the new brewers.

name: Yards Extra Special Ale (ESA)
review: Tap at Strangelove in cask. Hazy brown pour. Nose is cardboard, floral, and pine. Taste sof florals, caramel, toast. Ok

name: Yards Extra Special Ale (ESA)
review: 12 ounce bottle. CLear copper color. Large rocky beige head. Spicy toasted malt nose. Soft, silky toasted malt flavor. Notes of caramel and herbal hops. Easy drinking and very "English". Earthy malt and spicy hops in finish round this ale out nicely.

name: Yards Extra Special Ale (ESA)
review: Poured from a bottle into a pint glass. Aroma is of caramel, roasted oats, and a hint of citrus hops. A nice white head rapidly vanished; little lacing. Nice amber color is present. Flavor is a mix of honey, malt, citrus bitter bite, and a boozy warmth. Much better when offered on a handpump at a bar (true cask feel). Cheers!

name: Yards Extra Special Ale (ESA)
review: DATE: September 2, 2016... OCCASION: much work was done today, of the spreadsheet variety... GLASSWARE: Barley Creek pint... dark amber, almost opaque body that evokes a black and tan... the creamy head, off-white and smooth, almost lactic... tough to see, but bubbly enough... nutty, caramel sweet, slightly buttery with some suggestion of citrus and hop... the first sip is sweet, soft, smooth and savory--easily can see how this "helped establish" a cask ale following... flavorful, caramel-empowered, malt-forward profile... the nuttiness is also pronounced, with a lingering citrus--orange, mostly , with grapefruit--with pear strengthening the flavor... glass lacing is thick, filmy and significant... a delicious, full-bodied ESB that finishes strongly and invites the next... at 6% ABV, substantial but drinkable...

name: Yards Extra Special Ale (ESA)
review: I poured it from the bottle into a pint glass. It pours amber with a white head and lacing. The aroma is caramel and floral hops. The taste is caramel, nut, and slightly bitter hops. The bitter mixes nicely with the caramel sweetness. This is a nicely balanced and sessionable ale.

name: Yards Extra Special Ale (ESA)
review: On tap at the brewery. Pours a clear copper brown with medium off white head leaving sticky lacing. The aroma is bread and floral. Medium mouth, cocoa, toffee, grain, bitter finish.

name: Yards Extra Special Ale (ESA)
review: Yellowish clear appearance with a hoppy aroma. Taste of pine and citrus. Good ale but not amazing. On tap at cask fest.

name: Yards Extra Special Ale (ESA)
review: Bottle from Perfect Pour. Nice ameber body with slight head. Nose is spicy and hoppy. Taste spicy with good hops and caramel in there. Smooth carbonation.

name: Yards Extra Special Ale (ESA)
review: Pours copper-amber with a one finger off white head with decent lacing. Aroma is of toasted bready malts, caramel, sweet malts, floral hops, toffee, light pine, and light grassy hops. Taste is pretty similar to the aroma. Has a medium body with a slightly watery mouthfeel and a mostly sweet, medium finish. Overall, a pretty nice bitter that is easy drinking.

name: Yards Extra Special Ale (ESA)
review: slight malt aroma. brown and clear in color with light head. balanced flavor, bold caramels malts, slight roastyness, slight hop finish

name: Brakspear Mild Ale
review: Cask at the Bull, Bell Street, Henley. Back in production, and being brewed at the Bell Street Brewery at the back of the Bull. An attractive tawny brown pour with a cherry red gleam and tight cream head; aroma of toast; thin at first with a fruity sweetness, then some soft oaty grains add body; the finish is dry with lingering licorice. A proper old-fashioned mild.

name: Brakspear Mild Ale
review: Cask-Conditioned, Saracens Head, Henley. Dark brown. Malty aroma. Very malty flavour! -slightly sweet. Very good mild.

name: Brakspear Old Ale
review: Cask at the Bull on Bell Street, Henley. Pours dark amber, with a small off white head. Aroma of toffee, roasted malt, nut, hint of chocolate, dark fruits and molasses. Medium sweetness and bittrrness. Medium body, oily texture, average to soft carbonation. Bitterness increasing in finish. A good beer.

name: Brakspear Old Ale
review:
It must be 20 years since I’ve had a pint of this. Paler than I remember and perhaps a little thinner, it still has a pleasant aroma of caramel and a likeable enough malty palate. But despite being highly rated in its day, it doesn’t really hit the true heights now. OK, it’s been through the mill and is presently brewed at a
…

name: Brakspear Old Ale
review:
Cask at the Bull, Bell Street, Henley - where this is being brewed again. A bright, reddish chestnut colour with a thin cream head that provided lots of lacing; the aroma seemed rather smoky, but this may have been due to the woodfire burning in the pub; sweet, earthy, malt taste to start, then developing more
…

name: Brakspear Old Ale
review:
Tasted this in the Bull Inn, Paisley in January 1999. Cask, handpump dispense. Clear copper red in colour with a thin white head. Slight hint of toffee malt in the short aroma. Thin mouthfeel and good lacing. Pale malts give a sweet maltloaf base with weak caramel and watery redcurrants. Really strong chemical
…

name: Brakspear Old Ale
review:
Cask Stillage at the Parr Hall, Warrington 12/10/2002 Mid brown coloured with some spice aroma. Strong in alcohol. Slightly dry malt
…

name: Brakspear Old Ale
review: Cask Conditioned at The Swan, Banbury. Chestnut coloured with bubbly head. Rich malted, roasted chestnut flavours. Sweet and yet dry on the palate, caramel hints and fruity body.

name: Brakspear Old Ale
review: Tested Cask-Conditioned. Brakspear’s Old Ale, a dark brown colour, with strong aromas. Full-bodied, strong and satisfying, malty. A very good pint.

name: Fuller's Vintage Ale 1999
review: Bottle #70754. Purchased directly from the brewery in January 2007 and saved for a special occasion (earned my doctorate). Poured into an English pint. Redish brown hue a small beige head. Lots of visible carbonation at first but subsides. Aroma is caramel, sweet malts, a hint of sherry. Initial taste is caramel malt, dates, chocolate, rum, and a hint of alcohol. Aftertaste is caramel, sweet malts, and a very faint hoppiness. Palate is smooth... silky. Carbonation is mild. This is exactly what I hoped it would be.

name: Fuller's Vintage Ale 1999
review: Aroma is raisins, dried figs, other dried fruit, vanilla, very complex. Taste is smooth and drinkable, raisin juice. Incredibly drinkable. Not too strong and not harsh at all. Creme brulee all the way. Nice.

name: Fuller's Vintage Ale 1999
review: (bottle) very opalescent deep amber colour with a frothy light-beige head. aroma of green pears and raisins, with a hint of dried prunes, some medium sherry and bubble gum. flavour is mostly cornflakes, yeast slurry and dried fruits, with lots of brown sugar, some chocolate raisins and a slightly tannic moist wood finish. medium-bodied with average carbonation. great!

name: Fuller's Vintage Ale 1999
review: Bottle. Hazy brown-amber color with beige head. Aroma is vineous, prunes, toffee. Taste is prunes, red grapes, dried fruits, much more interesting than the newer ones, which were only malt and dust. Oily mouthfeel with low carbonation. Seriously great.

name: Fuller's Vintage Ale 1999
review: Bottle. Backlog. Dark brown with brown head. Aroma malts bread toffee. Taste sweet malts. Nice beer.

name: Fuller's Vintage Ale 1999
review: A big thanks to Fin for pulling this bottle out of his cellar to share! Pours a muddy orange/brown with a tan head. The smell is deep fruit, some oxidation, caramel. The taste is brown sugar, crisp and dry fruit also showing some hints of oxidation. Medium/full with fine carbonation. Wow!

name: Fuller's Vintage Ale 1999
review: Bottle 58057 Dark brown with a smll fleeting tn head. Complex aroma of molasses, brown sugar, and dried fruits. The flavor is very sweet, cloying. Boozy. Ok but too sweet for my tastes.

name: Fuller's Vintage Ale 1999
review: Bottle number 12597 . drank from a Chimay goblet @ room temp. I started a thread asking if this was past its prime recently , as the oneline Fullers shop had bottles going , this stuff is becoming obscure to locate . The view from my thread was differing on its condition ! I cracked this bitch open today as its FA cup final day .A classy sherry malt nose , cake , booze , jamish cherry . paint , wood ,. A sophisticated accent .. poured out glowing burnt peach with a small’ish beige head . this feels more robust and potent than 8/5 %.. which is a inevitable at this age . It is pretty soulfull on the palate . Loads of rich malt , earthy muddy hops , bitter nutty roast , cherry covered caramel dimensions that become burnt . On reflection this is in the middle of my expectations ...I expected it would be more haggard ,but hopped for something awesome and complex..it is somewhere in-between both.

name: Fuller's Vintage Ale 1999
review: 550ml bottle, No. 35200. Coppery amber-brown colour, beige foam head leaving a little lacing and a nutty, malty aroma with toffee, raisins & earthy notes. Taste is malt, caramel, sweetish toffee, raisins, dried fruits, tea leaves, earthy, herby, and boozy spicy bitterness. Oily mouthfeel, medium bodied, soft carbonation, spicy earthy nutty boozy lingering bitter at the finish. Very drinkable, this one has aged extremely well.

name: Fuller's Vintage Ale 1999
review: Bottle from allmyvinyl, also shared with Ash and nihtila. Beautifully cloudy gunk murk. Big plum jam rich cream sherry liqueur aroma. Nice sweet dark fruits flavour juxtaposed with a pleasant, aged in a cave, musk. ( should be had with a nice quality strong cheese or two and crackers) Yes it’s knocking on and would likely have been better a few years back but great all the same. Loved it.

name: Delirium Tremens
review: Sweet malt, some fruit, sugar, caramels, a bit of alcohol. Medium full, semi-sweet. High saturation, low bitterness. Fine.
