name: Delirium Tremens
review: Had many a Delirium, getting around to reviewing this after having a couple lately and enjoying it more than I remember. Easy to enjoy out on the patio with a crisp mouthfeel, served right in the special Delirium elephant chalice/glass.

name: Delirium Tremens
review: Strong ale met een relatief hoog alcoholpercentage met goudgele kleur in een prachtige fles met een olifant. Prima smaak met bitter en zoete ingrediënten.

name: Delirium Tremens
review: Tap (Stu Mostów, Wroc³aw). Lekko owocowe z subteln¹ nut¹ Belgii, lekkie w odbiorze, nawet za bardzo, niebezpieczne pijalne, przyjemne jasne piwko.

name: Delirium Tremens
review: Tap(Browar Stu Mostów, Wroc³aw) Klarowne, jasne z ³adn¹ pian¹. Aromat bardzo przyjemny, dosyæ intensywny. W smaku przyjemnie, s³odkawo ale w tle jakby delikatny alkohol. Przyjemne piwo.

name: Delirium Tremens
review: Strong smell of alcohol, not much else, light yellow color. Lots of foam that last a long time. Hints of yeast but nothing really special. The best thing about this beer was the bottle.

name: Delirium Tremens
review: Pours clear golden with a large head. Aroma of malts, herbs and spices. Taste of malts, bread, butter, spices, yeast. Alcohol warmth. High carbonation, sweet aftertaste.

name: Delirium Tremens
review: Hard to go past one of the most unique Belgian blondes out there. Strange but delightful herbs and malts prevail. Lovely!

name: Delirium Tremens
review: This beer is a great example how beer can taste different and on the other side well known. Sweet, strong and always welcome as a good old friend. A delirium you should try. I love it!

name: Caledonian 80/- (Pasteurised)
review: Bottle sampled at omhper, thanks. Light brown lasting head. Clear amber color. A bitt butter and wood aroma. Sweet caramell taste.

name: Caledonian 80/- (Pasteurised)
review: Donker/amber kleurig bier, Met weinig koolzuur en/of schuim. Moutige smaak met de aroma's van fruit en karamel. -backlog de BierApp-

name: Caledonian 80/- (Pasteurised)
review: Süffiger, trocken karamelliger Beginn. Weiche milde Herbe, steigend getreidig, moderat würzig. Gut trinkbar. 8/9/8/8/7/8

name: Caledonian 80/- (Pasteurised)
review: Bottle at The Edinburgh Castle, labeled as Caledonian Edinburgh Castle Pours clear dark amber with a medium off-white head, good lacing. Bisquity, toffee, dark fruit and mild bitters Good

name: Caledonian 80/- (Pasteurised)
review: Butelka 500ml jako Edinburgh Castle. Miedziany kolor z delikatnym rubinowym refleksem. Piana obfita,lekko palona o drobnych pêcherzach,opada doœæ szybko. Aromat s³odów,karmelu,toffi,melassy,i czerwonych suszonych owoców. W smaku karmel,rodzynki,melassy,susz owocowy,ciastka i skórka chlebowa.malo tutaj cia³a i dominuj¹cych akcentów. Piwo jest bardzo pijalne lecz niezapamientywalne....

name: Caledonian 80/- (Pasteurised)
review: Tried this Edinburgh Castle which I think is the same beer. Deep mahogany colour creamy tight head. Aroma of sweet caramel malt and fruity plums hint of spirit. Taste to follow classic sweet scotch beer style with fruity/bitter balance. Very Nice.

name: Caledonian 80/- (Pasteurised)
review: Pre RateBeer review taken from my 1002 Beers book. I wasn’t impressed with this as I only gave it a 2/5 lol

name: Caledonian 80/- (Pasteurised)
review: Clear light brown liquid, large head. Strong aroma of malt. Light body, hardly any carbonation. Taste of stout, a bit sour.

name: Caledonian 80/- (Pasteurised)
review: Bottle. Backlog rating from bottle collection and historic scoring. Source not recorded. No tasting notes kept, just rating.

name: Caledonian 80/- (Pasteurised)
review: Bottle@Edinburgh castle. Amber/brownish, off-white head. Malt, caramel, medium bitter taste. Decent ale.

name: Caledonian Golden Promise (Pasteurised)
review: Bottle. Backlog rating from bottle collection and historic scoring. Source not recorded. No tasting notes kept, just rating.

name: Caledonian Golden Promise (Pasteurised)
review: From old tasting notes. Bright yellow gold color. Big creamy white head. Assertive sweet malt nose. Soft malty flavor has buttery notes. Light dry finish. Nice lacing as well.

name: Caledonian Golden Promise (Pasteurised)
review: Aroma and flavor is caramel/malts, a bit of earthiness and a fruit/slightly hoppy finish.

name: Caledonian Golden Promise (Pasteurised)
review: Bottle. Orangey Gold. Malty; biscuity malts, caramel. Fruity; light grapefruit-citrus. Hoppy; slight grassy hops. Sweet malty fruity. Quite dry. Drinkable. OK. (2008)

name: Caledonian Golden Promise (Pasteurised)
review: Bona cervesa, bastant equilibrada i gustosa. Buena cerveza, bastante equilibrada y sabrosa.

name: Caledonian Golden Promise (Pasteurised)
review: Bottle. This is a decent golden ale but nothing worth seeking out. Straight forward simple brew.

name: Caledonian Golden Promise (Pasteurised)
review: Light hazy yellow. Aroma of fruit and butterscotch. Taste is thin, a bit sweet, a bit sour, and some bitterness late in the aftertaste. Not much flavour.

name: Caledonian Golden Promise (Pasteurised)
review: I think that many of the previous reviewers may have had out of date bottles, hence odd aroma and taste. My bottle was fresh (@ Sergio’s World Beer Bar in Louisville) as it was recently obtained and brought over from the brewer. Pours a hazy dirty orange with a good bubbly white head, big streaks of lace. Yes, the taste is full caramel malt (as are many British session ales), and there is some candied fruit in a mildly hoppy finish, but I could find nothing wrong here. It is a good example of the style, and, as such, I recommend it.

name: Caledonian Golden Promise (Pasteurised)
review: Claims to be the first ever organic beer brewed (back in the 1990’s). Good for Spock and other Vegans I suppose. This 500ml brown bottle had a best before date of 26 Sep 2008, I drank it a month later. Poured into a Batemans pint glass, it was a golden slightly hazey colour with a good sized white head which slowly faded to a collar and a wispy covering. The aroma was of flowers and cut grass, very floral indeed. The beer was spritzy more than fizzy, a twang of citrus fruits in the taste. Unlike most UK brewed beers I’ve had. Sadly there was something missing, where was the 5% alcohol, where was the bitterness I was expecting and like? Overall not too bad, it just lacked that bitterness I require in a UK pint.

name: Caledonian Golden Promise (Pasteurised)
review: Bottle pours a murky dark gold with a tiny off white head. Scent is yeast and earth. Taste is same.

name: Caledonian Robert Burns
review: Tasted this in the Saltcot, Saltcoats (JDW) in January 2000. Cask, handpump dispense. Clear mahogany in colour with a thin creamy white head. Strong distinctive Caley aroma of soft toffee. Thin but creamy texture to the mouthfeel and good lacing. Pale malt complex gives a robust maltloaf base with sweet notes of velvet butterscotch, dates, maple syrup and rum soaked raisins. No strong hop presence noted in the short aftertaste as sweetness continues into the toffee laced malty finish. A cracking take on the old ale style and ticks all the right boxes for me. Excellent session ale to celebrate the national bard.

name: Caledonian Robert Burns
review: Cask Handpump at the Beer House, Manchester 25/01/2003 Golden coloured and slightly rich on the palate. Lasting malt hop finish.

name: Caledonian Robert Burns
review: Bottle Conditioned. Dingy brown with short head. I have been looking forward to this for a while, after all a Scottish (for now) Brewery producing a beer in the name of its favourite poet (some might say), it must be good. Well this is a real stinker, sweet and plummy are the best adjectives I can give it, other than that a total waste of time, no body, no interesting asides, a flabby raw ale as R.B would say.

name: Caledonian Robert Burns
review: Cask at The Anchor, Birmingham. No head, some lacing, pleasant caramel aroma. This was a nicely sweet brew, with big dollops of toffee and lemon. Very slight bitterness on the finish, but fairly restrained. A rather nice brew.

name: Caledonian Robert Burns
review: Handpump, Head of Steam, Euston, London. From previous comments, it seems this might be rather better from the cask than from the bottle. Mid brown colour. Malt dominates the aroma, as expected. Although it was smooth and slightly sweet in the mouth, in the Scottish style, there was also plenty of bite to balance that out and, if fact, it finished quite dry. Medium bodies, well balanced and easy drinking. A nice drop.

name: Caledonian Robert Burns
review: This beer started life as bottle conditioned, then became pastuerised. The claim on my 2002 version is that it has become bottle conditioned again. This is a pleasant brew with a nice yeasty/brown bread after taste - but slightly spoiled by the straight ahead sugar sweetness.

name: Caledonian Robert Burns
review: Supposed to be bottle conditioned but was as clear as a bell and no sediment in bottle. Citrus hops on the nose followed by a hint of malt. Chewy body with hints of caramel and toffee backed up with a yeasty bite in the finish.

name: Caledonian Six Nations
review: Cask at Sports Bar & Grill, Crossrail Place. It pours a clean amber color with a small off white head. Aroma is nutty and grassy with notes of bread and custard. Taste is also medium crispy bready with more notes of caramel, straw and grass. Light bodied with soft carbonation. Overall, quite nice

name: Caledonian Six Nations
review: Tasted this in the Last Post, Paisley (JDW) in March 2000. Cask, handpump dispense. An interesting mahogany brown in colour with a thick creamy off white head. Strong caley toffee really evident in the lingering aroma. Thick creamy mouthfeel and good lacing. Pale malt complex gives thick chewy mouthfeel of maltloaf and sweet butterscotch. Slight citric taint of hop flowers but sweet toffee malt floods the finish with chewy biscuit flavours. An enjoyable session ale this but maybe too sweet for some.

name: Caledonian Six Nations
review: A ruby coloured ale, with a malty nose ,and a wattery smooth full sweet flavour with toffeish tones and bitter linger

name: Caledonian Six Nations
review: Pint off pump. Poured a thick reddy brown with a good and sustained off-white head. Aroma was faint, with hints of malt and fruitiness. A pleasant beer but not all that much flavour: a little hoppy with hints of malt and fruit. Sweet. Extremely smooth and goes down well. Not bad, but reminds me of a lot of ’rugby themed’ beers.

name: Caledonian Six Nations
review: Cask at Charlies. Amber coloured. Fruity aroma. Fresh and fruity flavour with malty notes.

name: Caledonian Six Nations
review: Cask at Charlie’s. Pale / amber appearnce. Flavour is sweet and slightly stickky. Some butter in the falvour adds character. Finish is bitter with hints of prunes?

name: Caledonian Six Nations
review: Cask conditioned @ Humble Plumb, Soton. Pale copper colour. Citrussy hops and sweet caramelised malts. Some fruitiness in the body but balanced by a smooth bitter finish.

name: Caledonian Six Nations
review: Cask handpull at Thomas Ingoldsby, Canterbury. Golden with lasting off white head. Soft but minerally, some sulphur, like many Caley beers. Creamy, citrus finish with soft, creamy floral caramel aroma. Soft and eggy in mouth. Finish has some tingle to it.

name: Caledonian Six Nations
review: Cask conditioned @ ’The Freshie’ Formby. Golden coloured beer. Quite sweet with some fruitiness. More malt than hops but finishes with a strong hint of bitterness.

name: Caledonian Six Nations
review: Interesting flavor, it is like creamy and sour. But stills being bitter, I like this kind, makes me not dislike all ales.

name: Caledonian Murrayfield Grand Slam
review: Cask Conditioned at The Lampett Arms, Tadmarton. Dark brown beer with bubbly head. Strange mixture of weak ingredients and sour grapes. Sold just as Murrayfield in England as their last grand slam was a while ago.

name: Caledonian Flying Scotsman (Retired)
review: Cask at the Goat and Tricycle, Bournemouth. Retired? Clearly not. A clear reddish brown pour with a white frothy head. A rather spicy aroma which leads to a very refreshing spicy malty taste. The spiciness sticks around for a while too. Quite an unusual ale and I'd love to know the hops they use! A really great beer suitable for any time of the year. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Caledonian Flying Scotsman (Retired)
review: First tasted this ruby ale in the Bull Inn, Paisley in December 1996. Cask, handpump dispense. Clear ruby in colour with a thick white creamy head. Caley trademark of highland toffee in the lingering aroma. Creamy smooth mouthfeel and good lacing. Pale malt complex gives a moist maltloaf flavour with rum soaked raisin notes and toffee. Slight prickle of hop resins in the short aftertaste. Malt is dominant in the fruity finish with caramelised strawberry evident. An excellent Scottish ruby ale and sadly missed.

name: Caledonian Flying Scotsman (Retired)
review: From memory as it was the One cally beer i really liked and ive not seen it in ages (probably needs retired) ... Dark malt and fruity. 3.6

name: Caledonian Flying Scotsman (Retired)
review: I LIKE IT. I REMEMBER YEARS PAST IT CAME IN SO FULL OF MALT AND THEN HOPS. YES, SOPHISTICATED I DRANK IT WITH IT’S WONDERFUL FRUITY HOP CHARACTER AND EARTHLY MALT SWEET GOODNESS I FIND IT HARD TO OBTAIN NOW. ONE OF THE EUROPEAN ALES THAT IS TRULY GREAT. THANX BUY RITE RTE 17 IN BEAUTIFUL NJ.

name: Caledonian Flying Scotsman (Retired)
review: A little creamy, buttery, greasy perhaps, but the flavour is nice, bubbling head and not annoying in flavour at all.

name: Caledonian Flying Scotsman (Retired)
review: 1. Cask Handpump at the Cross Keys, Knutsford 04/05/2001 Dark colour, creamy and sweet. 2. Cask Handpump at the Penny Black, Northwich 08/05/2002 Dark brown coloured, sweet and malty with a bitter dry finish.

name: Caledonian Flying Scotsman (Retired)
review: Fairly malty but very drinkable, good session ale. Deep ruby colour and a nice palate

name: Caledonian Flying Scotsman (Retired)
review: Cask @ County Hotel (JDW), Ashford. Dark ruby in colour with malty caramel and charcoal nose/flavour Creamy in mouth with a shortish length considering everything else. Very drinkable

name: Caledonian Flying Scotsman (Retired)
review: Cask conditioned - handpump - JDW Northampton. A dark brown beer with a slight ruby hue. The aroma has some fruit, some mocha but also some typical Caledonian diacetyl. The taste is malty with caramel, coffee and more diacetyl. Could be really good but let down by signature notes.

name: Caledonian Flying Scotsman (Retired)
review: Dark looking, heavy tasting and gorgeous. Hamilton Hall, Liverpool St., London. Tasty as hell. The type of thing I want on at any festival.

name: Caledonian 125
review: First tasted this ale in Coanes, Johnstone in September 1995. Cask, handpump dispense. Clear amber in colour with a thin white creamy head. Strong aroma of highland toffee, long in intensity. Creamy mouthfeel and good lacing. Pale malts give a smooth creamy toffee flavour through the chewy digestive biscuit base. Slight dusty hop prickle evident but does not impact on the sweet malty finish. A cracking session ale and sadly missed.

name: Caledonian 125
review: Sampled cask conditioned. Bronze coloured. Flowery aroma. Sweet, medium bodied, lighlty soapy mouthfeel. Medium bitterness.

name: Caledonian Golden Pale
review: 500ml bottle from Shropshire. Vintage 1997. Some carbonation, soon fading. Stale/vintage flavours and aroma- cardboard and stale bread and some mould. Few hops. Some soggy biscuit sweetness. Not a lot happening here.

name: Caledonian Golden Pale
review: My wife and I really disagreed on this. She liked it quite well, but I wasn’t so sure (of course I’m writing the review, so I win). It had lots of flavor in it, but it also had a skunky, musty side to it. A fairly standard english style bitter, a little too carbonated.

name: Caledonian Golden Pale
review: Cask Handpump at the Counting House, Glasgow (JDW) 07/07/2001 Golden coloured with some pale malt and sweetness.

name: Caledonian Golden Pale
review: Small head from a vigorour pour with large, fluffy,soapy bubbles on top. Grape and pear aroma with a bit of spices. Very interesting and good aroma. Some raisins in there also. Color is a medium orange/brown. Bitter, rusty, gritty flavor and mouthfeel. Not very plesant. Nice roasted character develops after the swallow. Thin body with some hops. Beer started off pretty damn good but fell flat on its face.

name: Caledonian Golden Pale
review: Hazy amber body topped by small beige head. Aroma is earthy, peach and light orange. Taste is earthy, medium sweet, light orange. Watery, undercarbonated medium body.

name: Caledonian Golden Pale
review: Bottled. Golden with a hint of orange. Nose is malty, some caramel notes, bit of zippy spice. Odd, odd, flavor. Definite maltiness, nutty quality I tend to associate with British ales. Has a very noticeable whiskey flavor, like a bottled boilermaker. While the abv is low, it actually seems to have a whiskey burn to it, very subtle, but definitely some odd harshness going on. Also quite yeasty in the finish, perhaps some kind of brewing problem here? Really enjoyed the creaminess of it, but too many odd things going on flavor-wise to really like this one.

name: Caledonian Golden Pale
review: Cask: Reminds me much of their IPA with its citrussy palate. A touch of spice and sweet malts add a nice level of complexity.

name: Caledonian Murrays Summer Ale
review: Cask Stillage at the Metropolitan Cathedral Crypt, Liverpool 19/02/2004 Golden coloured slightly sweet and pale with floral aromas. Pleasant smooth hop finish.

name: Caledonian Murrays Summer Ale
review: Light looking pale ale with a dry flavour and a grassy aroma. Overall a standard dry beer.

name: Caledonian Murrays Summer Ale
review: Golden with a small bubbly head. Aromas are soft and buttery with floral hops and some citrus notes. Flavours are dry hoppy and floral with some sweet buttery malts. Has a farily dry finish.

name: Caledonian Murrays Summer Ale
review: Gold colour. Some grassy hops in the aroma. Otherwise. quite clean and refreshing but not exactly packed with flavour. A respectable, if rather soft, quaffer. Cask (handpump) Head of Steam, Euston, London NW1.

name: Caledonian Murrays Summer Ale
review: Hand pulled at Olde Dolphin Inn Beer Festival, Derby. Amber body, sweet aroma and taste, hints of freshly coppiced pine wood, flat but fun bitter finish.

name: Caledonian Murrays Summer Ale
review: Cask Conditioned, at Hamilton Hall, London. Pale golden body, slightly foggy. Server really cold resulting in no aroma. Light fruity summer hops flavours, rather thin but easily drunk. I wish I had mine with Imdownthepub, it sounds like it beats the city rat race.

name: Caledonian Murrays Summer Ale
review: Cask Conditioned at The Steam Packet, Isle of Whithorn, Dumfries & Galloway. Pale gold beer with bubbly white head. Light juicy summer quaffing beer, fragrantly hoppy with a lemony sweet underbelly, great beer in an idyllic pub overlooking the fishing harbour in a beautiful unvisited area of scotland, oh to be there again.

name: Caledonian Murrays Summer Ale
review: Sampled cask conditioned in Edinburgh. Amber colour. Pleasant, distinct spicy hop aroma. Soft mouthfeel. Rather light body, grassy delicious malt accent. Well balanced with slightly salty finish. My favourite from this brewery so far.

name: Caledonian Tattoo
review: Tasted this in the Saltcot, Saltcoats (JDW) in August 2000. Cask handpump dispense. Clear amber red in colour with a thin creamy white head. Slight hint of butterscotch on the short aroma. Creamy texture to the thin mouthfeel and good lacing. Pale malts give a digestive biscuit note with slight raisin fruit. The hop resins give a brief appearance in the bitter aftertaste. Bitter sweet finish like Caley 80/. An ok session ale but nothing too spectacular.

name: Caledonian Tattoo
review: Tasting notes from 2003 Harbury beer festival.. Copper-amber with a copper head. Caramel, fruit, spices, and fresh hop aroma notes. Malty sweet, spices, fruit, and citrus hop flavour notes. Bitter finish.

name: Caledonian Tattoo
review: Cask @ Charlie’s, Copenhagen. Hazy paleamber colour with a small white head. Dry malty aroma with some hoppy hints. Dry malty hoppy flavor with some fruity hints. Long dry malty finish.

name: Caledonian Tattoo
review: Cask (handpump) at The Colonies, Westminster, London. Attractive bright amber colour, with a thin but lasting white head and some condition on the plate giving a crisp refreshing mouthfeel. Light citric notes throughout with a spicy, fresh edge to the flavour. Some juicy fruit. More in the flavour than the aroma. Very smooth. Maybe a touch sweet but slipped down very nicely. More in the flavour than the aroma. Rather better than I expected.

name: Caledonian Tattoo
review: Cask at The Regal, (Wetherspoons pub) Gloucester 02-09-06. Copper coloured beer that has a sweet yet hoppy aroma, vanilla came through very strongly in the taste in what was a smooth almost creamy easy drinking beer. Very good.

name: Caledonian Tattoo
review: Tap at Cocney Pub. Creamy white good mostly lasting head. Yellow colour. Moderate malty and hoppy aroma. Light bitter cheasy flavor. Short finish. oily palate.

name: Caledonian Tattoo
review: 1. Cask Handpump at the GBBF, Kensington Olympia 05/08/2005 Golden coloured hoppy and slightly pale. Crisp slightly creamy malt finish. 2. Cask Handpump at the Penny Black, Northwich (JDW) 11/08/2005 Golden smooth and creamy with a hoppy slightly dry crisp full malt finish with some bitterness.

name: Caledonian Tattoo
review: Cask at Wetherspoons Ashford. Copper colour,thinnish beige head, creamy strawberry aromas just a little watery in mouth, good finishwith more strawberry and dry hop, Typical Cale sulphur taste

name: Caledonian Tattoo
review: Cask conditioned and handpulled at the Babington Arms (JDW) Derby. Caramel nose, vanilla-ish notes, hint of bitterness, little bit washy.

name: Caledonian Tattoo
review: cask. solid caledoinan, nothign special but nothing terrible, very like every other cali ale.

name: Caledonian Mellow Yellow
review: Cask by handpump at State Bar, Glasgow - golden amber, very slight haze, bubbly white head, sweet caramel malt aroma, good temperature, moderate carbonation, cereal, hint of spice, oily feel, malty aftertaste

name: Caledonian Mellow Yellow
review: Cask @ JDW The Standing Order, Edinburgh 250912 Light amber, clear, dense white head, some lacing Aroma - caramel malt, soft caley popcorn malt, hint of spicy cereal Taste as aroma, slight aromatic tinge, quite a lot of rich pale malt with weetabix flavour, bit of a spicy edge, some yeast, it’s one od Calry’s better beers Palate - soft carb, thin to medium body, a little viscous. Finish as main flavour. Overall - Not usually a fan of Caley beers but this one was pretty OK

name: Caledonian Mellow Yellow
review: Cask. Pale yellow ale with a white frothy top. Very lagerish. Nose is straw and cereals. Touch of lemon. In the mouth, lots more cereal flavours and light lemon notes. Really pleasant and moreish. Sessionable and light with a nice lemon wafer finish.

name: Caledonian Mellow Yellow
review: Cask. Yellowish golden colour with a small white head. Aroma is bready malts, mild toasted notes with some earthy and floral notes. Flavour is quite floral and grassy bitter hops along with some bready malts and mild earthy notes as well. Smooth palate and gets some slight floral and fruityness in the finish and aftertaste.

name: Caledonian Mellow Yellow
review: Tasted this in the Anchorage, Troon in August 1996. Cask, handpump dispense. Crystal clear bright gold in colour with a thick white head. Dry dusty hop flowers and lemon peel in the long aroma. Thin but refreshing mouthfeel and good lacing. Pale malts give a slight digestive note but citric fruit comes to the fore with grapefruit and gooseberry flavours. Strong hop resins gives a dry bitter resiny aftertaste. Finish is again dry and citrusy. A decent summer session ale.

name: Caledonian Mellow Yellow
review: Cask (handpump) @ Guildford Arms, 1 West Register Street, Edinburgh, Scotland EH2 2AA. Clear medium yellow colour with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate malty, grain, toasted, caramel, keller, nutty - earth notes, moderate hoppy, citrus, lemon. Flavour is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20101030]

name: Caledonian Mellow Yellow
review: Light butter (of course, it’s Caledonian) but aroma overall is faint. Dull copper colour. Dull character - mellow - with pale malts and mushroomy notes. As advertised, I guess.

name: Caledonian Mellow Yellow
review: Cask Conditioned Handpump Crosse Keys London. A golden beer with a white head and lacing. A toffee sweet typical Caledonian aroma. Sweet and fruity with that toffee again. A husky cereal note is quite nice but the sweetness is too much.

name: Caledonian Mellow Yellow
review: 21st October 2010. On tap at the Goodmans Fields Very light haze on this gold beer, little white head. A trace of sulphur on the nose. Dryish palate, slightly soft. Dry malt - a little citrus hop. Sulphur again. Drinkable but not very enjoyable. My friend was on his 5th pint of this when I turned up - as soon as I pointed out the sulphur in it he couldn’t drink any more! Ah the power of suggestion....

name: Caledonian Mellow Yellow
review: Cask @ Ale House. Bright gold with stable head. Aroma is simple dough but balanced. Soft palate. Balanced, fruity malt. Dragonfruit mildness followed by nice herbal notes. Roasted rice or millet and some herb. Is drinkable.

name: Caledonian Double Amber
review: On tap at Berts bar. Appearance - amber with a thin head. Nose - definitely confectionery. Like Irn Bru or some other fizzy pop. Taste - confirmed as per the nose. Palate - medium bodied with a sickly middle texture thing. It certainly doesn’t clean after that. Overall - not to be repeated.

name: Caledonian Double Amber
review: The Ugly Pub, Rochester. Dark & balanced & quite dry with a light twiggy finish and a hit of tobacco over the whole thing. OK, but a bit dull.

name: Caledonian Double Amber
review: cask at standing order ... copper brown ... thin off white head ...soft sweet caley nose ... same toffeee malt sweetness ... no real hop ... sweet malt ... creamy ... again its just to bland and no diff from there normal

name: Piast Beer
review: Typowy koncerniak, jasnoz³oty, jakaœ tam piana jest nawet nie najgorsza. Aromat pusty, troche s³odowy. W smaku nijakie, brak goryczki, puste. Nasycenie w miarê ok. S³ago s³abo

name: Piast Beer
review: Ocena w ramach uzupe³nienia profilu. Piwo koncernowe, wodniste. Nie wyczuwalny aromat chmielu. Wysokie nasycenie.

name: Piast Beer
review: Wodniste, puste, mokre zbo¿e. Z drugiej strony nic szczególnego w nim mi nie przeszkadza³o.

name: Piast Beer
review: Woda s³odowa. Tak bym nazwa³ ten gatunek. Ja rozumiem ¿e lager jest jaki jest ale s¹ piwa które pokazuj¹ ¿e da siê to zrobiæ du¿o lepiej.

name: Piast Beer
review: W aromacie s³odkie, fuzlowe, jak ruski szampan, brzeczkowe. W smaku du¿o brzeczki, goryczki brak, lekko szampañskie. Bardzo mêcz¹ce.

name: Piast Beer
review: dobrze ze myja butelki / good they wash the bottles / tylko czemu ich potem nie plucza?? / still why don’t they rinse them?? / aha zdarza sie tak w okocimiu / well happens in okocim / tym pod wroclawiem dumie dolnego slaska / the one next to wroclaw proudly lower silesian / sciema / cheater

name: Piast Beer
review: W latach 90-tych smakowa³. Teraz to po prostu kolejne piwo warzone przez ksiêgowego.

name: Piast Beer
review: Aroma: Sweet corny malt, apple. Appearance: Head quickly disappears, body colour is pale yellow. Taste: Generic eurolager, sweet, watery, some people would say that it has biterness, I didn’t feel that, really; apart from it there is some corn and maybe light esters. Palate: Finish is sweet, carbonation is high, body is low.

name: Piast Beer
review: The beer has a nice pilsener appearance. The color is golden yellow. The beer is quite pale and very clear. The beer smells quite hoppy. Very nice smell for a pilsener, a very nice citrusy sweetness and bitterness. The smell is quite appealing. The taste is also very nice. The bitterness is nice and strong, but not to strong. Very refreshing and very tasteful. Especially for a pilsner.

name: Piast Beer
review: Clear, gold color. Minimal, short lasting, white head. Aroma of malt - not very intensive. Light bitterness, high carbonation.

name: Castle Eden Ale
review: Production of Castle Eden has now ceased at Camerons, and the brewery at Seaham that bought the name have started to make it. The first batch (this is at the Dun Cow in Durham City) was dreadful and had to be returned, very pale and thin bodied with bitterness in the aftertaste, nothing at all like CEA. Camerons stepped in and made an “emergency” batch, but the Seaham brewery then brewed again and I never tasted that as it too was rejected. Watch this space. Update. 19th Oct 2017. The Seaham brewery made a batch that was drinkable, and CEAesque, but still not the body and still lighter in colour. Update. 23rd Oct 2017. Still being made at Hartlepool by Camerons. The Seaham lot still can’t get it

name: Camerons Nimmos XXXX
review: I’ll have to re-rate this, I thought it was ok but I was so thirsty I couldn’t even blink. Caramel,fruity hoppage, watery finish, some bitterness. Not bad I suppose.

name: Camerons Nimmos XXXX
review: Golden, quickly disappearing head. When I pour this one, the notes of hops and flower spreads around the table. The flavour has floral, hoppy notes of fruit. The bitterness is medium, but develops in the finish. A nice and uncomplicated ale.

name: Camerons Nimmos XXXX
review: Golden colour, small, unstable white head. Apples and grass in the aroma. Pleasant, mild, fruity flavors with some pine, and a light bitterness at the end.

name: Camerons Nimmos XXXX
review: Bottle. Golden colour with a medium white head. Sweet caramel malty, fruity aroma and taste. Medium body with a light sweet finish.

name: Camerons Nimmos XXXX
review: Bottle. Clear yellow coloured with a white head. Aroma of malts and caramel with fruity notes. Flavour of malts, fruits and caramel.

name: Camerons Nimmos XXXX
review: (Bottle 50 cl) Clear, pilsener golden with a nice and creamy head leaving some laces. Lightly fruity and floral nose. Light-bodied with soft, malty notes and a light fruitiness. Dry - but discretely bitter - finish. Very quaffable. 150906

name: Camerons Nimmos XXXX
review: Bottled. Pale golden with small off-white head. Aroma of pineapple and metal. Pleasant, mild, fruity flavors with some pine, and a light bitterness at the end. Thin-bodied session beer. (061116)

name: Camerons Nimmos XXXX
review: Very light ale, but with a tint of metal or fruit thath enhances it considerably. Very nice head as well.

name: Camerons Nimmos XXXX
review: Bottle. Metallic, dusty aroma. Golden colour, small, unstable white head. Starts off with an OK bitterness, turns dusty. A little watery.

name: Camerons Nimmos XXXX
review: Quite hazy, dirty-orange beer with greenish shine; no head to speak of. Vague parsley nose, and a bit nutty (slightly "overdue" bottle). Both nutty and slightly grassy taste, some caramel apparent, even a bit toasted. Finish is metallic, but not really bitter. Very empty palate, watery MF, just a little burning sensation. If this "gave the Northeast a reputation for strong flavoursome ales"... Oh, well, I’ve had TTLandlord aplenty, and I suppose it must be better on cask.

name: Camerons Winter Knights
review: Cask Handpump at the Cross Keys, Knutsford 06/03/2001 Red coloured and fruity with a hint of wine flavour.

name: Camerons Winter Knights
review: Cask Conditioned, at the Battersea Festival, London. Deep amber coloured perhaps reddish hue. Green, green, green. Is the most descriptive thing I wrote relating to this beer. I do apologies. I expected a lot from this brewery and still will on the next outing.

name: Camerons Winter Knights
review: Gravity @ the Dishwater Beer festival. Watery taditional bitter colour. Vaque malt flavours. Some brown sugar. Little hop awareness, other than a stewed tea quality in the background. Nothing impressive shows through, though there is a brief caramel appearance in the finish.

name: Camerons Winter Knights
review: All I have in my notes is "ditchwater", as in "dull as". Not in peak condition, so I must give it another go when I get the chance. Cask, Battersea Beer Festial.

name: Camerons Winter Knights
review: Cask Conditioned at The White Horse, Wroxton. A brown red beer with thin head. A full sweet malt beer, chocolate and caramel flavours. Quite a heady floral finish, a little spicy. A fair winter warmer.

name: George Killian's Celtic Classic Stout
review: On tap at the Dublin Irish Fest.Sampled from a plastic cup.Poured black with a small thinning head.Malts, chocolate, and some roastiness.Flavor was mild with some bitter chocolate hints.A nice small bitter finish

name: George Killian's Celtic Classic Stout
review: On draught at the Dublin Irish Festival (As Dublin Irish Festival Stout). The beer is dark brownish-black with a thin light brown head that diminishes quickly. Stringy lacing doesn’t stick but it is served in a plastic cup. Light roasty aroma with notes of malt and chocolate. Medium, smooth body with flavors of roasted malt, sweet chocolate and a bit of coffee. The finish is roasty with a short malt aftertaste. Slightly above average overall.

name: George Killian's Celtic Classic Stout
review: I beleive I had this tonight under the name DUBLIN STOUT...Brewed for the Blarney Bash in Dublin, Ohio...Killians was the sponsor, and they were also selling Coors/Coors light...This was pretty basic, of course, a very watered down "Stout" but a tad better then a regular Killians...You know, it was served in a plastic cup on St. Pat’s day, so I didnt have my hopes up!

name: George Killian's Celtic Classic Stout
review: I refuse to carry this... the reason? its just killians red.. big whoopdedoo ive seen this stuff in killians pub in Boston’s Logan Airport.

name: George Killian's Celtic Classic Stout
review: Add more roasted barley to Killians Red and this is what you get............

name: Matt Maximus Super
review: This was an attempt (locally successful) to compete with the likes of Colt 45 and Schlitz Malt Liquor..Really it wasn't bad a little bit sweet and malty but not bad. It was a strong brew at 8.9%

name: Matt Maximus Super
review: From old tasting notes. Deep golden color with a big foamy white head. Good hoppy nose has a fruity character. Malty semisweet flavor upfront. Finish is clean and lightly tangy. Sour malt aftertaste.

name: Matt Maximus Super
review: 12oz can (Old Notes)-Pours golden with no head. Aroma of sweetness. Taste of the same with alcohol. This light to medium bodied brew is not a bad malt liquor. Light you up.

name: Matt Maximus Super
review: always knew where we had gone to drink this when I was a kid. We just followed the trail of puke. Has to be drunk cold and fresh. Gets the job done but ditch the flat backwash no matter what. Only American beer I could get my cousins from the UK hammered on. Does taste like booze, oily and burns the roof of your mouth but has improved flavor over I remember it.

name: Matt Maximus Super
review: 12 oz. can. When I was in college, we used to drink these and say "let’s go out and maximize." Twenty five years ago, this was the strongest beer you could find. The alcohol is not at all hidden, there is a definite burn. Really not a bad beer, but let’s face it, if you’re drinking this one, you’re looking to get lit!

name: Matt Maximus Super
review: Oh, god. What a beer this is. I can feel my head pounding in the morning after splitting a 22 oz. of this and moving on to utica club. I believe that the exact flavour profile of this beer has become completely blurred in my mind due to a painfully high number of cigarettes smoked that evening. In short, this beer exists to get you drunk. The $2.18 plus deposit and tax that two of these babies cost you will bring you a morning of pain, regret and blank shame.

name: Matt Maximus Super
review: I actually liked this malt liquor when I tried it. Then again I was on a drinking binge with a bunch of like minded Neanderthals. Goes great with chocolate cake for breakfast. Well, maybe Matt won’t be using that in their next ad campaign.

name: Matt Maximus Super
review: 8.99%, three of these 24 oz bottles and you will be swinging from the trees. This stuff really blew me away. Taste is a little overpowering, but when you're good and banged up, does it really matter?

name: Matt Maximus Super
review: While doing my Colt 45 review I remembered this beer from the 80's. It was harsh, but the fastet buzz from beer I ever had. I'm glad I have not seen it since.

name: Matt Maximus Super
review: This is by far the best beer to buy if you want to get hammered...hands down

name: Ales of Kent Brainstorm
review: (Bottle 50 cl) Black as original sin and completely opaque. Flat without a trace of CO2. Vinous, slightly acidic aroma. Same characteristics dominate the flavours. Smoked - but not burned - notes, tart but not sour. Hoppy but not really bitter. Existing somewhere in the borderland between a Porter and a Barley Wine. Yeasty sediment. A unique experience. 280502

name: City of Cambridge Boathouse Bitter
review: Bottle. Orangey Amber in colour. Average off-white head. Good lacing. Malty; bready malts, toffee. Fruity; orange citrus. Hoppy; grassy hops. Good malt/fruit/hop balance. Moderately bitter malty fruity throughout. Quite dry. Bitter fruity hoppy finish. Flavoursome for low ABV. Easy drinking. Tasty sessionable bottled bitter. (2016-04-12)

name: City of Cambridge Boathouse Bitter
review: Cask (Duke of Wellington, Norwich) (6:4:6:4:13+=3.3+) Soft sweet caramelly aroma. Ditto the taste. Soft palate, a little watery and sweet, carbonation low. Finish a little tanniny. A very solid bitter bitter. Not saying 3.7% - this has some real character. Bitterness very high, but it works very well in balance with the sweet caramelly malts.

name: City of Cambridge Boathouse Bitter
review: 23rd April 2015: 500ml bottle shared with my wife in bright sunshine on our patio. Really enjoyed this beer: light brown body with full heads on our two half-pint glass tankards (old Home Ales countryman glasses). Malty lead with a good hop content stopping any real sweetness from showing. Fruity and interesting, belies it’s 3.7% ABV with a flavoursome taste and aroma.

name: City of Cambridge Boathouse Bitter
review: Bottle from Waitrose. Light brown. Clear with reasonable head & lots of lacing. Negligible aroma: bit of fruit, wood, freshly mown grass. Taste is an improvement, with a hearty hoppy bitter taste and a slight bitterness in the finish. Nothing special but certainly a drinkable bitter.

name: City of Cambridge Boathouse Bitter
review: Bottle from Cambridge Wine Merchants, Cambridge. Copper with an amber glow and a thin head. Has a rich grainy-malt taste with a fruity sweetness.

name: City of Cambridge Boathouse Bitter
review: Appearance: Clear amber with finger thick ivory head. Aroma: Bready malts, peppery, slight citrus note and light toffee. Taste: Medium bitterness and low sweet and sourness. Palate: Medium thick coarse texture and body, average carbonation, abrupt citrus, peppery malty slightly bitter finish. Comments: Good and lace.

name: City of Cambridge Boathouse Bitter
review: Bottles from Rehills, Newcastle and Cambridge Wine Merchants. An amber ale with a slight burnt toffee and currant flavour, red fruit notes and roasted bitterness on the finish.

name: City of Cambridge Boathouse Bitter
review: Cask gravity at Planet Thanet BF 2014. Clear amber thin white head. Fruity on the aroma. Decent session bitter. English fruity bitter. Ok condition. Some bitterness on the finish some hedgerow which is attractive. Drinkable and distinctive. Dome apple fruit. Interesting.

name: City of Cambridge Boathouse Bitter
review: Bottle from the brewery (I believe). Poured a hazy amber with a thin, white head. Aroma of floral hops, hay and synthetic fruit. Very bitter initial flavours; metallic with some dry straw. Finish was astringent with copper and bitter hop resin. I could not recommend.

name: City of Cambridge Boathouse Bitter
review: Bottle. Amber color with small white head. Malt, caramel and floral hops. Medium sweet taste with caramel malt, bready notes, citrus hops. Light bitterness in caramel sweet finish. Not bad.

name: City of Cambridge Jet Black
review: Bottled, 500ml from The Jug, Norfolk. Black with no head. Sour, stewed, acidic beer. Terrible.

name: City of Cambridge Jet Black
review: Considering the style, Scores ranging from 1 to 5, 5 being the most intense Appearance: Body: &nbsp Clear(1)->Murky(5) : 3 &nbsp &nbsp Light Brown(1)->Pitch Black(5) : 4 &nbsp &nbsp Still(1)->Sparkling(5) : 2 Head: &nbsp None(1)->Large(5) : 2 &nbsp Off-White(1)->Dark Brown(5) : 2 &nbsp Lasting: 2 &nbsp Lacing : 1 &nbsp Nitro : XX Aroma: Intensity : 2 &nbsp Yeast : 1 &nbsp Bread : 2 &nbsp Apple : XX &nbsp Tropical Fruits : XX &nbsp Ink : XX &nbsp Tar : XX &nbsp Olives : XX &nbsp DMS : XX Malt : 3 &nbsp Biscuity : 1 &nbsp Burnt Toast : 2 &nbsp Caramel : XX &nbsp Nuts : XX &nbsp Pumpernickel : XX &nbsp Cereals : XX &nbsp Coffee : 1 &nbsp Dark Chocolate : XX &nbsp Vanilla : XX &nbsp Grapes : XX &nbsp Blackberries : XX &nbsp Cherries : XX Hops : 1 &nbsp Noble(1)->American(5) : 1 &nbsp Leafy : XX &nbsp Floral : XX &nbsp Lemon/Lime : XX &nbsp Grapefruit : XX Orange : XX &nbsp Herbal : XX &nbsp Pine/Spruce/Resin : XX Notes : &nbsp Earth : 1 &nbsp Wood : XX &nbsp Mint : XX &nbsp Smoke : XX &nbsp Soy : XX &nbsp Bourbon : XX &nbsp Anise : XX Flavor: Initial Flavor : Dry(1)->Sweet(5) : 2 &nbsp Finish Dry(1)->Sweet(5) : 2 &nbsp Sourness : XX &nbsp Lactic : XX &nbsp Bitterness : XX &nbsp Complex : XX &nbsp Length : XX Palate: Light(1)->Full(5) : 1 &nbsp Flat(1)->Fizzy(5) : 2 &nbsp Clean : XX &nbsp Sharp : XX &nbsp Watery : 3 &nbsp Oily : XX &nbsp Chalk : XX &nbsp Astringent : XX &nbsp Alcohol : XX &nbsp Mineral : XX &nbsp Oxidation : XX &nbsp Metallic : XX Comments: Rather light example with undefined roastiness and extreme wateriness.

name: City of Cambridge Jet Black
review: 500ml bottle (Bacchanalia, Cambridge) Jet black, thick head, tight, stays for ever. A bit fizzy on the tongue. Very rich roasted taste - exceptionally malty and very tasty. Well balanced, no down sides

name: City of Cambridge Jet Black
review: Bottled. Hazy dark brown with a small dissapearing tan-coloured foam.LPeasant malty aroma of nuts, fudge, earth and cold coffee with an yeasty undertone. Flavour is rather thin of cold coffee and milky chocolate with sourish undertone. Thin-bodied. Short nutty, sourish aftertaste with a low bitterness. Infected?

name: City of Cambridge Jet Black
review: Cask : The Wenlock, Hoxton. As its name suggests it was black! Quite a rich and full mouthfeel for a low abv beer, nice and easy to drink with an ok body but no finnish. But of roastyness in there somewhere

name: City of Cambridge Jet Black
review: Bottle. Very deep brown. Soft creamy mouthfeel. Roasty, nutty, with a hint of blackcurrant and chocolate, very soft and smooth, perhaps too smooth, still very drinkable though.

name: City of Cambridge Jet Black
review: Gravity @ 32nd Cambridge Beer Festival, UK. 25th May 2005 Oatmeal poridge aroma. Roasted nuts. Salty. Quite odd figure this one. Almost meaty in the end. Can’t really decide if it is terrible or interesting.

name: City of Cambridge Jet Black
review: Cask conditioned at the 32nd Cambridge Beer Festival, gravity dispense. Black (= VERY dark brown) colour. Some natural carbonation, zesty, very nice. Pleasant roasty aroma. Flavour has dark chocolate, walnuts and roast barley. Not overdone, easy drinking.

name: City of Cambridge Jet Black
review: From A Bottle.Black as coal in colour,medium size lasting head.Aroma of dark chocolate,tart taste of dark fruit,dry.

name: City of Cambridge Jet Black
review: Bottle Cond. Jet Black (surprise!) with a small beige head. Aromas are floral, soapy, earthy and thin. Flavours are smooth and malty with more of that darned soapiness. Has a very nice sparkle, but the lack of flavour dominates. Perhaps a poor bottle?

name: River Horse Roebling Bock
review: Pours a hazy amber in the glass. Nose and taste is malts, sweet fruits and barley. Rated 6/8/02

name: River Horse Roebling Bock
review: Sweet, yeasty and fruity aroma with some bready and caramel malt character. Opaque golden body with a low white head that recedes to ring. Sweet and fruity flavour is mildly bitter with some cakelike yeast. Medium body with somewhat low carbonation. Bottle sampled at the Country Inn with beerbuzzmontreal, MartinT, Rastacouere and Yowie.

name: River Horse Roebling Bock
review: Pours a cloudy golden color with a ring of white lace. Aroma of malt, fruits and yeast. The flavor feels a bit off with a package of fruits and yeast. The body is light with a creamy texture and soft carbonation.

name: River Horse Roebling Bock
review: The Lure: Fruity esters and wheaty cereals personify a Belgian origin. Soft caramel and honey sweetness benefits from some orange pith to diversify its reach. Interesting, but definitely not what is expected from the style designation. The Festivities: Rich caramel and honey combine to coat the phenolic haystack. Their slick sweetness works well with the pears and other fruity esters of the apparently Belgian yeast. Few hops can be detected, and raw grain keeps things fresh. Good, but I thought I had ordered a bock? Transcendence: Clothing can mask true natures easily.

name: River Horse Roebling Bock
review: Hazy pale gold appearance, almost no head. Tartish sourdough and cerealic bready and floral nose. Banana touched doughiness is tamed by bandagey phenols and a beginning of cardboardy oxidation. Medium bodied, watery mouthfeel, rather sweet. Not very exciting.

name: River Horse Roebling Bock
review: On tap at Porterhouse Brewpub. Yellow color. Mostly clean aroma. Clean and crisp with some hops in the finish. Nice beer.

name: River Horse Roebling Bock
review: On tap at the Porterhouse Brewpub (owned by River Horse) in Lahaska, PA. 8% abv and known as Spring Bock. Yellow, slight lasting head. Aroma is mostly clean, but a touch of cooked corn is noticed. Malty clean and crisp, with a touch of hops in the finish. Strong but easy to drink.

name: River Horse Roebling Bock
review: Same lame labels from this brewery - when will they realize that using a home inkjet printer for their beer labels just won't cut it? As for the brew, the aroma is sweet, yeasty and just plain terrific. I enjoyed the malt flavor, but the alcohol could have been more well-hidden. Overall, a decent effort and I'm glad to see them try to brew a challenging style.

name: River Horse Roebling Bock
review: Hazy golden body with small off-white head. Aroma is fairly light, apple and light straw. Taste is pretty sweet, though not cloying, basically apple and caramel, with a hint of alcohol. Minimal bitterness, and fairly light body. Quite guzzle-able.

name: River Horse Roebling Bock
review: Lightest looking bock I've ever seen, more like a hazy-orange wheat beer in appearance, with almost no head. Not promising. Nose is one-dimensional candy-sweet, all right but my hopes aren't increasing. Flavor also very sweet, sticky, tiny bit smoky, rather boring. This was really a nothing for a bock, a style I usually like a lot.

name: Mad Crab Sturgeon Stout
review: Warm coffee & cocoa aroma deceives you for what you are about to taste - sour, stinging - very unpleasant.

name: Mad Crab Sturgeon Stout
review: My 200th beer! Unbelieveably nice aroma, very strong roasted coffee smell. Thick, tan head that lasted. I was shocked at the dichotomy between the aroma and flavor though. It tastes very sharp and sour, not what I was expecting at all. It was very hard to drink.

name: Mad Crab Riptide Wheat
review: Interesting! Very refreshing - served with lemon. Great summer brew........

name: Mad Crab Riptide Wheat
review: This light crisp brew had a hint of vanilla in the aroma which I found pleasant. Kind of reminded me of Blue Moon. Served with a lemon.

name: Mad Crab Buzz Beer
review: Wow! Another unique taste! Hard to describe - really good and refreshing....

name: Mad Crab Buzz Beer
review: Obviously borrowed the name from the Drew Carey Show (Strongsville is pretty close to Cleveland). Complex aroma that was hard to get a bead on. Some honey in the flavor. Thin head and lacing. Different, but not great.

name: Mad Crab Pirates Pilsner
review: Huge bubbled foam atop a light golden liquid. Fresh, dry aroma including sour apples, plaster, and oxidation. Far too much carbonation, bottle conditioned, to make this work. Finishes extremely dry and numbing. Why waste time on such a beer? Practically worthless.

name: Mad Crab Pirates Pilsner
review: I don't know if it was the glass or the beer - but I smelled vinegar. The taste wasn't bad - but I still don't care for pilsners.

name: Mad Crab Pirates Pilsner
review: Vinous flavor, thin off-white head. Decent lacing. I detected hints of ginger and brown sugar as well. Not bad.

name: Theakston Prince of Ales
review: Bottle conditioned. Bottled in 1981. This is a hearty ale with plenty of biscuit, rum and raison and burning alcohol. It has stood up well. One of those moments when your mouth is both appalled and delighted. This is disgusting and wonderful at the same time.

name: Darwin Evolution Ale
review: 500ml bottle, Bowes Christmas Market. Golden amber colour, white foam head and malty, yeasty aroma. Taste is malt, some caramel, followed by watery yeast and remaining slighty drying, citric with lingering sharp bitterness. Medium bodied, medium carbonation, dry bitter finish. OK

name: Darwin Evolution Ale
review: Tasted this at the Paisley Beer Festival in April 2001. Cask, gravity dispense. Clear dark amber in colour with a thin buff head. Stunning aroma with burning peat hags and carmelised orange notes - wonderful stuff. Smooth oily mouthfeel and good lacing. Mixed malts give a robust maltloaf base with caramel, molasses and orange peel notes evident. Citric hops give a dry fruity aftertaste long in intensity. Malt returns in the toffee and orange oil finish. An excellent session bitter and well recommended.

name: Darwin Evolution Ale
review: A Mes rate: Cask at the Wenlock (I think). Fresh and hoppy all round with some grapefruit and a crisp and very bitter finish. Very dry but not in a bad way. Decent beer.

name: Darwin Evolution Ale
review: 1. Cask Stillage at the Mill At The Pier, Wigan 09/03/2001 Sweet with a hint of ginger. 2. Cask Handpump at the Bar Fringe, Manchester 22/07/2005 Golden and hoppy. Some fruity bubble gum flavour. Some dryness in a crisp nutty malt finish.

name: Darwin Evolution Ale
review: Cask@2006 Derby Winter Beer Festival. Dark amber beer with a light head. The aroma and flavour is lightly dry. Overall an OK lightly dry and slightly caramel beer.

name: Darwin Evolution Ale
review: Straight from the Cask at the Chesterfield Beer Festival on 04/02/05. Hazey light brown colour. Fresh tasting, hoppy & dry. Quite bitter in the aftertaste. Pretty avarage.

name: Darwin Killer Bee
review: Cask (gravity) @ Paisley Beer Festival 2011. Hazy dark golden oclour, off-white bubbles. Aroma is a bit fruity, some vegetables. Flavour is slightly caramel, vegetables, bit of hops. Dry and slight boozy finish.

name: Darwin Killer Bee
review: Cask gravity at Jersey BF 2007. Cloudy amber, bubbly. Slightly flowery scent with apples and sugar. Slightly bitter with a dry end. Wheat and straw in the mouth.

name: Darwin Killer Bee
review: Cask conditioned at Harbury Beer Fest ’07. Gold with slight white head, hazed. Honey to the fore, flowery and perfumed with a background aromatic nutty character. Very sweet indeed which kills it for me.

name: Darwin Killer Bee
review: Cask gravity at Planet Thanet BF 2007. Deep orange gold colour with no head. Reasonable honeyed. Some malt, some hop. Bit like a honey sweet, but not sweet, it’s dry. Honeycomby like a Cadbury’s Crunchie.

name: Darwin Killer Bee
review: A Sim Rate (Cask at Planet Thanet): Sweet honey aroma. Not spectacular. Tastes strong with little sweetness.

name: Darwin Killer Bee
review: Really nice, in aoma is really alcoholic but in taste it is really like cheese, but not cheddar, it is like a grown cheese.

name: Darwin Killer Bee
review: Cask Stillage at the Metropolitan Cathedral Crypt, Liverpool 19/02/2003 Golden coloured strong in alcohol and hoppy. Slightly dry finish.

name: Darwin Killer Bee
review: I'd actually like to speak a bit about a different Killer Bee than is listed - the one from Tin Whistle of Penticton, BC. This dark honey beer has an understated complexity, where you can find such diverse flavours as tobacco, chocolate, coffee, malt, smoke, and honey. The beer has that honey-ish crispness, and is made from 5 malts, 3 hops, 4 honeys and some spice.

name: Heather Ales Fraoch (Bottle)
review: Clear golden appearance. Aroma is herbal, malt and earthy, not a very appealing aroma. Flavour is bitter, cherry, malt, dry, hop and herbal.

name: Heather Ales Fraoch (Bottle)
review: 500 ml bottle from Beer Hawk, bb 01/2021. Deep gold/light amber, crystal clear, white head. Nose - sweet, heather, honey. Taste - sweeter than nose. No.

name: Heather Ales Fraoch (Bottle)
review: Very interesting brew. Very sweet with some obvious ginger and sweetness and floral notes. Thin fading head. Nose is honey enjoyable.

name: Heather Ales Fraoch (Bottle)
review: BPA Delft in 't Proeflokaal. 50 cl bottle. BB 07/2020. A gold yellow clear beer with a good white foam at the beginning. Aroma is some sweet, resin like hop bitterness, herbs, fruity with apple, light peach and raspberry. Taste is light sweet, fruity, bitterness in aftertaste. Also flowers.

name: Heather Ales Fraoch (Bottle)
review: The heather is not really apparent. Light on the palate. Crisp with subtle bitterness

name: Heather Ales Fraoch (Bottle)
review: Need more heather !! Appearance Amber color, transparent. Aroma Aroma: Weak honey-berry Taste: malt rolling in grassy shades. Well balanced beer, but I would like to "tougher"

name: Heather Ales Fraoch (Bottle)
review: Ar: floral, peppery, malt Ap: golden, clear, minimal head T: med sweetness, low bitterness P: easy to drink, refreshing

name: Heather Ales Fraoch (Bottle)
review: Bottle. Hazy amber color, thin fine white head. Sweet, floral, cracker-malty aroma. Medium dry, low bitter, light sour taste. Slightly roast, or peat, malty aftertaste, lingering floral. Medium to low carbonation, full body. Nice and refreshing.

name: Heather Ales Fraoch (Bottle)
review: Bottle, 500 ml at the Crown Liquor Saloon, Belfast. Clear orange golden, small white head. Malty, herbal, some fruit, honey, bit spicy. Sweetish. Medium bodied.

name: Heather Ales Fraoch (Bottle)
review: Bottle. Pours clear amber. Aroma is heather, some spruce, berries and fruit, quince. Body is medium, softly sweet, lively but lowish carbonation, rsome peat, low barrel, ginger spice, feels a bit like an older hoppy pale ale. Good!

name: Lancaster Amish Four Grain Ale
review: Bottle from Bethesda Food and Beverage. Nose is malty, caramel. Taste malts, sweet, spicy. Creamy texture. Okay. Not great.

name: Lancaster Amish Four Grain Ale
review: as an amber color about itself, with good carb’s and an avg. head that fades quickly to a foamy ring about the glass. A spicy malt aroma with an earthy hop bouquet. A spicy malt taste similar to Beligem brews. Hop flavor is very understated with a slight earthy or woodiness taste. The use of four grains gives a complex flavor. spicy from the rye and smooth from oats. Medium body with a bitter finish and dry after taste. I would like to taste more hop flavor to balance out the maltiness. I could drink a few of these but would change out after about two.

name: Lancaster Amish Four Grain Ale
review: Transferred from BA reviewed on 2-1-12 - Poured from bottle into pint glass. Appearance - Pours a rusty–copper color with a off white head; the color not quite so” pale” as the categorization implies. The head fades leaving very little lacing. Smell –Rye maltiness is the main aroma detected. This maltines however is mixed with a fair degree of sweeter aromas as well; mainly some caramel and toffee as well as some wheat and an ever so light toasted nut, which seems almost none existent in the beginning, but shows up at the end. Taste – Sweet caramel and rye malt are the backbone of the brew and seem ever present. A very light hop spiciness, mostly earthy in , is present at the start, but seem to fade quite fast, giving way to an even greater level of sweetness, with the caramel flavor mixing with some lighter fruit flavors,;a bit of banana, and some other sweeter flavors of vanilla. The taste transition is light and very smooth. Quite nice!! Mouthfeel – The rye flavor seems to blanket the tongue with a nice creaminess; a much creamier tongue feel then would have been expected. The carbonation level seems to be right on par, making it a very easy drinking and enjoyable brew. Overall – This is quite nice and very flavorful brew. The rye and sweet flavors and aroma are all quite smooth and enjoyable.

name: Lancaster Amish Four Grain Ale
review: Pours copper color with white head. Caramel malt aroma. Sweet caramel malt flavor with some bread flavors. Some honey notes and a citrus finish. Fairly smooth. Really like.

name: Lancaster Amish Four Grain Ale
review: This beer is being discontinued in lieu of the Lancaster Pale Ale, which is a reformulation.

name: Lancaster Amish Four Grain Ale
review: Bottle into a goblet. Pour IA a haze brown with a nice brown head. Aroma is a sweet malt. Taste is of fruit and malt, it is very different from other pale ale. Finish is a fruit wash. This is a very good ale.

name: Lancaster Amish Four Grain Ale
review: Bottle. Very bizarre odor that really gave an unappetizing feel to the beer as a whole.

name: Lancaster Amish Four Grain Ale
review: I like this beer overall, kinda like a meal in a glass. Tones of citrus, flavorful yeast, and mild hops. Poured well, nice light amber color. The thing that stood out the most with this one was the taste of baked bread behind other complimenting flavors

name: Lancaster Amish Four Grain Ale
review: 12 oz. pours a golden amber with a light ivory head. Lots of carbonation. Aroma of bread malts and honey. Taste loads of honey and bread malts. Very sweet. Hints of lemon zest and oak. Very light and easy to drink

name: Lancaster Amish Four Grain Ale
review: 12oz bottle. Orange-amber pour, white creamy foam. Sweet aroma. Caramel malt, fructose, sugar, malt powder, bread, and dried leaves. Sweet grain character. Flavors of sweetened cereal, mostly grains, bready. Oily, sticky texture. Finishes with a grain flavor and some bitter grass flavors. Very unique, on its own level. Not too balanced, but quality exists. (3519)

name: Unibroue La Fin du Monde
review: Someone Said This Is A Beast Of A Beer! Very True! Great Aroma & Great Taste! If You Drink It Like A Fine Wine You Will Enjoy It!

name: Unibroue La Fin du Monde
review: Bottle at Las Buenas Pulgas, served in a Chimay glass. Pours a golden colour, medium head with long retention, reducing to a permanent thin layer. Creamy lacing Aroma of cloves, bananas, plums, ripened fruits, phenols, green apples, cinnamon, almonds. Medium body, sticky texture, active carbonation, sweet alcoholic finish. Taste is just like the aroma. A beast of a beer. Wonderful.

name: Unibroue La Fin du Monde
review: Aroma is raisins and Belgian yeast. More dark fruit on the tongue. with sweet biscuit, a little banana and a touch of alcohol. Really good.

name: Unibroue La Fin du Monde
review: Aroma is apple, citrus, star anise and Belgian yeasts. Taste is light sweet malts, plums, raisins and Belgian candy sugar. Great depth and balance.

name: Unibroue La Fin du Monde
review: Aroma 7. Appearance 3. Taste 8. Palate 3. Overall 14. Spices and Belgian yeast aroma. Spices, some banana, and alcohol taste at the end.

name: Maclay Oat Malt Stout
review: From old rating notes taken around 2000. "Durable head, creamy and rich, but the pleasures lessened about halfway through as an astringent, slightly metallic aftertaste took over." Still, must not have been all bad with a 3.2 rating.

name: Maclay Oat Malt Stout
review: Cask drunk at the Fisherman’s in Broughty Ferry Christmas 1999. Pretty dense silky structure with a solid degree of thickness and oaty silkiness. A tad of truffly texture in there as well. A solid beer

name: Maclay Oat Malt Stout
review: Cask @ The Clockwork Beer Co. Almost black colour, not much head. Sour rancid aroma. Tastes like red wine. Quite smooth but not food.

name: Maclay Oat Malt Stout
review: Resumed brewing? Cask @ Clockwork brewpub. Black colour, creamy dense tan head. Aroma is roasted malts, bit of coffee and coffee cream. Flavour is roasted malts, little coffee. Fairly bitter finish. A bit thin bodied. Rerate Cask @ Brewpub. In bad condition. Sour, vegetables. -1

name: Maclay Oat Malt Stout
review: 2002 Vintage ~ "The only oat malt stout in the world." 12/06/2007: McLay & Co Ltd Oat Malt Stout has a color that is very dark brown to near black (black walnut or deep mahogany would be more descriptive terms). It is topped with a frothy tan-colored head. The deep red wine (merlot) aroma makes this beer smell very port-like. There are also hints of oxidation and a slightly mustiness. The dry flavor has hints os smoke/char, some oxidation and chocolate, red wine and port (not too much), and some sort of dark fruit or dried apricot. The beer has a medium body and a soft, smooth, and mellow texture. Overall this is a very good stout that is unique, memorable, and quite complex! 1 pt. 0.9 fl. oz. bottle shared by Peanut at the Dilly Deli in Mariemont, Ohio. Thank you so much! Rating #10 for this beer.

name: Maclay Oat Malt Stout
review: Bottle from Peanut at Dilly Deli. Poured clear black with a mimimal creamy light brown head that mostly diminished and produced fair lacing. Good roasted malty and port aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture. Medium complex roasted flavor with a medium pleasing bittersweet finish of moderate duration. Glad I got to try this one.

name: Maclay Oat Malt Stout
review: Cask at the Southsider, Edinburgh. Vintage notes from January 1997. Digging out these old notes because this beer seems to be retired. Surprisingly good (but not great). Smooth and a bit sweet but not too sickly. Burnt malt gives the impression of some bitterness. Creamy head. 6/10 on my old scoring sytem.

name: Maclay Oat Malt Stout
review: Date: 10/25/1997 Mode: Bottle Source: Burlingame Grocery, OR black, thin tan head, dripping lace, rich roasted malt aroma, light body, roasted flavor, bitter finish Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.8/5.0 Score: **/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

name: Maclay Oat Malt Stout
review: Nice thick dark liquid with a good head. Definitely a full round flavor as the commercial description describes. Good full malt flavor with a faint sweetness. Smooth full and creamy texture. Nice toasty finish.

name: Maclay Oat Malt Stout
review: This beer rocks. The commercial description will have to suffice since I didn''t take any notes while enjoying this beer. However, if you enjoy other sweet stouts that I have rated highly, this one will not disappoint you.

name: Yards Thomas Jefferson's Tavern Ale
review: Pours an amber from a tap, some lacing. Not much aroma at all. Big sweet molasses flavor up front tempered by a hit of bitterness on the finish. Good beer.

name: Yards Thomas Jefferson's Tavern Ale
review: Clear, amber color. Malt , honey, hint of Belgian yeasts in the aroma. Sweet start with moderate herbal/hoppy bitterness at the end. More Belgian than American.

name: Yards Thomas Jefferson's Tavern Ale
review: Pour is golden color. Very little carbonation. Aroma is kind of stale. Taste is initially sweet with a bitter finish that lingers.

name: Yards Thomas Jefferson's Tavern Ale
review: Bottle. Pours copper color with off-white head and lacing. Bready malt aroma with caramel notes. Bready malt with honey and caramel notes and some pine in the finish.

name: Shepherd Neame Master Brew (Cask)
review: Cask at The Plough Inn, Brabourne Lees, Kent, Thursday 26th April 2018 Pours clear gold dark amber, good clarity with a slim white head. Toffee and more toffee, hops are rustic and a little earthy but do throw a touch of bitterness. It's in superb nick and whilst not totally my thing it's fine. A6 A4 T7 P3 Ov13 3.3

name: Shepherd Neame Master Brew (Cask)
review: Cask at the Cock & Woolpack, London. Pours dark amber with a small lasting off-white head. Aroma of hop, malt, toffee, fruit and light floral notes. Medium sweetness, moderate bitterness. Medium body, oily texture, soft carbonation.

name: Shepherd Neame Master Brew (Cask)
review: historical back log rating so no notes on aroma / taste / palate . Just the rating saved

name: Shepherd Neame Master Brew (Cask)
review: Not much to say here. There is a little bit of malt and a thin palate, and a bit of lacto aroma, but that seemed to be from the lines. I had this about 90 minutes ago, and I've already nearly forgotten it.

name: Shepherd Neame Master Brew (Cask)
review: Cask (Angleterre, Helsinki) (6:3:6:3:11=2.9) Minerally fruity aroma. Light palate. Minerally bitter body. Sweet bready malts. Minerally finish. Ahh, Kent water, you can't mistake it, and the Sheps wear it as a badge with pride. Dullish bitter, but more drinkable than many a craft brew nowadays.

name: Shepherd Neame Master Brew (Cask)
review: 5 3 6 3 11 Cask shared at Angleterre, Helsinki. Clear golden with a white head. Aroma of fruits, light vinegar and malt. Flavour is moderate sweet and bitter. Above light bodied with very soft carbonation.

name: Shepherd Neame Master Brew (Cask)
review: Cask pint at the Running Horse, Leatherhead. Pours clear amber with a white head. Aroma of malt with hops. Taste of caramel and a little burnt malt. Bitter finish.

name: Shepherd Neame Master Brew (Cask)
review: Deep yellow, hints of caramel, very dry. ok beer. Cask at The Miller’s Arms in Canterbury

name: Shepherd Neame Master Brew (Cask)
review: Have had far too many of these over the years. One of Britain’s oldest beers, can suffer in hot weather but, when on form, a clean, light, hoppy Kentish beer with notes of strawberry and orange. The perfect session ale.

name: Shepherd Neame Master Brew (Cask)
review: Cask pint @ The Millers Arms, Canterbury. Pours clear amber, small off-white head. Aroma of fleeting, light, faintly sweet malts. Taste is typically very light, thin bodied, overly watery, very light sweetish malts. Marginally adequate table beer but difficult to warm to.

name: Murphys Irish Stout
review: Milk chocolate in the aroma and caramelish biscuity bites on the nose. Toasty, roasty with ash on the palate and slight chocolate at the finish. Creamy and tasty.

name: Murphys Irish Stout
review: Dark brown with the creamiest head. Aromas toasted malt, smoke, toffee and biscuit. Flavors light smoke, biscuit, toast, light toffee. Slightly sweet slight smoke finish and slightly dry. Light bodied. Not bad coming from this company.

name: Murphys Irish Stout
review: Takiego pok³adu metalicznoœci nie uœwiadczy³em w ¿adnym dotychczas pitym przeze mnie piwie. Poza tym wodniste, lekko czekoladowe, tylko piana jak zawsze na azocie robi wra¿enie

name: Murphys Irish Stout
review: Barwa niemal czarna, z drobno i œredniopêcherzykow¹ pian¹. W aromacie nik³a czekolada, s³aba palnoœæ. W smaku wytrawne, kwaœne, metaliczne, kawowo-czekoladowe, z ledwo wyczuwalnym posmakiem gorzkiej czekolady. Lekko wodniste, nijakie, mocno œrednie.

name: Murphys Irish Stout
review: Dunkelbraunes Stout mit hellbraunem, cremigen Schaum. In der Nase Haselnuß und Röstmalz. Im Mund recht bitter und cremig, etwas wässrig, deutlich malzig (aber ohne echte Süße) und, ein wenig Kaffeeschokolade und wieder etwas Nußaromen.

name: Murphys Irish Stout
review: Aromat lekko palony i kawowy, metaliczny. W smaku srednia palonosc, slaba kawa, troche wodniste z metalicznym posmakiem. Finisz lekko kwasny .Cialo niskie, nasycenie niskie do sredniego.

name: Murphys Irish Stout
review: Pint can dated best by 2/20/20 so assumed ~ 7 months old A: Turned up vertically into the glass it gave the beautiful cascade of carbonation from the widget. Dirty dark black/brown color. S: Light scent of bitter and sweet chocolate and faint coffee. T: Very watery taste finally presents some slightly sweet grain with light roast and bitterness. Bitter chocolate and cigarette butt aftertaste. M: Very thin as expected for the ABV but with the also expected soft creamy texture. O: You don't expect a lot at 4% ABV but this is lacking in flavor and body.

name: Murphys Irish Stout
review: Black-brown with excellent creamy foam. Nose .Roastedmalt a little coffee and chocolate. Very pleasant. Taste. The body is soft and velvety, in the taste of a shade of coffee, chocolate and roasted malt. in the aftertaste of the bitterness of roasted malt,

name: Murphys Irish Stout
review: On tap in Cork, Ireland. Pitch black with a creamy beige head. Aroma is roasted malts. Malty, roasty taste continues along with some coffee and a gentle bitterness. Good.

name: Murphy's Irish Red Beer
review: Plana en nariz. Notas de caramelo y poco más. Cuerpo medio y sensación cargante. Baja bebestibilidad. El puntito amargo suave es lo más positivo, aunque insuficiente. A evitar.

name: Murphy's Irish Red Beer
review: On tap at Dhillon's in Leipzig, Germany. Clear red with almost no head and nothing left on the glass. Caramel and some fruits, no noticeable hops. Slightly sweet. Medium mouthfeel.

name: Murphy's Irish Red Beer
review: From keg. Red amber color with creamy head. Some caramel, fruits, cherries, plum, smooth, refreshing. Like it.

name: Murphy's Irish Red Beer
review: Backlog, used to drink this when I was underage and working at the Cork N Bottle in Wildwood NJ. Amber color, metal taste are the main descriptors for this swill.

name: Big Time Prime Time Pale Ale
review: Bright orange. A simple pale with notes of floral, citrus, and toasted malt. Finish is clean, shortish, and dry. A simple pale ale made for drinking.

name: Big Time Prime Time Pale Ale
review: [3/2/15] Draught at Big Time Brewery in Seattle. Clear golden. Aroma of citric hops. a bit stale, and chalky malt. Flavor has some sweetish chalky malt, a vegetal note, slightly stale citric hops and some bitterness. Quite light-bodied.

name: Big Time Prime Time Pale Ale
review: On tap at Big Time, pours a clear pale golden with a small white head. Nose is pleasant, with notes of floral hops, light citrus and biscuity malt. Flavour is along the same lines, with floral and citrus hops, and balanced with dry biscuity malt. Very clean and balanced, with lots of flavour. Very nicely constructed pale.

name: Big Time Prime Time Pale Ale
review: Draft - Pale malts and light citrus notes. Clear gold with a nice white head. Earthy hops and light bitterness with pale malts. Very English in style , well balanced and easy drinking.

name: Big Time Prime Time Pale Ale
review: Seattle, Wa. - on tap at the brewpub. Light copper pour, bubbly white head, light lace. Fruity aroma with a hint of spruce and some back end floral notes. Nice subtle bitter citrusy notes, a hint of nuttiness and some peaches in the back end. Thick enough mouthfeel.

name: Big Time Prime Time Pale Ale
review: Draught at the brewpub Hazy golden color, with creamy head. Some malt and caramel, the aroma is mild, the flavor is more pronounced; the hopping is fade, without prominent aromatic characteristics; there is unfortunately a light feeling of pond water. A simple beer; the only one at the brewery that is a bit meh.

name: Big Time Prime Time Pale Ale
review: Bomber. Pours a bright yellowish golden color with a solid cap of white foam. Aroma is mostly grassy hops, citrus and malt. The taste is orange citrus and floral hops upfront followed by some toasted grain, honey and biscuit malt. The body is smooth with medium-level carbonation. The finish brings more citrus and mild honey sweetness. Should pair well with brewpub fare.

name: Big Time Prime Time Pale Ale
review: Draft at the brewpub in Seattle. Pours a slightly cloudy pale golden yellow color with a 1.5 finger frothy white head that slowly settles into a lasting ring. Chunks of lace left behind. Sligtly earthy aroma with subtly spicy, grassy hops that are countered by sweet fruit notes and pale malt.  Hints of straw, grass, pineapple and faint lemon peel countered by bread and biscuit.  Medium bodied with a nice balance of dry, bitter hops, sweet citrus and pale malts.  Grassy and dry up front but not too bitter with subtle fruit notes and a very light malt presence balancing things out.  Hints of bread, biscuit and graham cracker with a sweet yet dry finish.  Very easy to drink.

name: Big Time Prime Time Pale Ale
review: Tap @ the brewery. Nice head with good duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are malt, grain, notes of caramel, grass and hops.

name: Big Time Prime Time Pale Ale
review: Pours clear straw blond with minimal head. Smell is malt, a bit of caramel. Taste is there, a bit of honey and spice. Good drinkability. Pretty good.

name: Big Time Atlas Amber Ale
review: On tap at the brewery pours crisp copper amber topped with a sand head. Nose is light nutty caramel notes and some grassy hops. Tatse is more of the nice sweet malts light bread malts and a touch of hops.

name: Big Time Atlas Amber Ale
review: On tap at the brewery. Pours a clear copper with small white head that lasts. The aroma is rye and toasted malt. Thin body, rye, bready malt, metallic finish, ok.

name: Big Time Atlas Amber Ale
review: On tap at the brewery Hazy murky orange light amber. Standard soft woodybmalt flavors. Slight sour taste Not very interesting.

name: Big Time Atlas Amber Ale
review: Mijn eerste Amerikaanse Amber Ale. Zeer lekker en verfrissen, wel een donkere kleur.

name: Big Time Atlas Amber Ale
review: [3/2/15] Draught at Big Time Brewery in Seattle. Clear amber. Buttery aroma. Sweetish buttery flavor with some toasty and caramelly malt and a bitterish finish. Medium-bodied.

name: Big Time Atlas Amber Ale
review: On tap at Big Time, pours a hazy amber with a small off-white head. Aroma brings out bready caramel malt and a very gentle resinous hoppiness. Flavour is fairly bland but clean and pleasant, with bready caramel malts showcasing - not much hops at all. Very solid if unexciting.

name: Big Time Atlas Amber Ale
review: Draft - Light caramel and pale malts. Clear copper with a decent beige head. Caramel and hoppy bitterness, with an oddly bitter fruity finish.

name: Big Time Atlas Amber Ale
review: Draft. Bright amber color, white head. Aroma of earthy caramel. Taste has light grapefruit, light pine, caramel. Decent.

name: Big Time Atlas Amber Ale
review: What you would expect from an amber ale, just the right flavor but nothing too exciting. -- rated via 'Find A Beer' for Blackberry 10

name: Big Time Atlas Amber Ale
review: Draught at the brewpub, 4.5% ABV Hazy amber color. The aroma is mild. It has a quite nice flavor of caramel, with light nuttyness; compared to other Amber Ales, this one has just an impression of sweetness and fruitiness, therefore it’s a better one; correct bitterness. Good Amber Ale.

name: Big Time Coal Creek Porter
review: Draft - Only a hint of bitterness. More coffee and roasted flavors than sweet chocolate. Could be a little smoother for how it is on the palate.

name: Big Time Coal Creek Porter
review: Medium muddy brown. Lightly roasted, some cocoa notes, a decent bitter profile sort of overshadows the porter aspects. Decent brew.

name: Big Time Coal Creek Porter
review: On tap at the brewery. Pours a dark ruby brown with small beige head. The aroma is cocoa and cracker malt. Medium body, chocolate, licorice, light roast, decent.

name: Big Time Coal Creek Porter
review: Draft pour pint at stop #1 of my on foot Seattle tour. Research for an upcoming video documented experience. I am thankful for the wealth of beer places and breweries that are open at 11 on a Monday/Holiday. Listed at 5.4. Cola black pour with a cream foam head and lace. Sugar sweet, light roast aroma. Flavor is rich chocolate, soft roast, and a bit watery. Has a decent hop presence as well. If I didn’t know better I could mix this up with a CDA, but the styles seem to overlap in certain cases anyway. Overall a tasty beer, but a little watery and I’m missing the bold porter factor that I love. Still a good beer though.

name: Big Time Coal Creek Porter
review: On June 24, 2015. At Brouwer’s Cafe in Seattle, Washington. Listed at 5.4% ABV. Clear black color with red to the bottom, tan head. Sweet, some red apples scent. Sweet, light fruity taste. Medium low mouthfeel, medium low bitterness.

name: Big Time Coal Creek Porter
review: [3/2/15] Draught at Big Time Brewery in Seattle. Dark brown. Aroma of butter, caramel, some roastiness and a vegetal note. Sweetish flavor with butter, roast, caramel and a chocolate note. Medium-bodied.

name: Big Time Coal Creek Porter
review: Draft at brewpub. Hazy cola brown, small foam. Soft chocolately roast malt. Nice creamy, tasty body. Lots of flavor all around, a little sweet in the finish. Not the most defined or sharpest beer around, but tasty porter.

name: Big Time Coal Creek Porter
review: On tap at Big Time, pours a dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma brings out notes of charcoal in typical coal porter fashion. Flavour is well-balanced, with dry cocoa powder and light roast. Decent porter, just nothing special.

name: Big Time Coal Creek Porter
review: Draft - Roast malts and butterscotch. Deep brown with a decent light brown head. Dark roast, toffee and a burnt bitter chocolate finish. Complex and pretty nice.

name: Big Time Coal Creek Porter
review: Draft at big time. How the hell I haven’t rated this yet? Used to be the only thing I ordered when I came here. Dark brown pour (opaque, but light brown around the edges) with creamy head, decent retention, good lacing. Nutty, roasty, some dark fruit. Chocolate and roast in balance. Taste is somewhat sweet with a balanced lightly bitter roasty finish. Medium- body, average carbonation. Oily texture. Overall: still my favorite big time beer.

name: Big Time Baghwan's Best IPA
review: Golden. Bitter citrus, light toasted malts, lemon, and finish with light sweetness and a lasting bitter bite. Medium bodied. While this isn’t a powerhouse IPA, I could see myself cruising though a few pints.

name: Big Time Baghwan's Best IPA
review: On tap at the brewery. Pours a hazy orange gold with small white head that lasts. The aroma is citrus and pine. Medium body, bubblegum, grass, a bit soapy, decent.

name: Big Time Baghwan's Best IPA
