review: Bottle, Orcas Island. Pretty clear, dark amber, big bubble foam. Sweet amber beer, nutty brown malt. Distant bitter. Old school. Not my vibe. Fruity overtones. Alright.

name: Pike Pale
review: (tap) clear bright amber colour with a small white head, faint aroma of honey, creamy palate, assertive balanced flavour with a long light bitter finish

name: Pike Pale
review: Clear amber with a creamy head. Not much aroma, perhaps some floral/ citrusy thing going on. Dry, typical pale ale flavor. Not bad, but nothing special, either.

name: Pike Pale
review: Tap at Pike. Clear reddish orange pour with a smaller white head. Earthy, hoppy, slightly metallic.

name: Pike Pale
review: Draught at Hops ’n Headz, Bellingham, WA, as Heirloom Amber Ale, 5.3% ABV Golden color, medium sized head. Regular blond Ale, a bit sweetish, but with decent hop touch, although the final is a bit too mild. Easy, not bad.

name: Pike Pale
review: On tap at the brewery. Pours a softly hazed amber with a thin white head. Soft malt, a touch of dusty citrus. Medium bodied, toast, soft sweet malt. Toast, dull citrus. Soft malt, gentle toast.

name: Pike Pale
review: A decent pale ale. Pours light amber, malty aroma, with a medium body. Biscuit and caramel. Tried with Josh at the brewery in 2016.

name: Pike IPA
review: Draft: Poured a clear golden color ale with a nice large white foamy head with good retention and some light lacing. Aroma of citrus notes with some malt notes perceptible. Taste is also a mix of citrus hops notes with some light bitterness and some malt notes also perceptible. Body is about average with good carbonation. Nothing earth shattering but enjoyable west coast style IPA.

name: Pike IPA
review: Draft at the brewery. Clear, light amber with lacing head. citrusy and piney, a smooth, balanced IPA.

name: Pike IPA
review: A vice tasty IPA, discovered this beer on a trip to Seattle, very hard to find in Canada, if you can find it, try it very enjoyable

name: Pike IPA
review: Dorada consistentemente turbia, de abundante espuma cremosa. Aroma intenso lupulado, Muy suave en boca. Muy amarga, Intensa, frutal. Uva, pomelo. Buena IPA

name: Pike IPA
review: Proeverij bij de brouwerij in Seattle. Flink bitter, citrus, licht bloemig. (9-2016).

name: Pike IPA
review: Bottle flew straight form Seatle to Warsaw (Poland). Aromat hoppy sweet citrus. Medium to light bitterness. Not bad.

name: Pike IPA
review: Hazy orange with thin lacy head. Very fruity aroma, lots of citrus especially. Very sharp hop taste, really smacks you quick. Not too intense though it mellows to a more manageable fruity hop. Then finishes with quite caramely malts. Decent every day IPA.

name: Pike IPA
review: Poured from a 12 oz bottle into a plastic cup. Nice copper color with an off-white head. A little caramel and citrus on the nose. Medium body, average carbonation and moderate bitter. Bitter, but short finish. Simple, but refreshing.

name: Pike IPA
review: Pours a clear golden brown on tap with fluffy off-white head that leaves moderate lace. Aroma of mild piney and floral hops over deep caramel malt. Taste follows, a clean old school west coast IPA. It's ok.

name: Pike IPA
review: On tap at brewery on 1st Street, downtown Seattle. Pours dark gold with thick off-white head and lacing (my son called it crown lacing, so I’m going to adopt that descriptor, thanks to him!). Aroma: citrus, tropical flowers. Flavor: malt-forward (brown sugar, honey), floral. Mouthfeel: medium-bodied, soft on palette.

name: Pike Golden Ale
review: Tried for the first time back in 2011. Poured Golden, thick foamy head. Aroma of bready and a little citrus. Flavor is more malty than expected.

name: Pike Golden Ale
review: Pike Brewing Company--Pike Golden Ale--1998 Release--12 oz. Bottle--4.70% ABV. (4.25 / 5.0) Golden Ale--Bright light red golden color. Very nice malt flavor light but rich. Nice hop notes. Very tasty. Sampled 9/19/1998. Pike Brewing Company--Pike Golden Ale--Small Logo--1999 Release--12 oz. Bottle--4.70% ABV. (4.0 / 5.0) Golden Ale--Clear bright amber golden color. Earthy light floral hop front. Light textured roasted caramel malt body has crisp earthy pale ale richness. Light hop spice tinge finishes well balanced light brew. Sampled 6/24/1999.

name: Pike Golden Ale
review: Another impressive brew from Pike- pours a bright golden brown colour with a medium white haed. Aroma is slightly grainy but also of german hops. Semi sweet mouthfeel, light, refreshing and finishes very crisp.

name: Pike Golden Ale
review: Hazy gold ,big lasting off white head. Tiny bead. Fresh nose. Fruity malty flavor with decent hopping in the finish

name: Pike Golden Ale
review: Golden brown color, medium head. Slightly hoppy, some maltyness, slightly sweet (apricot?) yeast esters. A session beer (German style). Finish is crisp. Aftertaste is malty, slightly sweet.

name: Pike Golden Ale
review: i would like to drink some more of this beer, nice ale......................

name: Pike Golden Ale
review: I would have to agree, this beer comes across clean and refreshing, the balanced brew is smooth and has a great finish.

name: Pike Golden Ale
review: A good clean tasting beer. Hops and malts are well balanced and the beer comes across clean and fresh.

name: Pike Kilt Lifter
review: Tap @ Pike Brewing Co, Seattle. Pours a deep amber brown, small pale tan head. Caramel nose. Medium bodied, nice toffee presence, a small amount of sweet malt grain. Good wee heavy.

name: Pike Kilt Lifter
review: Draft: Poured a clear burgundy color ale with a medium off-white foamy head with OK retention and light carbonation. Aroma of caramelized malt with light toffee notes is enjoyable. Taste is also a mix of caramelized malt notes, some toffee with some residual sugar notes. Body is about average with good carbonation. Not the most complex offering from the style but enjoyable nonetheless.

name: Pike Kilt Lifter
review: Draft at the brewery. Dark amber color. Malty, with a slight hint of smoky scotch.

name: Pike Kilt Lifter
review: Warm and malty flavour, but lacking something. A bit too sweet and a little too unbalanced for my taste

name: Pike Kilt Lifter
review: Hint of musk amd some florals. Amber pour with good head. Light caramel. Light sweet end. Tap at brewery.

name: Pike Kilt Lifter
review: Cobriza de buena espuma y buen aspecto. Aroma escaso, malteado. En boca es suave y de predominio malteado, tirando a dulce, con contrapunto de tono ahumado, ligeramente lupulado.

name: Pike Kilt Lifter
review: Fles 35,5cl in Seattle. Lichte rooksmaak wegens peated scotch whisky malts, carameltonen, wat maltig. Apart. (8-2016).

name: Pike Kilt Lifter
review: Bottle flew straight form Seatle to Warsaw (Poland). Aroma caramel, toffee, bread. Little bitternes.

name: Pike Kilt Lifter
review: Bottle in Seattle. Ring of soft offwhite foam on a darker Ruby amber body. Lightly peaty and fruit forward malt aroma. Medium body with dry red fruit skin and a hint of metallic and peaty malts. Boring but enjoyable enough. Soft mid palate with some malt bitterness by finish. Classical American example of style.

name: Pike Kilt Lifter
review: Pours a clear copper brown on tap with thin ring of bubbly off-white head that leaves light lace. Aroma and taste of typical scotch ale, earthy hops, sweet and dark malts, a hint of fruity esters, booze is lighter here. Decent.

name: Pike Old Bawdy
review: 30-Jul-17 (12-oz bottle: Purchased 09-Apr-07 for $5.58 at Liquid Solutions in Tigard, OR) This aged Barley Wine pours a very hazy, amber-brown body, but just a ring of large bubbles because when I popped the cap, there was no carbonation rush. So, yeah, it's pretty close to flat. The nose is earthy and very caramely, with aromas of wort, decayed logs, toffee, and some milk chocolate. On the palate, lots and lots of caramel, but it's not nearly as sweet as expected. Earthy logs, lightly toasted bread, fig, and dried apricot, but the finish is strangely reminiscent of a slightly smoky Pilsener like the famous Urquell. The beer is medium-full in weight, low in carbonation, and because it's not that sweet and there's a touch of earthy acidity, it's not heavy or cloying in the least. Overall, with the exception of the low carbonation due to the twist top, this is very tasty and enjoyable.

name: Pike Old Bawdy
review: Boozy with lots of caramel. Pours hazy orange with good head and lacing. Bittersweet boiled down with tobacco. Tap at brewery.

name: Pike Old Bawdy
review: August 8, 2014 - with blankboy, gregclow, jercraigs and mabel. Bomber. Ruby-copper pour, nice creamy tan mottled head. Hoo yeah, US barleywine aroma all right - alcohol, floral/resin bitterness - lots of sweet cereal/gluten grain. Taste follows - strong, malty and big bitterness to match - just the thing (8+). Solid body, chewy, decent carbonation - big mellow bitter/boozy/malty finish ... I would grab this again in a shot.

name: Pike Old Bawdy
review: Bomber, 2012 vintage. Caramel malt aroma with notes of peaty smoke, dark fruit and grassy and floral hops. Pours cloudy caramel colored with a thin tan head that has little retention or lacing. Starts with caramel malt and dark fruit flavors with peaty smoke notes. Finishes dry with grassy and floral hops as well as light citrus hops. Pretty good barleywine.

name: Pike Old Bawdy
review: This gets worse as it goes along. Smells nicely of grass and molasses, with a nice similar first flavor. However, it gets sweeter the deeper in the bottle get, which, for a 2-year old bottle isn’t great. Maybe it’ll mellow out even more as it gets older, but I was hoping for a bit more here.

name: Pike Old Bawdy
review: It pours cloudy medium brown with a tinge of orange and a light brown head. The aroma has plenty of sweet malt with bread and caramel. It also has aroma of plums and floral elements. It also has hints of citrus that is orange like. The malt is predominant with a balance between the esters and hops in the background. The malt flavors are sweet with the hop balance being somewhat aggressive with a moderate alcohol element in the taste. It has bread and caramel malt richness in the flavors with floral hops and citrus that in orange like. There are also hints of plums and the alcohol does has a hint of whiskey element in it as well. It has a chewy body with moderately high alcohol warming that is a slight tinge hot, but not unpleasant. It is somewhat dry and the floral hops and dryness linger on the palate. Overall, this is a malt forward barley wine that is moderately hop aggressive as the beer warms.

name: Pike Old Bawdy
review: 2013 vintage. Nice maltiness, caramel and clove. Was a bit of medicinal taste on first sip. Pretty rounded as you might expect with a three year old barleywine.

name: Pike Old Bawdy
review: 22oz bottle, winter 2015 edition. Hazy dark amber, with a thin but lasting head, and spotty lace. Aroma is malty, caramel, smoke, peat, raisin. Flavor is sweet and malty up front, lots of caramel and dried fruit, a touch of peat, with some citrusy hops on the finish.

name: Pike Old Bawdy
review: On tap at the brewery. Pours a hazed amber brown with a medium sized tan head. Big sticky malt on the nose, sweet and fruity, a hint of isopropyl. Medium bodied, big and malty, rather sticky fruity malt. Slow malt, sticky and sweet. Big plum and prune notes. Long malt and soft bitterness into the finish, a bit of warming alcohol.

name: Pike Old Bawdy
review: Pours a hazy reddish brown. Aromas of hops, caramel malts, kind of medicinal. Flavor is to strong for me, big alcohol taste, malty with a citrus taste.

name: Pike Old 89 Nitro Porter
review: Draft at Pike Pub in Seattle, WA. Dark body, small head. Alcohol noticeable for such a light brew. Good deal of hops with some lingering woodiness.

name: Pike Old 89 Nitro Porter
review: For those with a zest for dark porters, the Pike Old 89 is a wise choice. Pours a dark amber-brown body with a handsome tan head. Described as a modern version of an old world beers, Old 89 heads out much like an English stout, while coming at you with rich coffee tonus and closing with a particularly malleable, lightsome finish.

name: Pike Old 89 Nitro Porter
review: on tap at the brewpub. quite dark with a thin, lasting off-white head. some cocoa powder and whipped cream in the aroma, smooth and drinkable, faint tartness and a little after dinner mint

name: Pike Old 89 Nitro Porter
review: Tap at brewpub. Good nose, choc/coffee/mocha. Little egg or salty too. Classic brown/ black color. Good head that faded. Sweet and bitter flavors, chocolate/ soap/ tinny. Thin bodied, sweet dry finish. Slightly off from a classic porter. Just alright.

name: Pike Old 89 Nitro Porter
review: hat this on tap and it was pretty good, I compare it as a tasty version of guniess. It was very creamy with decent lacing, and the taste was very full, very much a decent porter. I will go with this one again if I go back.

name: Pike Old 89 Nitro Porter
review: Had it on Tap, was supprised on this rendition of the old classic. My buddy thought it was better than a good Guiness I didn’t agree but still thought it was a damn good nitro brew. I did pick up a bit of ’wateriness’ that was a bit dristracting and the creaminess wasn’t up to par with what I look for in a Guiness style beer. But all in all this is brew can stand w/ the best of what I normally find of tap in Washington.

name: Pike Old 89 Nitro Porter
review: Dark brown/ruby, tan light head/lacing. The aroma is chocolaty with some mocha & coffee. Watery, metallic. The flavor is salty with some astringent malts. Very light and too dry.

name: Pike Old 89 Nitro Porter
review: Bottle(sample bottling) pours black with brown highlights, nice cream colored frothy head, with clingy lacing.   Roasted malts and a major amount of butter on the nose.   Forwardly butter like with minor roasted malt flavor.   By the middle and through to the finish the flavor falls off the boat and is completely gone after I swallow.   Maybe a light flavor of coffee or dark chocolate on the exit, but VERY light.   Body and mouthfeel are decent, but this is one that I will soon forget.

name: Pike Old 89 Nitro Porter
review: Tap@Pike. Sweet caramel and toast, some roasted malt, soft and light. Also noticed odd aromas of sweat and nappies, which made it a bit more interesting.

name: Pike Old 89 Nitro Porter
review: This actually surprised the hell out of me. I tend to find nitro beers watered down beyond belief and aching to be gulped...not this one. This was wonderfully balanced between the roasted barley and great chocolate notes. I would be lying if I said this didn't carry with it the nitro characteristic of a less-than-full aroma, but the appearance makes up for it right?

name: Pike Weisse
review: Nitro tap@ Pike. Clear golden color with lasting white head. Light apricot, dusty pale malt, wheaty yeasty aromas. Super smooth medium body. Lightly tart wheat flavors with mild clove, banana yeast, and mild earth____smooth easy finish---not bad.

name: Pike Weisse
review: "there were only a couple brews at Pike that i DIDN’T like, but this was the worst of em. A weak ass beer, even for a hefe. a muddled slightly unpleasant aroma atop an unassuming beer in both body and flavor. one to avoid."

name: Pike Weisse
review: Not included in the Sampler, so I ordered a glass after I tried all the rest. It was a good decision as this is a decent Hefeweizen.

name: Pike Weisse
review: On tap at the brewery. Poured cloudy yellow with a white head. Aroma was lemon. Medium sweetness, no bitterness, and a thin body.

name: Pike Weisse
review: this was very wheaty. I had this in my first visit and like the amber weisse better

name: Pike Weisse
review: 2010-07-05. Crisp dark yellow with a small white head. 3+ Mild aroma is lightly estery, touch of wheat. Flavour is thinner than hoped, fruity esters, tart grainy wheat in the finish lingers in the aftertaste. Average palate. bit dull but okay. On tap at Pike Place brewpub, Seattle

name: Pike Weisse
review: Draught at Brewpub, Seattle, WA, USA. Slightly hazy pale golden colour with small white head. Citrus, wheat and spices in aroma. Wheat, sweetish fruits, citrus and some mild hops in flavour. Slightly thin.

name: Pike Weisse
review: Draught at the brewpub. Served with lemon, which took over the nose. Some banana, clove, and ginger in there too. A bland American wheat ale cum weizen. Banana, lemon, and ginger in the mouth. Not very crisp or refreshing. Mediocre.

name: Pike Weisse
review: Tap at the brewpub. I suggest this is more of a wheat beer than a hefe. Eh. Hazy golden amber with a creamy white head. Mild malt/wheat aroma. Medium body; mild carbonation. Flavor is light wheat/malt with a little Belgian yeast/spice. Hints of fruit. Very refreshing. Might be some citrus, but they stuck a lemon on it. So?

name: Pike Weisse
review: tap at brewery. pours a clear golden with a small offwhite head. creamy wheat. light toast grass and sourdough notes. pears. okay.

name: Pike XXXXX Stout
review: Draft at the brewery. Opaque with a frothy, tan head. Aroma of chocolate and dark roast coffee. Smooth and creamy.

name: Pike XXXXX Stout
review: 65cl bottle at home (27 IV 2019), as Pike XXXXX Stout. Allready shared such a bottle at a beer geeks gathering, now let's have this world class stout a go at a more convenient pace. The black tanned brew with orange-red to even brown gloom - never being sticky, whatsoever - comes with almost no foam. The beer is pitch-black at its core. The nose has a typical dry stout character, with a herbal and even creamy body. Think of black chocolate, of course, but also several hints at cacao, cigar, chocolate ice cream topping. The roasted malts are omnipresent. The mouthfeel is very soft, with just a hidden carbonation at best. The body is a sour, with different bitter chocolate and smoked malt features. Sweetness is unresponsive, which is nice. This continues being a good-old stout, so don't expect an explosion of taste sensations. The warming alcoholic touch is smooth and restrained. Here again, one can just feel those creamy, yeasty dashes. At the end, a caramel feeling drops in - making this a great treat.

name: Pike XXXXX Stout
review: Ingredients: Water, Malt, Hops, and Yeast....Plain and simple. A nice chocolate stout with good hop finish. Balance close to perfect for this style. Similar to the new Guiness Foreign Extra. This is my first sample from Pike and is a nice start. Solid beer that I would try again.

name: Pike XXXXX Stout
review: 19-Aug-17 (22-oz bottle: Purchased 14-Mar-07 for $4.30 at Liquid Solutions in Tigard, OR) This Stout pours a black body and a thin, tan head due to lower carbonation from the extended cellaring. The nose is very roasty with lots of licorice, scorched earth, char, molasses, and old wood. On the palate, aged, earthy character and dark-roast dominate, with notes of chocolate, cocoa, some coffee, and molasses. The beer is medium in weight, medium-minus in carbonation, and very smooth on the palate. Overall, despite the long cellaring, this is still a very tasty and enjoyable Stout.

name: Pike XXXXX Stout
review: Roast and dark chocolate. Light caramel but properly subdued. Pours black with good mocha head. Rich and fairly dry. Velvety texture. Bottlr.

name: Pike XXXXX Stout
review: Excellent stout. Lots of bitter chocolates some dried fig and molasses but not too sweet. Typically all the stuff u want in a stout especially if u don’t like the too thick and syrupy type. Liking it more as I sip. Great balance of alcohol and fruit. Sexy beer!

name: Pike XXXXX Stout
review: Proeverij bij de brouwerij in Seattle. Koffie, gebrande mout, flink bitter, licht romig. Ook zoeten. (9-2016).

name: Pike XXXXX Stout
review: Need an oil change? Smooth rich roasty stout with a dry finish. Very well made ale. A long-time fav. Go to the brewery in the market downtown and hope that it is on nitro... sip slowly and enjoy the moment. Doesn’t get much better.

name: Pike XXXXX Stout
review: pours opaque from bottle with beige head. very roasted with coffee notes. pretty thin feel. a good obe

name: Pike XXXXX Stout
review: 26/VIII/17 - 1Pt. 6Fl. Oz. bottle, shared @ RBBSG17 - BB: n/a (2017-1362) Thanks to Mathieu the bottle! Clear dark brown beer, small creamy beige head, unstable, bit adhesive. Aroma: malty, grains, bit yeasty, pretty roasted. MF: soft carbon, medium to full body. Taste: very roasted start, bitter, malty, some coffee, chocolate. Aftertaste: rather bitter, some coffee, chocolate, caramel.

name: Pike Bootleg Brown
review: Somewhat grainey and rather dull, this beer sports a hint of roasted nuttiness, some sweet maltiness, but is overall pretty bland and boring.

name: Pike Bootleg Brown
review: Deep brown beer. Very faint aroma. Some light nuttiness over the sweet caramel and a light cocoa note. Flavour is pretty bland and watery though. Light sweetness and a touch of nuttiness. Meh.

name: Pike Bootleg Brown
review: clear brown beer with a tan head. dominant choc nose. filed down the throat with ease. pushing mostly malty tones of shakra. mild and easy to drink but not impressive.

name: Pike Bootleg Brown
review: Medium brown colour with thin tan head. Medium malt nose with underlying alcohol notes. Mild roasted malt taste with a dry finish.

name: Pike Bootleg Brown
review: on tap at pike. pretty decent brown ale. browny amber, caramel aroma, lightly nutty with a pleasant late saltiness in the finish

name: Pike Bootleg Brown
review: Nut Browns tend to be smooth, but this was very much so. Mild malt, not so overwhelmingly flavorful, but loaded with caramel and slightly toasty nuttiness. Not the most palatable brown, with a malt loaded beer like this the palate should be a given, but this was a touch thin. Overall average, although tasty.

name: Pike Bootleg Brown
review: Tap at brewpub, ok nose, lite roasty, carmel & chocolate with a touch of orange. Clean orange brown color. No head. Bitter flavors. baker chocolate and touch of orange/ grapefruit came to mind. Thin bodied, bitter dry finish. I like it, though tad hoppy for a brown ale

name: Pike Bootleg Brown
review: Amber mahogany with no head & some lacing. The aroma is like musky hop dishwater. The flavor is watery with some thick malt & a finish that really cries out for some hop or alcohol balance.

name: Pike Bootleg Brown
review: Tap@Pike. This wasn’t too bad for a brown ale. Not too sweet or sickly, nice nutty malts and not much else, simple, but it tasted OK to me.

name: Pike Bootleg Brown
review: On Tap Pours a bit darker than the Pike Pale Ale but is similar in taste. Floral with a small hop undertone and sweet malt. A slight "woody" aftertaste.

name: Pike Auld Acquaintance
review: Glad that I got this on clearance. 2nd sample from this brewer and liking what I am seeing so far. This is one of those simple beers. Description says "lots of malt", but the ingredients say "malted barley, water, hops, yeast ......" along with the other spices. Balance works well for me and is a nice representation of a winter ale. Does not seem that malty, and like a lighter version of a barleywine...or has that pale ale feel. Will look for this again next season.

name: Pike Auld Acquaintance
review: Deep orange. Spice and orange zest with some caramel. Fruity, lightly toasted, medium bitterness. Light citrus tang. Decent.

name: Pike Auld Acquaintance
review: Charlie Papazian bottle. Sweet and spicy aroma. Spot on with the winter spices. Nicely balanced by the malt. Would be good with a pumpkin pie. Where’s that pie anyway?!?

name: Pike Auld Acquaintance
review: On tap at the brewery. Pours a hazed amber brown with a medium sized white head. Soft fruity malt on the nose, toast, a vague hint of spices. Medium bodied, soft and toasty, musk, a bit of dusty dry spices. Warm malt into the finish.

name: Pike Auld Acquaintance
review: Pours a half finger of head on a dirty dark straw body. The aroma is grain and wet hay, a little barnyard. The taste is mildly sweet: plum and apricot; then some mild bitterness. A bit mushed in flavor. The texture is softer.

name: Pike Auld Acquaintance
review: 22 ounce bomber bottle to wine glass Appearance: Orange- brown color(held against light, hazy, minimal off white head, minimal lacing Smell: not a lot of aroma, slight toasted grain smell, hint of alcohol Taste: slight bitterness Mouth feel: Overall Good Beer but will not buy again

name: Pike Auld Acquaintance
review: Draught at the Pike Brewing Co, Seattle, WA. Slightly cloudy red brown color with a mid-size creamy tan head. Darkish sweet malt, mild hops and some dryness in the aroma. The flavor is dark hops, moderate bitterness and dry dark malt. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Pike Auld Acquaintance
review: Draught at Collective on Tap, Woodinville, WA Hazy dark amber color. Some caramel, very light biscuity malts, ordinary bitterness, tiny nuttiness in the final. Not much effort, but at least it’s clean.

name: Pike Auld Acquaintance
review: From bottle. Dark amber color. Aroma is light spice, citrus, and caramel malt. Taste is similar, with some coriander and slight bitterness. Lingering spice.

name: Pike Auld Acquaintance
review: 22oz bomber, this is the 3rd time I am buying this beer just to rate it. And you know I really want to rate it because its not a very positive review. Dark orange amber color. Head fades quickly. Aroma is sweet fruity and toasty. Nothing about that is fun or good. There are some poor spices, just a mix of bad stuff.

name: Black Horse Premium Lager
review: Pints out of the bottle at Harbour View Restaurant. Soaking wet cold and miserable with 4 hours before the ferry leaves Port Au Basques. Clear yellow lightly sweet and a bit grainy, cold and crisp. Its a macro lager, not anything you wouldn't expect cleanly made. The first one went down in record time as I slowly returned to somewhat normal. The next two paired well with the Greco pizza I savored before heading getting on the ship to head back home.

name: Black Horse Premium Lager
review: Bottled. Clear yellow body with small white head. The taste is mellow and yeasty and there almost no finish.

name: Black Horse Premium Lager
review: 341 ml bottle @ Maxwell’s Goose Bay, Labrador. Pours a light, clear straw with a large, light, white head. Aromas are too faint when cold. Tastes are standard macro lager (light grain, corn) with only a subtle hint of hops. Light body, crisp, fairly assertive carbonation and a medium grain finish. Inoffensive and easy drinking but not interesting. ---Rated via Beer Buddy

name: Black Horse Premium Lager
review: Sampled from the tap at Maxwell’s Plum. Pours a clear light gold with a white head that dissipates to the edges and laces. Aroma has notes of corn and sweet grains with some biscuit supporting. Flavor has lots of corn and stale sweet grains with a touch of bread underlying.

name: Black Horse Premium Lager
review: Draft - Light corn. Clear gold with a nice white head. Light something, but really nothing. A very tasteless beer.

name: Black Horse Premium Lager
review: Bottle at Kwang Tung, Fogo Island’s only Chinese restaurant, and apparently the most northern Chinese restaurant in Canada (as told to me by someone in St.John’s). This has basically no flavour or aroma. Very pale yellow with thin white head. Very faint honeyish flavour. This is an inoffensive alternative to water.

name: Black Horse Premium Lager
review: On tap at the Fo’c’sle. Pours a clear golden colour with white head with decent retention. Aroma is hard to detect besides bland graininess. Flavour also has weak granny notes with some wet straw. Finish? What finish. No seriously off notes, but an incredibly forgettable beer.

name: Black Horse Premium Lager
review: In bottle and on tap; overall just OK. Another Molson beer .. easy drinking but medium bodied, not very interesting ...

name: Black Horse Premium Lager
review: Aroma: Mild Sweet Corn Appearance: Golden Straw Hue, Passes All Light, Thin White Head, Some Lacing Taste: Water, Mild Corn Mouthfeel: Average Carbonation, Light Bodied, Watery

name: Black Horse Premium Lager
review: Drank straight from bottle. Nose, corn and sweet malt. Taste of sweet malt, no hop character. Not as much skunk and adjunct flavor as most pale lagers.

name: Legend Porter
review: On tap at Legend, pours a deep dark brown / near-black with a small tan head. Aroma brings out toasted malt and some bready notes. Flavour is along the same lines, with toasted malt and a hint of earthy cocoa. Nothing special here, but it’s drinkable.

name: Legend Porter
review: on tap at the brewpub in Richmond - super dark color. Nice sweet aroma. A very good porter.

name: Legend Porter
review: Bomber->pokal. Pours black with tall frothy tan head. Moderate carbonation. Roasted malt and coffee, thin and watery.

name: Legend Porter
review: Tap @ brewery shared with HopTsing. Very dark with thin dissipating head. First sniff reminds me of wine, then I get chocolate, then light coffee, and a sour note. Light roast flavor. Lots of carbonation. Not too bad.

name: Legend Porter
review: February 2010. 22 oz. bottle. Pours dark brown with a tan head. Roasted malt, chocolate and some coffee notes. A little sweet on the palate with a bitter finish.

name: Legend Porter
review: Poured from 22 oz. bottle at Dixie Bones BBQ in Woodbridge, VA. Opaque, near black with a huge brown head and fair lacing. Aroma of chocolate, coffee, roasted malt and toast. Taste of chocolate, roasted coffee, roasted malt, earthy hops and a hint of molasses. Medium/light body and medium/low carbonation. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Legend Porter
review: Received in a trade from RABinVA. Drank this brew with a fantastic birthday dinner of Falafel, African Mango and Avocado Salad , and Carrot Cake, all prepared by my darling wife. Pours Mahogany with ample tan head. Flavor notes of coffee, chocolate, and citrus, in that order. Weak scent. Glad I got a chance to give this a try. Bottle - Trade from RABinVA - Atlanta, GA

name: Legend Porter
review: Roasty light coffee and alcohol notes. Black body with slight red hue. Dry coffee and choclate notes with malty finish. Crisp and dry on palate

name: Legend Porter
review: Aromas of roasted dark chocolate, coffee, dark earth, and subtle citrus. Black with ruby highlights, and a mostly fading, beige head. Dry, earthy, and roasty. Medium body, good carbonation, and with a roasty finish.

name: Legend Porter
review: Very dark brown pour, light brown head. Dry porter, lots of roasted malt, licorice, dark toast, roasted nuts.

name: A1A Ale Works A. Strange Stout
review: NIce and not troo strong. Was part of the flight. Wasy to drink with some cocoa features and thick in shape

name: A1A Ale Works A. Strange Stout
review: on tap at the brewpub; black color; roasted malt and coffee aroma; smooth, roasted malt flavor with coffee notes; slightly sweet

name: A1A Ale Works A. Strange Stout
review: Draft at the A1 Aleworks bar. Poured into a pint glass. Very dark in color, nearly black. Thick mocha head. Some lacing. Aroma was mild but good. Coffee, chocolate, roasty toasty malts, and peat. Taste was actually pretty good and balanced. The roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, and earth combined nicely. Medium body, nice mouth feel, slightly creamy. Easy to drink. Slight bitter coffee finish. Pretty good!

name: A1A Ale Works A. Strange Stout
review: Ordered draft at A1A Aleworks in Saint Augustine, FL. Served in a stout glass, dark brown color with dark tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, some coffee with a slightly earthy note. Taste was malty roast, some chocolate and dark fruit with very light hop note. Medium body, average carbonation, slightly creamy with sweet roast finish. Overall quite tasty, a lighter body but still full of flavor. Nice drinking over the downtown streets of the oldest city.

name: A1A Ale Works A. Strange Stout
review: On tap at the brewpub. Black pour with a small khaki head. Laid back roasted malts, cocoa, and light coffee in the aroma and flavor. Follows suits of the other GB recipes.

name: A1A Ale Works A. Strange Stout
review: On draft at A1A. Pours a porter brown color with an off-tan head. Nose is roasted malt, some earth, some cocoa, and some dry coffee. Flavor is similar with roasted malts, earth, cocoa, and some dry coffee. Baseline stout. Light to medium in body and very drinkable.

name: A1A Ale Works A. Strange Stout
review: Light aromas and flavors of coffee, chocolate and maybe some charcoal. Pours a nice opaque black with a small khaki head that left some lacing. Mouthfeel was slightly creamy but overall too thin. A decent stout I guess but nothing special.

name: A1A Ale Works A. Strange Stout
review: Dark brown, black, beige cover. Roasty, coffee aroma. Taste is bitter, roast, coffee, chocolate.

name: A1A Ale Works A. Strange Stout
review: Tap at brewpub. Coffee and chocolate taste pretty discreet, not much hops in there. A bit watery and served too cold... Still decent and enjoyable.

name: A1A Ale Works A. Strange Stout
review: Sampler at brewpub pours dark brown, light mocha head. Aroma and taste, malty with good notes of chocolate that is not overly bitter. Some faint touch of coffee and roast. Sweet with a lactose/cream like mouthfeel and some caramel.

name: Michelob Black and Tan
review: Aroma and flavor is dark malts, thin in the middle and a mix of chocolate and and slight acidity in the finish.

name: Michelob Black and Tan
review: "a weak lighter ale blended with a weak dark ale. not revolting, but i had it on tap with a pizza and beyond the crispness and tiny bit of malt, there’s nothing there..."

name: Michelob Black and Tan
review: 12 oz bottle, pours black with a tan head. Malty aroma but not really much more then that.

name: Michelob Black and Tan
review: body that is dense with soft carbonation like a parfait. bit of chocolate and gravy master flavor that is sweet and with cereal grains. finish lightens on the body and lingering flavor of sweetness and barley. it is good on a hot day and would probably be good in certain situations.

name: Michelob Black and Tan
review: Anheuser-Busch, Inc.--Michelob Specialty Brewing Group--Black and Tan--1998 12 oz. Bottle. 5.00% ABV. (3.25 / 5.0) Very dark and black. Light chocolate flavor in medium light body. Very clean finish.

name: Michelob Black and Tan
review: This is inferior in all ways to any black and tan that you could possibly concoct on your own. Too sweet and watery by half for my tastes. More lager than Porter.

name: Michelob Black and Tan
review: Bottle. Found some old notes. somewhat of a muddy brown in color, next to flat pour. It had somewhat of a roasted coffee aroma. Tasting revealed somewhat of a bitter lager porter mix. It had a watery body, and somewhat of an oily character. Not very good.

name: Michelob Black and Tan
review: Bottle Poured a dark brown. Had aroma of grain and bubbles. Did not taste like a mix but rather a weak bock. Not awful but its gone now anyway.

name: Michelob Black and Tan
review: Bottle poured like a dark lager. Aroma was of roasted malt. Flavor was burnt malt and very light on the tongue.

name: Michelob Black and Tan
review: I want to say this was the precursor to Amber bock, but this is terrible. No separation between the dark and the light, just an amberish dark brown color. Light and grainy and not quite horrid, but close.

name: McSorleys Black and Tan
review: From old tasting notes. Deep reddish brown color. Bubbly tan head. Sweet malty nose. Light chocolate malt flavor.

name: McSorleys Black and Tan
review: Tap. Dark pour with mocha head. Slight dark roast, nuts, toffee flavor. Easy to drink. Not bad, especially at a bar like this

name: Dogfish Head Raison D'Etre
review: 12oz bottle share in 2013. Deep brown with a tan head. Aroma of raisins, prunes, dates, dark malt and caramel. Fantastic mouthfeel in the beer. So much wonderful dried fruit and Christmas pudding flavour. Not too sweet, though. Such a shame you don’t see Dogfishhead in the UK anymore.

name: Dogfish Head Raison D'Etre
review: 2008 bottle reviewed on 4/5/19. Dark brown pour with a short-lived khaki head. German alt or maibock pruny esters on the nose. Prune and brown sugar flavors.

name: Dogfish Head Raison D'Etre
review: 2009 bottle, at a tasting in 2018. Hazy reddish amber with very small frothy beige head, woodsy sweet rum aroma, low carbonation, very boozy sweet taste, thin body, long finish. This is like drinking pure spirits!

name: Dogfish Head Raison D'Etre
review: From May 2008 I got this bottle in a trade with Wasatch. Thanks John! The pour reveals a clear reddish amber liquid with a 2 finger head of foam and plenty of lacing. Very good head retention. The smell has notes of wood, bubblegum, candy sugar, and a fruitiness. The taste is....different. I get a musky flavour mixed with some caramel malt, along with bubblegum, some candy sugar, but, I can't get over the muskiness, if that is the proper way to describe it. Whole lot of alcohol going on in the taste as well, and too much warming for the abv, imho. I'm drinking this at near room temperature and maybe that isn't the way to go but under these conditions, it's not working for me at all. The body is definitely on the watery side for me.. I'm glad I got to try this brew but it just doesn't do it for me, unlike the majority of DFH's brews. 1 bottle is more than enough and I wouldn't seek this out again, for sure. To me, the flavours are a mess.

name: Dogfish Head Raison D'Etre
review: May 28, 2017. Flight selection at DFH brewpub in Rehoboth. Outstanding Belgian strong...smoky, oak flavor...long caramel, sugary finish. Will be looking for this in the future.

name: Dogfish Head Raison D'Etre
review: Originally rated on 1/2/2009.A nice deep brown with a slight reddish tint body, off white head that left plenty of lace. Flavor was a disappointment with mostly a metallic presence that dominated the other flavors. I guess this was a bad bottle, maybe i might try it again someday.

name: Dogfish Head Raison D'Etre
review: Dark clear, brown / reddish pour with thick beige foam. Full body with less fizz and a thick, sweet finish. Dried fruit in the nose and caramel, nutty malts, burnt sugar. Some light bitterness, but this is all about the malt mingling with the fruit. The finish has a little yeast and alcohol. A strong, complex approach to a Belgian that would compliment a range of flavorful foods.

name: Dogfish Head Raison D'Etre
review: Backlog, ocena przepisana z untappd, w ramach uzupe³niania profilu na ratebeer.

name: Dogfish Head Raison D'Etre
review: Pours dark brown with whitish head. Aroma of dark fruits, belgian yeast, caramel malts. Just the same in the mouth. Medium body with low to medium carbonation. Sticky palate. Somehow decent, not that good but not that bad after all.

name: Dogfish Head Raison D'Etre
review: On tap at DFH. The mouthfeel is smooth but there’s a banana yeasty taste I’m not a fan of.

name: Dogfish Head Chicory Stout
review: Pours black with a one finger, tan head. Aroma is molasses, coffee, wood and light licorice. Taste is brown sugar, moving to coffee, roast, licorice and wood. Finish is wood and coffee. A good stout.

name: Dogfish Head Chicory Stout
review: Had on April 3, 2019 from a bottle from 2007. Pours a very dark brown with a quickly evaporating khaki colored head. Sorghum and chicory on the nose. Moderately thick male feel. Drinks more dryly than the nose would suggest. Chicory earthiness and bitterness dominates the sorghum flavors.

name: Dogfish Head Chicory Stout
review: From Aug 2007 I got this one in a trade with Wasatch. Thanks, John! Pours from 12oz bottle a very dark brown with reddish hues and a small but tight head of foam that shrinks to some islands and it has some good sticky lacing. The smell is of sweet malt, roasted malt, vanilla and wood. The taste is of caramel and roasted malt, some vanilla and woody notes. Further sips give me a bit of chocolate and a wee bit of fruit and sharp bitterness just before the finish and the finish itself is semi sweet. This is a good taster and easy to drink and it has a smooth mouthfeel and the carbo is light. All in all, a solid American Stout that should please most palates.

name: Dogfish Head Chicory Stout
review: Backlog, bottle from Canals West Deptford. pours a dark brown color with a medium head and plenty of lasting lace on my glass. Notes of coffee, smoke, licorice, crystal malt, oat, and pine. Some more smoked cherry wood as it opens up. Not bad

name: Dogfish Head Chicory Stout
review: 12oz bottle. I just had to rate a DFH beer after all the anger about AB this week. Pours out dark brown almost black topped with a tan head. Nose is light chocolate some roast malts and a little hop bitterness. Taste is more like sadness as you can see my shity same old reviews are still mine and not a AB robot. Sure hope this blows over at some point but I am sure the scares are deep.

name: Dogfish Head Chicory Stout
review: Sampled at Epcot Food & Wine Festival 2016. Dark, reddish brown pour with moderate and persistent beige foam. Strong toasted malt nose with some cocoa and licorice notes. Medium body and light fizz. Cocoa an anise flavor with a slightly sweet finish.

name: Dogfish Head Chicory Stout
review: Nice woody flavor and scent. Slightly watery up front. Gets a little richer later with the oak. Nice and dark. Tap

name: Dogfish Head Chicory Stout
review: Rated from old notes. A workmanlike stout, rich, hints of chocolate and licorice. Served too cold at the time so some of the flavors were probably dulled. Definite candidate to re-rate.

name: Dogfish Head Chicory Stout
review: Vom Fass im Brauhaus. Tiefes Schwarz mit cremigem Schaum. Kaffe, Bitterschokolade und leichte Kräuternoten. Antrunk überraschend herb. Für mich zuviel Kaffee.

name: Dogfish Head Chicory Stout
review: Draught @ Dogfish Head Brewing & Eats, Rehoboth Beach, DE Pours dark reddish brown with a tan head. Aroma has notes of roasted malt, chocolate, caramel, and coffee. Taste is medium sweet and light to medium bitter with a long chocolate, roasted, coffee and cocoa finish. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

name: Rodenbach Grand Cru
review: Really sour:)) teasty, but actually seems to me very simple, tastes like black bread, Russian “Kvas” like. Red Ale from Rodenbach much-much better:)

name: Rodenbach Grand Cru
review: Brunröd i färgen med smutsvitt lätt skum. Softar fruktigt och syrligt av surkörsbär. Behaglig syra med sprudlande känsla mot gom och tunga. Smaken behaglig syrlig där körsbären tar lagom mycket plats ihop med en touch av vinägerkaraktär.

name: Rodenbach Grand Cru
review: .. attractive red beer .. red wine balsamic vinegar nose ... tingly tongue feel , very sour , ripe prunes , oaky ... finish bitter , sour .. a beer to savour , to sip and enjoy : cheers .

name: Rodenbach Grand Cru
review: Really dark reddish colour, small head. Aroma: oak, vinous aroma, "red sparkling wine", dried red fruits, tart berries, green apples, blackcurrant. Taste: tart fruits, blackcurrant, sore apples, "red sparkling wine", some strawberry syrup, cherries, some vinegar.

name: Rodenbach Alexander
review: Bottle. Pours pink/redish hue with think white and head. Sour cherry on the nose. Sweet cherry and sour caramel flavour.

name: Rodenbach Alexander
review: Hazy red-brown with a medium off-white head. Aroma is cherries, barnyard, tart and malt. Taste is medium sweet and light sour.

name: Mansfield Smooth Creamy Ale
review: Nitro Keg at the Storehouse, Amble. Pours clear golden amber with a thin white head. Aromas of light malt, little else. Taste is sweet and thin. Disappears to nothing.

name: Mansfield Smooth Creamy Ale
review: On tap at a hotel outside Mansfield. Pale Amber colour with a tick cream head. Very slight floral aroma, but dead other than that. Taste was quite sweet. Very poor.

name: Mansfield Smooth Creamy Ale
review: On keg at Matlock Town FC - Thought I’d had this, a very familiar feel to it. Typically good looking nitrokeg look, amber body, solid white head. Nose is a sweet caramel, a bit of malt and the taste has a similar feel too. Nitro helps this have a good mouthfeel, smooth and creamy. Very refreshing for its style.

name: Mansfield Smooth Creamy Ale
review: Golden pale ale with a creamy head. Its aroma is light and and the tropical fruit flavours are mild in taste.

name: Mansfield Smooth Creamy Ale
review: Two pints poured into UK pint sleeves at the Wellington cricket club bar on Sunday 9 Oct 2011 during a Christening party. Bright semi-dark amber body with a creamy foaming topping. This beer is cold when it comes out, it is also creamy, the nitrogen sees to both the temp and creaminess. No smell and the whole deal is weak, with only a slight bitterness in the taste. OK for none cask bitter men maybe, but not for me.

name: Mansfield Smooth Creamy Ale
review: Keg at the Dudley Sports & Social Club. Pours orange with a medium head. Aroma is some orange and bready malt. Taste had a hint of orange and watery bready malt. Got better as it warmed.

name: Mansfield Smooth Creamy Ale
review: Cask@Wheatsheaf, Cropwell Bishop. Golden/amber beer with a light head. The aroma is light and the flavour is slightly bitter and weak. Overall a weakly hopped and watery beer.

name: Mansfield Smooth Creamy Ale
review: On keg in a Burtonwood pub in Yorkshire - can’t remember where or when (old notes). Ventured into a Burtonwood pub because W & D bought the pub group and the days of finding Burtonwood beers in pubs bearing their name may be numbered. Unfortunately only W & D beers were on offer. So I took the tick rather than drink a Banks’s beer I’d had before. Amber colour. Certainly smooth and creamy. Unfirtunately its entirely devoid of flavour. Except a rather metallic aftertaste. It could hardly be called horrible - it doesn’t have enough character for that - but I surely won’t be seeking this one out again.

name: Mansfield Smooth Creamy Ale
review: Keg at The Pepperpot, Banbury. Orange amber with masses of nitrogen, white head. Crikey Ratebeer has messed my drinking habits up, there was a perfectly acceptable Pedigree to be had, but I opted for this. Cardboard notes to the fore with a flat malt taste. The creaminess comes from a thick primeivel soup of nitrogen awaiting to be released from the freezing liqued. Me not like.

name: Mansfield Smooth Creamy Ale
review: June, 2005. The Magna Carta, Lincoln. Keg. Creamy apple tinged beer - slightly tinny. Drinkable.

name: Mansfield Original Bitter
review: Keg pint on 23 April 2016 in The Countryman, Ingoldmells Lincolnshire. Not seen this beer for years, so thought I would have one for old times sake. Golden syrup coloured with a good, steady white head. Decent blend of malt and hops with a slight sweetness overall, ideal lunchtime throwing beer. No huge flavours or aroma, just a Cooking Bitter.

name: Mansfield Original Bitter
review: On tap at a hotel outside Mansfield. Amber colour with a tick cream head. Metalic aroma, but dead other than that. Taste was quite sweet. Very poor excuse for a bitter.

name: Mansfield Original Bitter
review: Orange yellow with smooth off-white lacing, lip-sticking foam head. Aroma and taste of regular British bitter. Just a good beer. (Immingham 201211)

name: Mansfield Original Bitter
review: 500ml can at 3.6%. Pours orange brown with a medium head. Aroma is fruity Ribena malt and a little dust. Taste is like drinking Ribena, dark berries. A little cocoa. Better then expected.

name: Mansfield Original Bitter
review: My first ever beer in a pub Sherwood Hall, Nottingham University Social Club........happy memories!

name: Mansfield Original Bitter
review: Can from my local offy. Miserable fucking bitch in The Last Oasis, Macclesfield. I boycotted her right after this the nosy fat cow. Clear amber gold with thick soapy white head. Just like her. Dripping in shite gold, thick fat swede on her. I might have to rate it again in case her evilness seeped into the can. I doubt it. Low carbonation, malty, tea. Don’t like it. Never buy from that evil donkey faced old fish wife again.

name: Mansfield Original Bitter
review: Nice smooth session bitter - good colour, nice head, fruity, nice malt but not overpowering. Hop aroma and finish. Very drinkable, sadly hard to get in these parts (West Yorkshire) - Inexplicably I picked up 20 cans of these in my local Morrisons as a split case yet they don’t appear to sell it unfortunately.

name: Mansfield Original Bitter
review: Can, Co-Op, Bracknell. Slightly cloudy amber colour with an off-white head; malty aroma and taste and a little bitterness at the end. Nothing exceptional.

name: Mansfield Original Bitter
review: Can, Sainsbury’s, Kidlington, 31-10-06. Mmmhh difficult to think of many positives about this, I only picked it up because it had been split from a multipack and was cheap. Amber coloured with white creamy head, bit sweet some malt but all in all as expected quite disappointing.

name: Mansfield Original Bitter
review: Can. Pours a nice amber colour, nice creamy head, and slight fruity taste. Overall, a pretty good bitter.

name: Mansfield Cask Ale
review: Cask @ Hole In The Wall, York. Copper-gold with a creamy head. Has a light bitterness and is a sessionable bitter.

name: Mansfield Cask Ale
review: Cask, Hole-in-the-Wall, York. From 2008 notes. Enjoyably smooth palate. Toffee flavour and slight caramel aroma. Amber pour with thick white head. Enjoyable

name: Mansfield Dark Smooth Ale
review: Keg at Beehive, Stoke. Pours dark brown with a light tan head. Some nut, some sweet caramel, spoiled by an artificial back taste.

name: Mansfield Dark Smooth Ale
review: 18th July 2015: keg pint at The Robin Hood just outside Baslow, Derbyshire. Dark, deep brown with a red hue the head a thick creamy affair. Served very cold, so no smell for at least 5 minutes. Roasted/toasted malt aroma once it was allowed to have one, I already knew it would have a promise of a mini sweetness to come in the taste, which it did. The taste was dominated by the malts and as it’s name suggests it was smooth in nature. Not really a keg bitter man but this was a whole lot better than the pint of cask Pedigree I had before it in the pub.

name: Mansfield Dark Smooth Ale
review: On tap at a hotel outside Mansfield. Deep brown colour colour with a tick cream head. Roasted malt aroma, but rather dull. Taste slightly sweet, but a touch of bitterness at the finish.

name: Mansfield Dark Smooth Ale
review: Black with a creamy head and a mild roasted aroma. Has chocolate notes in the flavour.

name: Mansfield Dark Smooth Ale
review: On Tap at the Hope & Anchor, Prescot 30/08/2008 Fruity aroma. Large beige head. Dark red smooth on the palate and slightly grainy with a little dryness in a crisp malt finish.

name: Mansfield Dark Smooth Ale
review: A Mes rate: Ok I have to describe this scene. Sim and I were driving to my brothers house in deepest darkest Macclesfield. It’s lashing down with rain and we are both busting for the loo. Eventually we can go no further, pull up the car and run over the road getting soaked into the nearest pub. Before I knew it I was in the gents and Sim had disappeared down a corridor hopefully to find the ladies. All of a sudden it occurs to me that we have just run through the pub not saying anything and the place was TOTALLY empty and the only three people in there had given us such a stare when we ran in. So being the good chap that I am I decide to buy a beer (don’t be cheeky and not use the toilet without buying anything, small pub struggling for business etc....) I’m done before Sim so I go straight to the bar and order a swift one of this as I have never seen it before. The well poured and conditioned beer was on the bar straight away and there I am, on my own with the three people who were now at the bar. Oh one of them is the landlord behind the bar by the way. Sim returns from the loo and we sat there and shared the beer and rate it infront of them into my phone. They honestly barely spoke and if they did it was just grunting. Instead they spent their whole time looking at us and my phone. If you have ever seen "Withnail and I" (and if you havent, you should) it was just like the pub near the cottage where the poacher comes in and serves himself at the end of the night. We left and stoped just around the corner to pick up a chinese meal from what was the exact take away equivalent of the watering house up the street. Imagine how pleased I was to get home and find out the beer was retired and the last rating was well over two years ago. The beer was decent but what do you care, you can’t get it anymore. Long rate very sorry.

name: Mansfield Dark Smooth Ale
review: Smooth headed ruby red/black mild with a roasted aroma and a fruity, watery, burn't and roasted flavour. Overall a watery weird tasting mild.

name: Mansfield Dark Smooth Ale
review: Doing this by memory so cant do a detailed description - Standard has dropped since brewery been taken over.

name: Mansfield Dark Mild
review: dark brown color with tan head medium sweetness, medium bitterness, medium body, average carbonation, bitter, i used to drink this in the local many years ago all because it was 95p a pint......95p a pint look at prices now !

name: Mansfield Dark Mild
review: Keg @ Pack Horse Inn, Failsworth. Very dark with a thick smooth head. It’s smooth tasting too with some light but very pleasant roasted and slightly burnt malts that are evident in both aroma and taste.

name: Mansfield Dark Mild
review: The Union, Hinckley. Dark ruby with a slick cream head and lace. Faint raisin and roast aroma; flavour butter biscuit, dried fruit and soft casky hints with a hint of beefiness (Monster Munch). Actually pretty decent- saw off 2 pints without whinging.

name: Mansfield Dark Mild
review: June, 2005. Keg with a soft nitro mix @ The Still, Lincoln. Tastes like the Mansfield Cask Ale but with some caramel stirred in. Bland for a mild. Poor quality stuff really. Low cost, high profit.

name: Mansfield Dark Mild
review: A dark red beer with a small chocolate brown head. It has no aroma, but the flavor is slightly smoked, slightly sour with roasted notes. A good mild - though the body is somewhat thin.

name: Mansfield Riding Traditional Bitter
review: Pours a pale amber colour. Tastes fine just boring and forgetable. This brewery produces better beers

name: Mansfield Riding Traditional Bitter
review: Cask @ Bar Fringe, Manchester. Clear golden malty bitter with a medium-high bitterness. Light and easy drinking for its style - certainly sessionable.

name: Mansfield Riding Traditional Bitter
review: First tasted this in the Wee Howf, Paisley in June 1995. Cask, handpump dispense. Clear copper in colour with a thick white head. Slight hint of sweet caramel in the short aroma. Thin mouthfeel and good lacing. Pale malts give a digestive biscuit base with soft caramel notes present. Slight metallic tang to the not too dry bitter aftertaste. Finish is slightly malty but weak in the mouth. Better session bitters out there.

name: Mansfield Riding Traditional Bitter
review: Cask @ Market Porter, Borough SE1. Pours a clear copper color with a small off-white head. has a fruity malty caramel aroma. Fruity malty caramel flavor with some hoppy hints. Has a fruity malty caramel finish.

name: Mansfield Riding Traditional Bitter
review: Cask at the Hope Tap (JDW), Reading. Amber with a thin cream head; caramel aroma; sweet caramel malt flavour; short, rough, bitter finish. An unexceptional Yorkshire-style bitter.

name: Mansfield Riding Traditional Bitter
review: Cask@Wheatsheaf, Cropwell Bishop. Golden/amber beer with a creamy light head. The aroma is light and the flavour is light, floral and watery hopped. Overall an average beer.

name: Mansfield Riding Traditional Bitter
review: cask at The Whole in the Wall, York: translucent light copper color with small white cask head. Slight aroma with malt and slight bit of hops in the background. Well balanced tending a bit towards malt. Pretty wattery. Nothing special.

name: Mansfield Riding Traditional Bitter
review: Cask at The Swan in Cheltenham. Used copper with a small dense cap of off-white. Carmel, plum and dark bread aroma. A wholesome smell. Carmel sweetness, an estery lingering fruit. A pleasant pint.

name: Mansfield Riding Traditional Bitter
review: Clear dark golden color, medium creamy head. Light hops in aroma, smoothly bitter and caramel malty in taste. Bit dry palate.

name: Mansfield Riding Traditional Bitter
review: Copper coloured, lasting head. Caramel malty aroma, some "zoethout" in flavour. Smooth brew.

name: Tröegs Pale Ale
review: A very solid IPA, very NW approach. Lots of pine, some lingering citrus sweetness. Tried for the first time back in 2010.

name: Tröegs Pale Ale
review: blackberry backlog, Tap, pours a clear orange gold with medium head. Smell is pine grapefruit, sweet fruit, malt and lemon.. Flavor was orange, pine, sweet malt, and wood. Bland and nothing to write home about. Medium body

name: Tröegs Pale Ale
review: Draft at CAH. Pours pale golden yellow with a slight orange hew. Aroma is lemon/lime line Sprite with biscuits and cereal. Finish is pleasant with a soft hoppy and stone fruit finish.

name: Tröegs Pale Ale
review: Golden yellow appearance with a thin head. The flavor is slightly effervescent. It has some slight malty and maybe a pineapple note. It finishes with a traditional hoppy character

name: Tröegs Pale Ale
review: Pours a highly carbonated, dark yellow with a fair amount of head. The aroma is pears, malt, a little white grape thing going on, too. The flavor is mild and clean but pretty good. A mild, mellow malt on the finish is probably the defining characteristic. Pretty good pale ale.

name: Tröegs Pale Ale
review: Bottle pour into tulip glass from Leary’s Fine Wines, Newburyport, MA. Aroma is bread dough with caramel and mild pineapple. Appearance is hazy gold with nice sparkle, finger-width foamy white head with fair retention and nice lacing. Taste is mild sweet caramel malt, citrus and mild bitter finish. Palate is light-to-medium bodied with thin, dry texture you can feel at the back teeth. Overall, fairly mild all around. Not bad, just not very bold.

name: Tröegs Pale Ale
review: 12 oz. bottle. Pours a clear gold color with a thin white head that settles to a film leaving some nice lacing. Aroma is a nice combination of pine hops with a touch of citrus in the background. Medium body, the taste is a good balance of hops and malt. Lots of carbonation on the tongue. Slight bitter finish. Great pale ale, I’ll miss this one when it’s gone.

name: Tröegs Pale Ale
review: Tap at Munich Tap House, 25th November 15. Pours clean and clear, light coloured. Aroma is fresh, not too much going on though. Taste is refreshing, clean, some hops, not enough maybe. Fairly standard but reasonable pale

name: Tröegs Pale Ale
review: Draft from the brewery. Pine, floral notes with slight citrus. Above average carbonation. Golden color. Lacing on glass. Some grass notes. Pretty good. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Tröegs Pale Ale
review: Pours a clear golden yellow with a white head. Aroma of citrus zest. More lemon than grapefruit. Taste is lemony with a bright bitterness. Very dry in the finish. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Tröegs Rugged Trail Nut Brown Ale
review: [On tap at brewery] Aroma and flavour are sweet, fruity nuts and sweet. Flavour has some toasted hazelnut quality as well as dark bread crust. Moderate bitterness. Medium light body, medium caronbation, fairly crisp.

name: Tröegs Rugged Trail Nut Brown Ale
review: deep brown coloring with a slight burnt chestnut aroma. taste is slight woody and malt with roasted nuts. nice full to medium mouth. tap at brewery.

name: Tröegs Rugged Trail Nut Brown Ale
review: A better than average brown. Murky delightfulness. Sweet and very mild toastiness. Tried for the first time in Pittsburgh in 2010.

name: Tröegs Rugged Trail Nut Brown Ale
review: Sample on tap @ the brewery. Pours a dark brown cola color with a thin white ring. Not much of an aroma. Some dark malt flavors but pretty ordinary. No nut flavor at all. Blah.

name: Tröegs Rugged Trail Nut Brown Ale
review: Pint glass from the brewery. Dark brown medium bodied beer, lightly carbonated. Bitter finish.

name: Tröegs Rugged Trail Nut Brown Ale
review: Location: Pint on tap at tap room Appearance: Lighter amber brown almost clear. thin head of smaller off white bubbles Nose: medium roasted malt. Roasted Nut, Coffee and a bitter edge behind it all. Taste: Hints of roasted nuts. Bitter is the strongest flavor element. Quite different. Hoppy. Body: Thin to medium. No real texture. Parting thoughts: A hoppy nut brown ale. The bitter edge was unique. Not bad mind you, just different.

name: Tröegs Rugged Trail Nut Brown Ale
review: Flight shared with ebone1988 at the brewery. The pour is a dark amber color, strong brown colorings, with a thin light gray ring of head and a couple spots of lace. The aroma is very bitter for being so malty. Lots of bitter malts. Light hop. Little earthiness. The flavor is much of the same. The bitter malt and hop combo makes this drink like an ESB. The mouth feel is thin and watery with hardly any carbonation. Falls right off of the tongue. Aftertaste is bitter malt. Meh.

name: Tröegs Rugged Trail Nut Brown Ale
review: Flight shared with koleminer20 at Tröegs. Aroma is bitter, roast, dirt, trace nuts, weird. Appearance is amber brown, light tan head, clear. Taste is spice, dirt, caramel malt, nuts, bitter. Mouthfeel is medium body, light carbonation, bitter malt aftertaste. Overall, a lot of weird things happened here.

name: Tröegs Rugged Trail Nut Brown Ale
review: It pours dark brown with plenty of lacing and an off white head. It has a strong aroma of nuts. There are flavors of nuts, roasted malts, and floral hops. It is moderately bitter with a good deal of carbonation.

name: Tröegs Rugged Trail Nut Brown Ale
review: Draft. Pours a dark brown. Aroma of nuts, caramel. Taste is slightly watery with caramel, slight roasted malts, hazelnut, and a mild bitter hop finish. On dry side. Ok. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Tröegs Bavarian Lager
review: Rated from old notes. A dark gold lager, pours with medium head. The caramel malts are dominant both in taste and aroma. Smooth and unchanging throughout. Decent.

name: Tröegs Bavarian Lager
review: Bottle. Pours a copper body with an off white head. Malty body with some light bitter notes, some bread and a bitter pine finish. Light with a soft finish. Average.

name: Tröegs Bavarian Lager
review: Poured a deeper copper color body with a thick white foam. The aroma is grains and carmel malts. The flavor start with a carmel and honey shot while finishing a little doughy.

name: Tröegs Bavarian Lager
review: Copper colored with a lasting off-white head. Aroma of honey toast, fruit, and mildly spicy hops. Flavor is fruity initially (apples, plums), slightly sweet malts, spicy and earthy hops in the finish. It is ashame this is no longer being made.

name: Tröegs Bavarian Lager
review: From my long lost notes. 12 oz. bottle purchased as part of a sampler case in July, 2004. Pours a clear amber with a fizzy slightly off-white head. Light, pleasant aroma of caramel and malt. The flavor is again mild caramel and malt with some light hops at the finish. An easy to drink good lager.

name: Tröegs Bavarian Lager
review: Bottle sampled. Pours deep copper with aa average size off-white head. Aroma of sweet malts, caramel, nutty, and slight traces of hops to the nose. The flavor is sweet, toasted caramel malts, nuts, and small traces of hops in the finish. Average body, good brew.

name: Tröegs Bavarian Lager
review: In a 12oz bottle. A good over all beer. fairly typical for a good lager. makes you wonder how people can drink marco lager.

name: Tröegs Bavarian Lager
review: Clear amber color with almost no head. Malts with some bread and butterscotch seem to compose the aroma. Smooth character for a lager. Clean malty flavor. One of the best lagers I’ve ever had.

name: Tröegs Bavarian Lager
review: I very pleasant tasting lager. Sold at a good price. Better than Sam Adams lager

name: Tröegs Bavarian Lager
review: Thanks to kramer17801 for the bottle. Nose hhas rich malt, maple, butterscotch. Some spritzy hops behind that with a hint of breadiness. Maple & bread u pfront, rich malt gives way to butterscotch/dark fruit finish.

name: Orkney Dark Island (Bottle)
review: Shared bottle at Cardinal. Pours dark brown to black with little off-white head. Aroma of dark bread, fruits, distinct diacetyl. Tastes slightly sweet with some bitterness. Thin bodied.

name: Orkney Dark Island (Bottle)
review: Good malty character of this ruby coloured Orkney brew makes for good session

name: Orkney Dark Island (Bottle)
review: Thanks hannah! Darkest brown. Aroma is dark chocolate slight mushroom some cocoa also good melasses some deep vanilla or so. Taste is a bit umami with good bitterness and a bit more complex sugars. Pretty tasty and good intensity for less than 5abv. Good one.

name: Orkney Dragonhead (Bottle)
review: Black beer opaque with a nice brown head, rather persistent. Roasted aromas of malt, with notes of chocolate, black coffee, licorice and touch of smoked. That we find to taste, evenimproving, dry and roasted, with a full body, very chocolate-espresso, slightly smoked but a little thin in alcohol.

name: Orkney Dragonhead (Bottle)
review: As Stouts go this has many characteristics of both a stout and an IPA. A heavy toasted oat flavour with an underlying bitterness and hoppy finish.

name: Orkney Dragonhead (Bottle)
review: Bottle, from Tesco, Orkney. Jet black, thin but lasting coffee beige head and gentle condition. Pleasant roasted coffee beans, blackberry and sweet liquorice in the nose, soft and dry in the mouth with a roasted barley bitterness, a brief hint of sweetness and slight liquorice notes. Finish is quite bitter and dry with a lingering sweet coffee note and more liquorice.

name: Orkney Red MacGregor (4%) (Bottle)
review: Malty grainy aroma. Pours copper body with tan lace and ruby tint. Taste is predominantly bitter with some background fruitiness. Palate is medium bodied oily texture average carbonation and a bitter finish. An Orcadian beer but an ordinary one.

name: Orkney Red MacGregor (4%) (Bottle)
review: A 500ml bottle from Waitrose, pours a deep red colour. Tastes of malt & a touch smokey. Decent red ale

name: Orkney Red MacGregor (4%) (Bottle)
review: A: Amber with a medium off-white head. N: Berries and caramel T: Fruits, toast and toffee. P: Medium O: Enjoyable

name: Orkney Red MacGregor (4%) (Bottle)
review: 500ml bottle. Pours a clear coppery red/deep amber with a creamy off white head. Looks lovely in the glass. Aroma of dark/red fruits, caramel, bread. Slightly floral and earthy. Taste of toast bread, burnt malts, caramel, dark/red fruits, some spices. Light sweetness with a nice bitter backbone. Medium mouthfeel. Low carbonation. Very nice balance of earthy hops and malts. A solid Scottish red ale. Would definitely drink this again.

name: Orkney Red MacGregor (4%) (Bottle)
review: Clear red/ochre liquid, hardly any head. Light smoky aroma. Light body, average carbonation. Taste is bitter, a bit smoky.

name: Orkney Red MacGregor (4%) (Bottle)
review: Deep amber red from the bottle with off white/tan head. Carmelly malt, lightly floral and a touch hoppier than expected. Very smooth and full flavored for the abv.

name: Orkney Red MacGregor (4%) (Bottle)
review: From the 500 ml. bottle stamped L5187-10:55. The color is ruby red amber with a modest off-white head. The aroma is floral with a caramel-toffee character. There is also a subtle sort of pipe tobacco or peat moss character on the nose too. The body is thinner than I would have liked. The taste has the same sweet malt toffee, caramel, and peat moss character with a musty bitterness to end.

name: Orkney Red MacGregor (4%) (Bottle)
review: Pours dark red-brown with a decent off-white, almost beige head. Fruity aroma. An elegant bitterness combines with roasted malts and slightly herbal notes. Flavorful, well-balanced flavors with a bitter touch. Very good!

name: Orkney Red MacGregor (4%) (Bottle)
review: medium bitterness, light sweetness, very bitter, medium sourness, caramel, leather, caramel,

name: Orkney Red MacGregor (4%) (Bottle)
review: Tap @ Bothy bar, our favorite pub in Kirkwall. Red smoothly frothy bitter ale

name: Orkney Northern Light (Bottle)
review: Bottle from Beers of Europe. Appearance - golden with a proportionate head. Nose - caramel and just a hint of lemon. Taste - more lemon with biscuit this time. Palate - light bodied with a creamy texture. Dry finish. Overall - decent.

name: Orkney Northern Light (Bottle)
review: Barwa z³ota, klarowna, gêsta piana d³ugo utrzymuje siê w kuflu. Smak zbo¿owy, trawiasty, gorzkawy z delikatnymi nutami s³odu. Posmak delikatnie gorzki.

name: Orkney Northern Light (Bottle)
review: 500ml bottle from Tesco. Clear golden with a white head. Sweet aroma - pale malts, bread, hay, citrus, some caramel. Taste is more of the same, with floral notes and hints of honey. Light bitterness in the aftertaste. Smooth mouthfeel. Low carbonation. Nicely made and well balanced. Thoroughly enjoyable.

name: Orkney Northern Light (Bottle)
review: Pours golden with fine head. Some citrus, gentle bitterness, after all mild and easy to drink yet flavorful enough. Good.

name: Orkney Northern Light (Bottle)
review: 0,5l bottle from Stromness Coop. Refreshing but not more, csicsak de nem góré.

name: Orkney Northern Light (Bottle)
review: Bottle in Dundee, Scotland. Pleasant ale, drinkable, mild hops, ligth citrus finish, easy.

name: Orkney Northern Light (Bottle)
review: Pours a light amber with a white head. Nose is sour apple, apricot and slightly sweet malt. Light mouth feel, taste is green apple, light caramel malt, apricot and lemon. Not bad, but not great either.

name: Orkney Northern Light (Bottle)
review: 50cl Bottle, thanks Bob & Rosemary! Clear deep golden colour, white head. Aroma of unripe fruits, light leafy, hint of toffee, medium sweet, apple. Flavour is light to medium sweet, fruity, red apple, green banana, firm bitterness underneath, bitter finish, hint of toffee. Light bodied, watery.

name: Orkney Northern Light (Bottle)
review: Bottle, 500 ml at the Clachan, Dornie. Pours golden, white head. Malty, bit perfumy. Sweet, light bodied, light bitter finish. Bland and disappointing.

name: Orkney Northern Light (Bottle)
review: Flasche 50cl. Typische Pale-Ale Malzfarbe, leichte Trübung. In der Nase fruchtige Hopfen und obergärige Hefe. In Antrunk viel kaltgehopftes, schön in die Malzigkeit eingebunden, Sehr erfrischend und sehr komplex angesichts des Alkoholgehalts. Sehr gelungen!

name: Nelson Hardy's Kiss
review: (cask @ The Coopers Arms , Rochester) A rich -malty sweet dark ale , that had some ’Old Ale’ character and tendancies . The ale drank down with notes of caramel and what felt like chcolate malt had been used. A little winey , fruity and bloody like old peculier or something. The palate , while treacly , did offer some late light musty dryness. Full bodied ale that feels more boozy than 4% . Drinkable and somehow comforting

name: Nelson Hardy's Kiss
review: Cask handpull at Simple Simons, Canterbury. Amber with lasting beige head. Yeasty, malty, fruity best bitter. Not sure all the parts go together well. All fighting with each other. Fine, but not as good as the Rochester Bitter.

name: Nelson Hardy's Kiss
review: Dark tan color and low tight head from the cask. Light toasted malt with some sugary sweetness. Reserved hopping and tinge of bitterness at the very end. Thinish and rather uniteresting.

name: Nelson Hardy's Kiss
review: Cask Conditioned, at the Wenlock Arms, London. Red mahagony color. Little foamy head. Light bitter taste with sweet intervalls. Nice but nothing special.

name: Nelson Hardy's Kiss
review: Cask Conditioned, at the Wenlock Arms, London. Good solid beer this, the very first at the Lock last Friday. Lovely amber coloured body with as white head. Hoppy with moderate bitterness, the malts play a secondary role in what is best described as a full classic bitter. Initially there was some confusion, SilkT et al, thought that this beer was Harvey’s – Kiss Ale but my notes didn’t say that. Committed as I am to rating quality, I returned to the Wenlock on the Saturday to double check with Dave. Flagship (Nelson Brewery) is what it was. Just to make doubly sure of everything I fronted up on the Sunday as well…..to find the absolute gem, Adnams Oyster Stout, just out of retirement. Wow!!

name: Nelson Hardy's Kiss
review: April, 2003: Three Daws, Gravesend. Sweet malt dominates - a mollases taste which coats the roof of your mouth. Hops are in the background. [2.4] March, 2004: The Rising Sun, Kemsing. Badged as Hardy’s Kiss. Amber bitter. Fresh on, but a bit cloudy. Fruity notes with just enough bittering hops to provide a neutral palate. A restrained and undeveloped beer that somehow manages to produce some oaky character, plus some brown sugar and watery caramel flavours. Undeveloped malt aroma. Nelson’s yeast seems a slow acting yeast which does not fully attenuate resulting in an interesting oaked malt quality which sadly does not quite suit my palate. [2.1 Feb, 2005: Three Daws, Gravesend. Light orange flavours. Drier and more gulpable than on previous samples. Enjoyable. [2.7]

name: Nelson Futtock
review: Cask Stillage at Lewisham Theatre, Catford 14/06/2001 Dark coloured and strong in alcohol. Slight malt finish.

name: Nelson Futtock
review: White Cliffs Winter Ales Fest. Gravity. Lovely colour - a deep scarlet. Smooth and flavoursome but lacking in real impact. Nice balance, but it then wanders between watery and gritty. Everything fades quickly. Vintage ale aroma.

name: Great Lakes Dortmunder Gold
review: 12 oz bottle, pours coppery gold clear. Medium body. Bready aroma, caramel malt taste and bitter hops finish.

name: Great Lakes Dortmunder Gold
review: Clear with amber color. Good head retention. Toasty grain with overtones of mint. Minimal hop bitterness. Very unique and drinkable.

name: Great Lakes Dortmunder Gold
review: Pours lightly hazy dark golden with thin, white head. Aroma is light caramel and light roast. Taste is caramel, moving to light roast and light hops. Finish is toasty.

name: Great Lakes Dortmunder Gold
review: 12oz bottle. 9/4/19 BB date. Appearance: Deep golden, crystal clear, with a thick pillowy white head that lingers with nice lacing. Aroma: Breadiness is strong with quite a bit of caramel. All malt, with no noticeable hop or yeast contribution. Taste: Medium caramel malt sweetness with a light breadiness and toasted crust on the back end. Moderate bitterness pears only on the swallow to balance out the malt. Mouthfeel: Medium bodied with a low to moderate carbonation. Finish: Malt lingers long after the swallow, primarily with caramel and some bread crust. Overall: Really clean and crisp with a strong malt character throughout, with a complimentary but not overpowering caramel and toasted crust. World class

name: Great Lakes Dortmunder Gold
review: Pours amber from a tap. Wintergreen/birch beer aroma, flavor is an oddly sweet birch beer, very thin. Okay beer.

name: Great Lakes Dortmunder Gold
review: Solid flavor that goes down smooth. Would drink this beer again.............. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

name: Great Lakes Dortmunder Gold
review: Bottle into flute glass. Amber with ok head. Yeasty aroma with some hints of grapefruit? Similar taste. Good malt balance. Solid larger

name: Great Lakes Dortmunder Gold
review: bottle oro carico sciuma media buona mltatura discreto corpo amaro medio leggero erbaceo

name: Great Lakes Dortmunder Gold
review: Bottle. Very smooth, malty lager. Definitely sweet. Clean finish. Very well finished with no off-flavors. Many of the current IPA microbeers have a punchy, hoppy hook. They create a "wow" at the tasting, but they quickly fatigue the palate, and are ultimately not a drinking beer. This one is the opposite: unassuming at first, but so smooth and drinkable. Extremely well finished, and one of my new favorites!

name: Great Lakes Dortmunder Gold
review: Mild hops with a nice balancing bready malt. A little malty sweetness. A lot of flavor for a lager.

name: Nelson Crows Nest
review: Golden and still in appearance. Aromas are fruity pear and floral. Flavours are pears, apples with dry hops. Not very biiter on the finish. Just reasonable.

name: Nelson Crows Nest
review: Cask Conditioned, at The Frog & Todd, Gillingham. Bright as can be, golden honey colour, charming. Strong volatile aroma, that dominates the entire experience. Alcohol, perhaps paint thinner, permeates this beer. A fight with one of the looks was narrowly avoided as I quickly explained we were not beer wankers but just two guys doing our job, sure I said ‘you can make a living our of drinking beer, but some days it just hard work’ the guy loved us from that point on. The second funny thing was that the brewer walked in whilst we were drinking this, Silk quickly collars him about the poor quality, that was a mistake….I don’t think I’ve ever seen someone say so much which meant so little, including some of the greatest politicians. Part of the life threatening SilkTork Gillingham Magical Mystery Tour.

name: Nelson Crows Nest
review: Cask Conditioned at The Hobgoblin, Oxford. Limpid gold colour with little head. Citric hoppy beer with an orange like background. Little conditioning and a little flat.

name: Nelson Crows Nest
review: May, 2003: Gravity, Rochester Beer Festival. Gee, getting quite a skinful now. Time for something to eat. Anyway - pale gold colour. Citric cidery flavour with the citric tang progressing well into the finish. Somewhat watery and lacking the distinctive fresh bite of a typical Golden Ale. [1.9] April, 2004: Frog & Toad, Gillingham. Orange-gold possibly premium bitter. Served slightly warm. Pale malt aroma. Fruit with a late hop bite. Chrissie finished this. Good girl. [1.9]

name: Great Lakes Holy Moses White Ale
review: Pale gold poured with a thick white head. The aroma is light coriander and citrus. Light bodied. Good.

name: Great Lakes Holy Moses White Ale
review: Amber pour with bright white head. A bit too floral and spicy for my taste. On tap @ Three Cellars, Oak Creek, Wisconsin.

name: Great Lakes Holy Moses White Ale
review: Slight haze. Yeast aromatics come through nicely for the style with a refreshing medium-light body.

name: Great Lakes Holy Moses White Ale
review: Bottle. Pours a cloudy gold color with a white head and great retention. Good lacing. Light Belgian yeast nose. Similar taste. Light Belgian yeast flavor cut by light background spices, keeping it from getting too yeasty. Traces of citrus. Soft mouthfeel. I'm not a witbier fan, but this one isn't bad.

name: Great Lakes Holy Moses White Ale
review: Cloudy pink orange appearance. Aroma is gets better as it warms. Sweet Raspberry and yeasts aroma. Very light palate. Taste is Belgian yeasts with fruit sweetness. Tap

name: Great Lakes Holy Moses White Ale
review: On tap at The Old Town Pour House in Oak Brook, IL., dispensed to a tulip displaying a hazed, golden color, a persistent finger's width of soft white froth, with wavy spots & strands of lacing. The nose needed a bit of warming to expose soft grain/wheat, light fruitiness as lemon, pit variety, and orange peel, with subtle spice, mainly coriander. Light to medium bodied, with lively carbonation, the taste was similar notes, with some tartness & tanginess, a touch of earthy & rind-like bitterness, and dryness to the finish. Not too spiced or sweet. A decent style representation.

name: Great Lakes Holy Moses White Ale
review: Twelve .ounce draft at The Original Hot Dog Shop in Oakland, Pittsburgh. Taste was very nice on a 93 degree summer day in the 'Burgh. No complaints, just compliments on a beer well done.

name: Great Lakes Holy Moses White Ale
review: Bottle from Franks. Clear golden. Hint of wheat, mostly malts. Bit of orange peel, a bit spicy. Med carbo. A bit harsh. Lacks wheat and fruitiness. Quite poor.

name: Great Lakes Holy Moses White Ale
review: Pours a hazy gold with a thin white head. Aroma is floral and spicy notes. Flavor is similar, sweet, with hints of cinnamon. Well-carbonated and crisp. I enjoyed this.

name: Great Lakes Holy Moses White Ale
review: 12 oz bottle pours a hazy golden color with medium white head. There's almost nothing to smell. Aroma is faint and wheaty. Flavor is dominated by coriander, over a base of floral hops. Taste is slightly bitter. Body is light to medium with average carbonation. A decent witbier, but not one I'll seek out again. This is the only Great Lakes brew that has disappointed me.

name: Nelson Spanker
review: Sampled at the red cow, Sandwich. No head and a clear brown color. Small aroma of an ocean beach with sea weed. Light acidic ( lactic) taste that over powers malt and hops. Medium body and a low bitterness.

name: Nelson Spanker
review: July 2017 - Cask handpull at The Crosse Keys London on a warm day in London after crushing my new iPhone under weights at the gym. As ’Nelson Spanker’, 4.2%. Dark amber brown with an orange hue, still with a very small ring of head. Aroma is light bready malt and apple peel. Smells a bit dodgy. Body is smooth with soft carbonation. Taste is watery with some Brighton rock sweetness, "candy cane", light red apple, very light malt, minerally, subtle floral hops. Not much to it but it’s a subtle old school bitter in good condition with malt, water, yeast and hop nuance all in tandem. The flavour is actually pretty good, well balanced. Could drink a few pints of it. (5-4-7-3-14=3.3)

name: Nelson Spanker
review: Cadk harrys bar wakefield. Amber good white head. Malty aroma taste caramel malts fruits light bitters. Medium body. Ok stuff.

name: Nelson Spanker
review: Cask handpull at County Hotel, JDW, Ashford. Copper colour with lasting beige head. Rather a lovely biscuity bitter. Good malty fruit too. Excellent yeast aroma. Like a digestive biscuit with red berry fruit jam on. Excellent dry finish. This brewery is getting better.

name: Nelson Spanker
review: 1/2 pint cask, Cloisters. Deep reddish golden colour and a creamy medium-sized off-white head that seems like it wants to disintegrate. Nutty rich malty aroma without being sweet. Prickly toffee-like malty flavour with a crisp minty bite. Mouthfeel is slightly acidic with a crisp hop bitterness. Interesting use of malts. It is quite unlike the other cask ales I’ve had the last few days. Smooth texture. I suspect there to be some oxisation introduced during the brewing process.
